column3:
It has been nearly a month since we transitioned to Phase Three of our re-opening. Over the past week, we have seen an increase in the number of local cases. We must remain vigilant to avoid an uncontrolled resurgence of community cases.

To further mitigate the risk of large community clusters arising from infections that spread within a household and through them to all their contacts, we will impose a cap of 8 distinct visitors per household per day. This will take effect from 26 January 2021. Individuals should also limit themselves to visiting at most two other households a day, as much as possible.

We will also step up enforcement checks at F&B establishments, malls and other crowded public spaces during the upcoming Chinese New Year period. Strict enforcement actions will be taken against individuals and operators who do not comply with safe management measure.

As community interactions are likely to increase in the leadup to Chinese New Year, we will carry out surveillance testing for stallholders, shop owners, persons in the food and beverage industry, as well as food delivery persons, who are operating in and around Chinatown. The testing will take place from 8 February to 9 February 2021.

We seek the cooperation of all Singaporeans to remain united and disciplined in our fight against COVID-19. Observe all safe management measures, see a doctor and get tested when sick, and be vaccinated when it is offered to you. Together, we can look forward to a safer and healthier 2021.
https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/tightening-safe-management-measures-and-update-on-vaccination-plans

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As we embark on our journey of Phase Three today and the year draws to a close, Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong has penned a letter to our healthcare family to thank them for their unwavering commitment to keep every patient safe amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

While 2020 has been a gruelling year for our healthcare workers, it is also a year defined by a strong sense of mission, purpose and camaraderie as the healthcare fraternity came together to keep Singapore safe.

It will be some time before the storm will pass but we are quietly confident that whatever comes our way next, our healthcare family will be able to take it our stride, and once again find strength to confront adversity together. The pandemic may have tested our mettle, but it will not break our resolve and spirit.

Read on for Minister’s full letter to the healthcare family.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce will start Phase Three of re-opening from 28 December 2020, and allow for the further re-opening of the following activities in the community:

1️⃣ Social gatherings will be allowed to comprise up to 8 persons, an increase from 5 persons today. Households may also receive up to 8 visitors at any point in time.
2️⃣ For malls and large standalone stores, we will increase the capacity limit from 10 square metres per person to 8 square metres per person; attractions may also start applying to the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) to increase their operating capacity from 50% to up to 65%.
3️⃣ All Religious Organisations may increase their capacity for congregational and other worship services to up to 250 persons (in zones of up to 50 persons each for congregational services). Congregational and other worship services as well as religious rites/ prayers conducted at places of worship may involve live performance elements with the necessary safe management measures in place.
4️⃣ For marriage solemnisations held in the home, the hosting household will be able to invite up to 8 visitors (excluding members of the hosting household, the solemniser and vendors), even if this exceeds the existing cap of 10 persons.
5️⃣ Marriage solemnisations (in indoor venues only), funerals and funerary-related activities will also be allowed to have live instrumental music (except for wind instruments) with the necessary safe management measures in place.
6️⃣ We will allow indoor live performances to have up to 250 persons in zones of up to 50 persons each. We will also expand outdoor live performance pilots to 250 persons in zones of up to 50 persons each, to ensure that venues are still able to safely manage larger outdoor performances and mitigate the gathering of peripheral crowds.

We will continue to conduct pilots in some higher-risk activities and settings such as busking and live performances in outdoor venues, karaoke, nightlife, which will allow us to assess how these activities can take place and scale up safely.

If the local COVID-19 situation remains stable and we are able to deploy more of our enablers to allow more activities to resume safely, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will consider allowing further resumption of activities, over the course of Phase Three.

Even as we cross this milestone, we must continue to remain vigilant in the coming months and avoid an uncontrolled resurgence of cases which could slow or even reverse our progress.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moving-into-phase-three-of-re-opening

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

To ensure the continued safe resumption of social and economic activities, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will extend community surveillance testing operations to more identified groups in the community.

The Taskforce has been progressively conducting testing operations for identified community groups, such as stallholders, food delivery personnel and cashiers across the island. These operations aim to provide a better picture of population prevalence and facilitate the early containment of cryptic cases in the community, especially as we continue to reopen our economy and allow more activities to resume. More than 5,000 individuals have been tested at Marine Parade, Ang Mo Kio and Taman Jurong since September 2020, and all who have participated in these voluntary testing exercises have tested negative for COVID-19.

Government agencies will be reaching out to other identified community groups to offer COVID-19 testing on a one-time basis. We are offering COVID-19 testing to stallholders in and around Tekka Centre this week. In the coming weeks, we will also be offering COVID-19 testing to individuals working at key delivery centres (e.g. Pasir Panjang Wholesale Centre) and key logistics delivery companies.

We strongly encourage individuals in these identified community groups to come forward and utilise the testing services offered. The costs of these tests will be fully borne by the government.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-and-community-surveillance-testing-operations

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As we progressively re-open our borders and resume more social and economic activities in Phase Three, we should expect to see the number of cases increase, beyond the current single digits or even low teens each day. This is why we need to double down on our surveillance and testing efforts to nip the seeds of transmission to prevent further spread.

To support a larger range of needs as we resume more economic and community activities, we will now make COVID-19 testing more accessible for all. From 30 November 2020 2359hrs, any company or individual who requires a PCR test will be able to procure such services from approved providers. This includes individuals who require pre-departure testing. Individuals will no longer be required to seek approval from MOH for pre-departure tests. The list of clinics and providers approved to provide COVID-19 testing at off-site locations can be found on https://go.gov.sg/covid19pcrtestproviders. We are also conducting pilots on pre-event testing using antigen rapid tests to enable more large-scale and higher-risk activities to resume in a safer manner.

The most important enabler is safe management. By keeping our social groups small, maintaining safe distancing and exercising social responsibility, we are all contributing to the nationwide effort to prevent spread.

While testing and safe management can help to mitigate spread, it is not foolproof. This is where a strengthened contact tracing regime incorporating both SafeEntry and TraceTogether is important. We encourage everyone to download and use the TraceTogether App or collect a TraceTogether Token for use at TraceTogether-only SafeEntry (ToS) premises, when ToS is implemented. ToS will only be enforced after everyone who prefers to use the TraceTogether Token has had the chance to collect one at a Community Centre/Club in their constituency.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/safeguarding-lives-and-livelihoods

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As we continue on our journey towards Phase Three, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will continue to build on our efforts to enable the public and businesses to resume normal activities as much as possible, within safe limits. With the cooperation of Singaporeans and businesses, we have brought the situation under control and kept community transmission low.

We need to re-open our borders safely to safeguard our aviation hub status which is essential to many of our businesses, our jobs and our future, and support our social and community needs. In re-opening our borders, we must do so safely so that we can facilitate more travel while minimising the impact on public health. We have taken a risk-managed approach to our border controls, based on the assessed risk of importation and onward transmission in the community.

To further reduce importation risk from high-risk countries/regions, from 17 November 2020 2359 hours, all inbound travellers who are not Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents, except those from lower-risk countries/ regions, will need to take a COVID-19 PCR test within 72 hours before departure. These travellers will still be required to serve their SHN upon arrival in Singapore and be tested at the end of their SHN.

Singapore’s border measures will evolve as the global situation changes. We encourage everyone to check the Safe Travel website (https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg) regularly for the latest updates.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/safeguarding-lives-and-livelihoods

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

It has been more than half a year since we entered the Circuit Breaker, and more than 4 months since we started our gradual reopening. To continue our journey of safe re-opening towards Phase Three, several conditions and enablers need to be in place. In particular, we must continue scaling up testing and tracing efforts as well as adhering to the safe management measures.

To ensure that the situation remains under control, we will each have to keep up the habits and practices that we have painstakingly put in place over the past few months. These include keeping group sizes small, maintaining a safe distance and practising social responsibility such as mask-wearing.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce is piloting the use of pre-event COVID-19 testing for larger-scale and higher-risk activities to reduce the risk of a COVID-19 case being present at the event. Given the need for shorter turnaround time, we are exploring the use of antigen rapid tests, which can return fairly accurate results quickly.

We also need to continue to strengthen our contact tracing regime, leveraging our two key digital contact tracing tools – SafeEntry and TraceTogether. We need greater participation in the TraceTogether Programme to help us quickly identify close contacts of COVID-positive cases.

With the above conditions and enablers in place, we will be able to move to Phase Three. But the exact timing of these changes will depend on our collective ability to cooperate with the requirements.

In Phase Three, the group size for gatherings outside the home could be increased from the present 5 persons to 8 persons. The number of visitors allowed to homes could similarly increase to 8. Capacity limits for events like congregational worship and weddings could be increased to multiple zones of 50 persons.

As we make these adjustments towards a new COVID normal, the Taskforce will continue to explore parallel tracks such as vaccines, treatment, testing and other technologies which could enable us to further ease restrictions and resume connectivity with the world in a safe manner. The journey ahead may be long, but with the cooperation of everyone, we are confident of transiting smoothly to Phase Three and beyond, emerging stronger from this experience.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/roadmap-to-phase-three

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

When will we transition into Phase 3 of re-opening? When can we stop wearing masks when we are out? How can I better understand schemes like MediSave and MediShield Life? These are some of the questions on Singaporeans’ minds, and also ours at the Ministry of Health as we seek to address these pressing matters in healthcare. Even as we tackle the COVID-19 outbreak to keep Singapore safe in this new normal, we continue with our efforts to improve Singaporeans’ health and wellbeing, from helping our seniors to enjoy their silver years, to ensuring that no Singaporean will be denied appropriate healthcare because of an inability to pay.

Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong sat down with Liu Zhipeng of Lianhe Zaobao 联合早报 to talk about some of these pressing matters. You can watch the full interview and find out more at https://www.zaobao.com/zvideos/news/story20200913-1084415?utm_source=ZB_Android&utm_medium=share

ZAOBAO.COM.SG
【我的部门有三急】卫生部长颜金勇

Over the coming weeks, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will continue taking further steps towards a new COVID-normal.

We are in the final stretch of dormitory clearances, which will allow the vast majority of workers to resume work by mid to late August 2020. The Inter-agency Taskforce will complete the testing of all workers in the dormitories by 7 August 2020. This means that all the dormitories will be COVID-cleared, with the exception of several standalone blocks which serve as quarantine facilities.

As we gradually open our borders, we are adjusting our charging policy for COVID-19 treatment to support returning travellers should they be infected while participating in permitted essential travel. From 7 August 2020, all outbound Singapore Citizens, Permanent Residents and Long Term Pass holder travellers who travel abroad under permitted travel arrangements will be able to tap on regular healthcare financing arrangements for their inpatient medical bills, should they have onset of symptoms within 14 days of their return to Singapore and require hospital admission for suspected COVID-19 infection.

While more activities and events are allowed to resume over time, most events should remain fully virtual or hybrid physical-virtual where possible to protect our loved ones and fellow Singaporeans. Social responsibility remains key, and we will need to work and innovate together so that we can achieve a new COVID-19 normal where we can resume most activities and events safely.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/final-stretch-of-dormitory-clearance-further-steps-towards-a-new-covid-normal

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce will be easing restrictions on two key life events – namely weddings and wakes/ funerals – as part of a careful, calibrated resumption of activities in Phase Two.

From 4 August 2020, marriage solemnizations will be allowed to take place with up to 50 persons (including the couple, excluding the Solemniser and vendors) for the entire event, subject to the venue’s capacity limit based on safe management principles. This will apply to venues such as places of worship, HDB common areas and other external venues.

In addition, we will launch a pilot where each wedding couple will also be allowed to hold one wedding reception (including food and drinks), with up to 50 attendees (including the couple) for the entire duration of the event, in venues that are permitted to serve food and drinks (e.g. restaurants, hotels), and subject to their capacity limit based on safe management principles. All other wedding-related activities including customary rites and ceremonies, would have to adhere to prevailing gathering size limits, e.g. up to 5 visitors to each household, or up to 5 persons in a group outside the home.

To facilitate more family members and friends to pay their last respects at wakes and funerals, from 4 August 2020, up to 30 persons may be present at any one time, subject to the venue’s capacity limit based on safe management principles.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/easing-restrictions-on-key-life-events

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce continues to closely monitor the COVID-19 situation, and take aggressive actions to prevent, detect and contain local transmissions.

We have been stepping up our surveillance, active case finding and containment efforts, in order to detect and ringfence cases of infection as early as possible. Where infection clusters arise, we undertake swift action to quarantine and test close contacts, mount swab operations, and suspend operations at the relevant facility if deemed necessary. Over the past months, we have conducted 7 such swab operations associated with newly emergent workplace clusters. We also launched swab operations to test individuals at retail premises frequented by multiple positive cases.

We have also been stepping up our general surveillance efforts, and have been using a combination of different testing methods to pick up any early signals of emerging clusters. The National Environment Agency is also planning to progressively expand waste-water testing to include more workers’ dormitories and other populous living quarters such as nursing homes and hostels.

Under Phase Two, we have observed crowding and poor adherence to safe distancing measures at some hotspots, such as popular night spots, beaches, selected malls and parks, as well as in HDB towns. Agencies will put in place enhanced crowd control measures, as well as step up enforcement, at these hotspots.

The Inter-agency Taskforce is close to completing the dormitory clearance. We expect all the dormitories to be cleared by the beginning of August 2020, with the exception of 17 standalone blocks in 8 Purpose Built Dormitories, which serve as quarantine facilities. This means that all the migrant workers in the dormitories would be cleared by then, except for 28,000 workers still serving out their isolation period in the various quarantine facilities.

It is critical that we continue to stay disciplined and vigilant. We need everyone to observe safe distancing as we carry on with our daily activities, and seek medical attention early if unwell. Let us play our part to keep our loved ones and our community safe!

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/enhancing-surveillance-and-enforcement-efforts-to-keep-covid-19-at-bay

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global and local COVID-19 situation. Several countries are experiencing a resurgence of cases after a general resumption of activities, and we have to keep our guard up to avoid a resurgence of cases.

We will adjust our border controls, in line with the COVID-19 situation abroad and the assessed risk of importation from arriving travelers. Travellers entering Singapore after 19 July 2020, 2359hrs, who have recent travel history, including transit, to Victoria (Australia); Japan; and Hong Kong within the last 14 days will be required to serve their Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated SHN facilities instead of their own place of residence.

We continue to take aggressive actions to detect and ring-fence local transmissions. We have significantly scaled up testing of those with acute respiratory infection (ARI) symptoms at first presentation, and are now testing around 2,400 ARI cases a day on average.

The Inter-agency Taskforce (ITF) is continuing efforts to systematically test and clear workers and dormitories. As of 16 July 2020, around 232,000 workers have either recovered, or have been tested to be free from the virus. The ITF expects to complete the testing of all workers by mid-August.

As we resume more activities under Phase Two, we must double down on our efforts to control the spread of the virus. Everyone’s continued vigilance and adherence to safe management measures remains important to reduce the spread of infection and protect our loved ones.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/keeping-our-guard-up-to-avoid-resurgence-of-cases

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As we resume more activities in Phase Two, we will continue to step up testing capacities and contract tracing capabilities as key enablers to support the safe re-opening of our economy and society.

We will continue to expand our community testing efforts to include all individuals, aged 13 years and above, diagnosed with acute respiratory infection (ARI) at first presentation to a doctor, starting from 1 July 2020.

In recognition of the role that Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs) play in supporting the nation’s efforts in combatting the COVID-19 pandemic, we will provide a one-off COVID-19 grant totalling $10,000 to each PHPC.For the 400 PHPCs who are on the Swab and Send Home (SASH) programme, we will also provide a one-time start-up grant of $1,200.

The Inter-agency Taskforce (ITF) is continuing its efforts to systematically test and clear workers and dormitories. To date, about 120,000 workers have either recovered or have been tested to be free from the virus. Amongst them 80,000 are able to resume work while the rest are pending movement to appropriate accommodations before they start work.

The risk of infection and spread remains and the implementation of strong safe management measures, safe distancing measures and infection control measures by everyone remains key.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/steady-progress-in-dormitory-clearance-aggressive-testing-and-tracing-in-phase-2

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As we move into Phase 2 after 18 June 2020, 2359 hours, we will need to continue to step up our precautionary measures to enable a safe resumption of activities. Our expanded COVID-19 testing regime, and the use of technology to facilitate efficient contact tracing, are part of these efforts and key enablers to support a safe re-opening of our economy and society.

We have plans to increase our testing capacity to 40,000 tests per day, and we have applied this increased testing capacity in several ways:
1) We have stepped up the testing of close contacts, by testing all close contacts of confirmed cases before the start of quarantine.
2) From later next week, we will extend testing to all individuals aged 45 and above who are diagnosed with acute respiratory infection (ARI) at first presentation to a doctor. This will progressively be extended to more groups subsequently.
3) We will continue to do more active surveillance testing in the community.
4) We will be setting up more Regional Screening Centres to support the needs of our population and bring testing services closer to our people.

As we re-open and resume more activities in Phase 2, raising the adoption level of TraceTogether is critical. We encourage everyone to download and use the app.

To ensure everyone benefits from the TraceTogether Programme, we will be providing TraceTogether Tokens to those who do not have smartphones or the requisite smartphones for the app to work properly. The TraceTogether Tokens will be rolled out from end June onwards, starting with the elderly and then progressively to the rest of the population. Details will be provided at a later date.

All individuals must play their part, and continue to practise strict safe distancing and good personal hygiene, to reduce the risk of transmissions. With our collective efforts, we can look forward to a safe re-opening and resumption of activities.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/enablers-to-support-safe-re-opening

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Seniors are especially vulnerable and should be extra careful as more senior-centric activities resume in Phase Two from 19 June 2020. We encourage seniors to continue to stay home as much as possible and to limit their interactions to a small regular circle of close contacts.

In Phase Two, senior-centric activities organised by the People’s Association, Health Promotion Board, Sport Singapore, and the Council for Third Age (C3A) may resume but will be limited only to activities that can be done individually, and with safe distancing measures in place.

Day care services at most Senior Care Centres and Active Ageing Hubs will resume on 29 June, to support seniors and their caregivers who have to return to work in Phase Two. Providers will continue to enforce safe distancing, limit group interactions, and ensure good infection control practices such as hand hygiene and wearing of masks.

Face-to-face visitations at residential care homes may resume starting from 19 June, with the implementation of additional precautionary measures. To minimise the risk of infection within the nursing homes, each resident will be allowed a total of two designated visitors, and only one may visit each day, with each visit limited to 30 minutes. The total number of visitors allowed each day in a home will also be capped through appointments.

We will continue to monitor the situation closely, with the aim of continuing to ease measures until we reach a new normal in Phase Three.

Read more about support for seniors in Phase Two here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/support-for-seniors-in-phase-two

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has assessed the situation and decided to start Phase Two after 18 June 2020, 2359 hours.

In this next phase, our goal is to ensure that efforts taken during the circuit breaker period and Phase One of reopening are sustained. By limiting close contact among individuals, while maintaining hygiene and safe management principles, we will be able to resume more activities without substantially raising the risk of new clusters of infections.

Apart from a small list of exceptions, Phase Two will see the resumption of most activities, with the following safe distancing principles in place:
a. As a default, individuals are to maintain safe distancing of at least one metre at all times.
b. Where not feasible or practical to apply one metre safe distancing between individuals, this one metre requirement can instead be enforced between groups, with each group made up of not more than five persons, and with no mixing between groups. Other safe management measures should also be in place.

Similarly, small-group social gatherings of up to any 5 persons can also resume. Within the home, households may receive up to 5 visitors at any one time.

Read more about the activities to be resumed in our press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moving-into-phase-two-of-re-opening

With the range of activities resuming in Phase Two, the number of close contacts between individuals will increase. More new community cases should be expected. To keep the number of new cases under control, it is critical that we continue to exercise caution. We must adhere to safe management principles, and practise social responsibility in upholding good personal hygiene and safe distancing measures.Let us continue to stay disciplined and vigilant, and not let all our previous efforts go to waste.

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

COVID-19 testing is a key enabler of the Government’s overall efforts to safely re-open after the circuit breaker.

Besides diagnostic testing, we have started to conduct active surveillance testing on targeted groups, to help detect cases early and reduce the risk of large COVID-19 clusters from developing.

With the gradual re-opening of more workplaces, we have started testing workers who are returning to work in the construction, marine and process sectors. We have also extended testing to individuals who are diagnosed with acute respiratory infection (ARI) at first presentation to a doctor, starting first with groups such as seniors 65 years old and above, healthcare workers, as well as staff and students aged 13 and above from our education institutions.

The Health Promotion Board, Singapore has been setting up regional screening centres across the island to support the national testing efforts. These centres are integral to the implementation of our national testing strategy, and play a critical role in keeping Singapore COVID-19 safe.

While testing helps us to detect, isolate and contain possible spread, strong infection control measures will continue to be the mainstay of disease prevention in our community. Let’s continue to practise strict safe distancing and good personal hygiene, to reduce the risk of transmissions.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/regional-screening-centres-set-up-to-facilitate-testing

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As Singapore exits the Circuit Breaker and transitions to a “new normal”, our utmost priority is to keep everyone safe and healthy as we resume activities safely in Phase 1.

Find out how we can all work together to adopt good practices within our community, on public transport, at the workplace and even at home.

Let us stand united in this battle against COVID-19 as Singapore moves ‘Together, Towards A New Normal’.

As Singapore exits the Circuit Breaker and transit to a phased approach to resume activities safely, Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong has penned a letter to express his heartfelt gratitude to our healthcare workers for their unwavering commitment, dedication and resilience in Singapore’s fight against COVID-19.

While the journey is long, and we are far from the end of the pandemic, let us come together and stand behind our healthcare workers who have worked tirelessly to keep us and our loved ones safe. #SGUnited

To our healthcare workers, we salute and thank you for your sacrifice and contribution.

Read on for Minister’s full letter to the healthcare family.

As more activities and services resume after the circuit breaker lifts from 2 June 2020, the use of masks will continue to be mandatory when people go outside their homes. The use of masks that closely and completely cover the nose and mouth will be required as a default. With effect from 2 June, face shields will be treated differently from masks, and will be allowed only for specific exempt groups or settings.

In some situations, the wearing of masks may not be practical. In such situations, face shields may be worn. The face shields must be worn properly so that it covers the entire face, from the forehead to below the chin, wrapping around the sides of the face. The groups which can wear face shields are as follows:
• Children 12 years and below, who may have difficulty wearing and keeping face masks on for a prolonged period of time;
• Persons who have health conditions that may result in breathing or other medical difficulties when a mask is worn for a prolonged period of time; and
• Persons who are speaking to a group in a classroom or lecture-style setting, where they largely remain at the spot from which they are speaking, and are able to maintain a safe distance away from any other persons.

As more activities and services gradually resume, we urge everyone to play their part by wearing masks, observing good personal hygiene, and adhering to safe distancing and safe management measures.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/guidance-for-use-of-masks-and-face-shields

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Singapore will be exiting the Circuit Breaker and embarking on Phase One of re-opening on 2 June 2020. We expect more than three quarters of the economy to resume operations by then. The Multi-Ministry Taskforce will carefully monitor the effects of increased activity in this phase. If the community infection rates remain low and stable over the subsequent two weeks, we can decide by the middle of June to proceed with Phase Two, which could then happen before the end of June.

Phase Two will entail the resumption of a broader range of activities. We expect almost the entire economy to re-open, subject to safe management measures being in place. Small-group social gatherings of up to 5 persons will be allowed. Within the home, households may receive up to 5 visitors per day. Under Phase Two, masks will remain compulsory whenever outside one’s home.

As restrictions are eased, it becomes even more critical that each of us exercises social responsibility to ensure that community transmission remains low as we resume more activities. We need everyone to play their part, observe good personal hygiene, adhere to safe management measures, and avoid crowded places. We can look forward to moving to Phase Two and beyond if each of us plays our part. Together, we can and we must achieve a COVID-safe Singapore.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/roadmap-ahead-to-phase-two

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Over the next few weeks, more healthcare services will resume in a gradual and controlled manner to minimise crowding. This carefully considers the need to set aside sufficient capacity, critical resources and manpower in our healthcare institutions to cover ongoing COVID-19 operations. Appropriate safe distancing and precautionary measures remain necessary.

Healthcare providers will triage and prioritise the resumption of healthcare services based on medical necessity, where patients with more urgent medical needs will be attended to first. Services for patients who are well, or whose conditions are stable and whose treatment can continue to be safely deferred will resume in a later phase. Similarly, services which alter the appearance but do not cure or ameliorate disease or illness (e.g. Botox, fillers, threadlifts) will continue to be deferred.

Even as some healthcare services resume, physical visits should be minimised whenever possible, so patients should continue to use teleconsultation and medication delivery.

Visitors from the same or one other household will also be allowed to visit loved ones who have been hospitalised. However, to protect our patients who are still vulnerable, we will allow a maximum of five such visitors to pre-register with the hospital, and only one person will be allowed to visit at a time.

Even as we resume more healthcare services, managing the current outbreak situation and preventing new large clusters from forming remain our priority.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/end-of-circuit-breaker-phased-approach-to-resuming-healthcare-services

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Seniors are especially vulnerable and should continue to take extra precautions after the Circuit Breaker. In Phase 1, with more activities and interactions, there will likely be a higher risk of community transmission. Therefore we will continue with most Circuit Breaker measures for seniors in Phase 1, to ensure that they stay safe.

As family support for seniors remains important, we will allow family members to visit their parents or grandparents staying elsewhere in Phase 1. This will be capped at two visitors from the same visiting household per day to minimise risk of exposure. Essential services such as residential care services, home care, and meals support will also continue. To protect our seniors, face-to-face visits in residential care homes and senior-centric activities will continue to be suspended. We will also continue to complement our precautionary measures with surveillance testing.

While all activities that involve physical interactions amongst seniors remain suspended, we will gradually resume some activities for clients of SACs and CREST providers to address their psychosocial wellbeing. In order to keep interactions low, these will be limited to activities that can be done individually, and with restrictions on the activity duration and total number of persons per session.

Depending on the COVID-19 situation and our risk assessment, we will continue to ease measures gradually and eventually reach a new normal in Phase 3. In order to resume these activities that we enjoy, we must continue to be vigilant. Stay home, avoid crowds, and stay in contact with your friends and family remotely as far as possible.

Read more on the post Circuit Breaker measures for seniors:

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/post-circuit-breaker-measures-for-seniors

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce announced earlier that parents should not send their children to the care of their grandparents on a daily basis during this circuit breaker period. However while most parents would be working from home, there would be some households where parents who are in essential services, have to continue going to work during this period.

The Taskforce will be implementing exemptions for the following families, where they may continue to tap on the grandparents for childcare support on a daily basis:
a. Both parents are essential service workers and unable to work from home;
b. One parent is a healthcare professional (e.g. doctor, nurse, allied health professional, support care staff) and is unable to work from home; and
c. One parent is an essential service worker who is unable to work from home, and have a child/children below the age of three.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/changes-to-childcare-arrangements-during-circuit-breaker

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Fee Benchmarks Advisory Committee has recommended fee benchmarks for anaesthetists’ fees and doctors’ inpatient attendance fees for the private sector. These include recommended fee ranges for anaesthetists for about 190 procedures, as well as doctors’ inpatient attendance fees for consultations and reviews of patients in different ward settings.

The Ministry of Health (MOH) has accepted these recommended fee benchmarks in full and published them on MOH’s website at www.moh.gov.sg/billsandfees.

This is the second tranche of fee benchmarks, following the surgeon fee benchmarks for common surgical procedures published by MOH in 2018. The two tranches of fee benchmarks when used together, will give patients and payers (e.g. self-paying patients and insurers) more complete information on total doctors’ fees for surgeries and hospital stays and enable better informed decisions. They will also serve as a guide for private sector healthcare providers in charging appropriately.

Read more in the press release:

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moh-publishes-fee-benchmarks-for-private-anaesthetists'-and-inpatient-attendance-doctors'-fees

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Seniors can soon experience the benefits of a new public housing concept customised to support their needs as they age. Jointly developed by the Ministry of National Development, Ministry of Health and Housing & Development Board, the new Community Care Apartments, located at Bukit Batok West Avenue 9, will be launched for sale in the February 2021. The new housing-cum-care model, where additional health and social support services can be layered on as needed, will give seniors and their caregivers peace of mind as they age.

With the new apartments, our seniors can look forward to living independently even as their care needs change, and enjoy more opportunities to stay active and take charge of their health through specially curated programmes and services. Seniors and caregivers will also be better able to navigate the range of social and health support services with the help of an on-site community manager.

If you are interested in applying for a Community Care Apartment, do visit the HDB Hub from 14 December 2020 to 31 March 2021 to view the exhibition which will feature 3D models of the apartments and a mock-up of the communal space. Visitors can also get more details on the service packages, eligibility conditions and flat prices at the exhibition. The safety of visitors to the exhibition is a priority, and prevailing safe management measures will apply. Visitors need to book an appointment via HDB InfoWEB before visiting the exhibition. Appointments can be booked from 11 December 2020. https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/singapore-s-first-assisted-living-flats-to-be-launched-in-in-february-2021

CareShield Life, our national long-term care insurance scheme, launched on 1 Oct for Singapore residents aged 30 to 40 this year. It provides monthly cash payouts for as long as one is severely disabled. These payouts will increase annually until age 67 or when a successful claim is made, whichever is earlier.

Read on to find out more about CareShield Life and how it helps with your long-term care costs.

https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/compulsory-careshield-life-for-all-born-1980-or-later-starts-oct-1

For more information on CareShield Life, visit https://www.careshieldlife.gov.sg.

STRAITSTIMES.COM
Compulsory CareShield Life for all born in 1980 or later starts on Oct 1

As part of an ongoing review of MediShield Life benefits and premiums, the MediShield Life Council is conducting a public consultation to seek views from the public on its preliminary recommendations for enhancements to the scheme.

Guided by the considerations of providing better protection to Singaporeans while keeping premiums affordable, the MediShield Life Council has identified preliminary enhancements to refresh and refine claim limits to provide better coverage, and support larger healthcare transformation.

Premiums need to be adjusted periodically to support enhancements that provide better coverage and higher payouts, and to keep pace with healthcare cost inflation and actual claims experience. The MediShield Life Council recommends adjusting the premiums this round to ensure that the scheme continues to be sustainable.

While the public consultation on the proposed benefit enhancements is ongoing, the Government has committed about $2.2 billion for premium subsidies and support over the next three years to help Singapore Residents with their MediShield Life premiums, particularly in view of the impact of COVID-19 on Singapore Residents and the economy. With these support measures, the net premium increases for all Singapore Citizens will be kept to up to about 10% in the first year.

The public consultation will be held from 6pm, 29 September to 6pm, 20 October 2020. To contribute your views and feedback on the preliminary recommendations, go to the online feedback form at http://www.moh.gov.sg/e-consultation/mshl2020, or mail it to the following address: Quality Service, Ministry of Health, 16 College Road, College of Medicine Building, Singapore 169854. Your feedback will be carefully considered by the Council before the final recommendations are made by end 2020.

Read on for more information on the launch of the public consultation:
https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/public-consultation-on-medishield-life-review
https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/government-to-provide-about-2-2-billion-to-help-singaporeans-with-medishield-life-premium-adjustments

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As the number of community cases has remained low, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will ease measures to facilitate business operations, by supporting essential business travel, and enabling more employees to return to the workplace.

(1) We are piloting a new business travel pass for senior executives in Singapore with regional or international responsibilities who need to travel regularly for official and business purposes. Travellers on this pass will be required to abide by a strict controlled itinerary when they travel overseas for work. To ensure that we can carefully monitor the public health outcomes of this pilot, the number of passes will be strictly limited in the initial phase.

(2) Working from home remains the default mode of working. We will allow more employees to return to the workplaces. But employers must ensure that such employees continue to work from home for at least half their working time, and no more than half of such employees are at the workplace at any point in time. Employers should play their part in minimising crowding and possible congregation at common spaces, including on public transport. In addition, split team or shift arrangements must continue to be implemented, with each team restricted to one worksite where possible.

(3) Work-related events within the workplace premises that are business-oriented will be allowed to resume, for up to 50 persons with strict adherence to safe management measures requirements. As per existing guidelines, employers must not organise or encourage larger scale social gatherings within or outside the workplaces.

As we resume more economic and social activities, with more employees returning to the workplace and more persons engaging in business travel, the risk of community transmission increases. We strongly urge everyone to do their part by observing safe distancing and practising good personal hygiene to reduce the risk of transmission. Together, we can continue in our fight against COVID-19, to protect ourselves, our loved ones, and our community.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/resuming-more-activities-safely

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce will continue to allow a calibrated resumption of economic and social activities, while putting in place measures where needed to ensure that activities can continue to be conducted safely.

From 1 September 2020, we will expand the list of public facilities where organised exercise classes conducted by instructors can be held, to include more open spaces at SportSG sport centres, parks, and HDB common areas. Safe management measures have to be put in place and adhered to. These include temperature and symptoms screening, safe distancing, and maintaining a list of participants in venues where SafeEntry is not deployed. The instructor must be registered to conduct these activities.

To reduce the risk of overcrowding in lifts and lift lobbies, we will put in place stringent safe management measures in lifts while exempting them from the 1-metre safe distancing requirement. These safe management measures include wearing of masks, refraining from speaking, and using hand sanitisers provided in lifts.

From 29 August 2020, Lucky Plaza and Peninsula Plaza will implement odd and even date entry restrictions on weekends, based on the last digit of an individual’s National Registration Identification Card (NRIC) or Foreign Identification Number (FIN), to better manage crowds and ensure that safe distancing can be observed both inside and outside the buildings.

Some F&B outlets have been observed to be playing extremely loud music, causing patrons to have to talk more loudly to be heard which increases the risk of droplet spread. As an added precaution, we will tighten the rules to allow recorded music at F&B outlets to be played as soft background music only.

We urge everyone to do their part to ensure that our businesses and public spaces can continue to be safe spaces for all, by observing safe distancing and avoiding peak periods and crowded places. All who are unwell should see a doctor immediately and stay home to prevent spreading illness to others. Let’s work together to protect ourselves, our loved ones and our community.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-and-community-measures

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

[Just in] SMS Edwin Tong announced in Parliament that MediSave will be enhanced to better support patients with complex chronic conditions. From 1 Jan 2021, patients with complex chronic conditions are eligible for a higher MediSave withdrawal limit of $700, under the MediSave 700 scheme.

Patients can continue to tap on their own and their family members' MediSave accounts, up to the patient's own annual withdrawal limit for the treatment.

To enable patients to make more informed decisions, we had published private sector professional fees for common surgical procedures in 2018. MOH will continue to monitor charges and review the benchmarks with the Fee Benchmarks Advisory Committee (FBAC) to ensure they remain relevant and effective.

In addition, FBAC is studying fee benchmarks for less common surgical procedures, doctors’ inpatient consultation fees and anaesthetists’ fees.

[Just in] SMS Amy Khor shared that in the next three years, we will progressively level up eldercare centres to provide a common suite of baseline support services for seniors nationwide.

Services include active ageing programmes for the well, befriending services for the lonely, and information and referral for care services for frail seniors. These services will be available to all seniors in each neighbourhood.

In addition, half of the eldercare centres will eventually provide higher level care services, such as day care and community rehabilitation services, to cater to those who are more frail.

We are re-activating the Public Health Preparedness Clinics to focus our primary care efforts to better detect and manage COVID-19 infections. We have also observed that many of the local confirmed cases had continued to circulate in the community or gone to work when they were already ill. This is why we had earlier given guidance to doctors to provide medical certificates (MC) of five days for patients with respiratory symptoms so they could stay home to recover.

Based on the COVID-19 cases in Singapore so far, the National Centre for Infectious Diseases has observed that a significant number of them have mild symptoms in the initial phase of infection. Similar to influenza, these patients typically experience mild flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough. And similar to influenza, they can be infectious during this initial period of mild symptoms. The risk of their infecting others can be reduced with appropriate measures.

In fact, most patients with respiratory symptoms are not infected with COVID-19. But we must take extra precautions. It is therefore important that anyone with respiratory symptoms (such as fever, cough, sore throat and runny nose) seek medical treatment early, and stay home throughout their illness. We urge all individuals and employers to cooperate, and follow strictly the five-day MC regime that has been put in place. In addition, we will be taking further pre-emptive measures to reduce the risk of community transmission.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/additional-pre-emptive-measures-to-reduce-risk-of-community-transmission

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has observed cases of COVID-19 infections among the cleared dormitories. Dormitory residents who have never been infected remain susceptible to COVID-19. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has put in place a multi-layered strategy to detect any new COVID-19 cases in the dormitories and to contain infections quickly and decisively:

-To prevent the spread and formation of large clusters, MOM has put in place “Safe Living, Safe Working and Safe Rest Day” measures in the dormitories.

-To swiftly detect new cases of infection, MOM has deployed a number of strategies including (i) self-monitoring by migrant workers and regular updating of their health status; (ii) close monitoring of workers who report sick at medical posts with acute respiratory illnesses; (iii) conducting wastewater testing at selected dormitories for traces of the virus as a means of early sentinel surveillance; and (iv) conducting Rostered Routine Testing for dormitory residents every 14 days.

-If a new case is detected, MOM will quickly ring-fence and test close contacts to contain its spread.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/strengthening-measures-for-safe-re-opening-of-activities

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The various initiatives implemented by the Multi-Ministry Taskforce have substantially reduced the number of COVID-19 infections in the community, and stabilised the infections at the foreign worker dormitories.

The Taskforce has embarked on a systemic plan to test all migrant workers in the dormitories, to ensure that migrant workers are well and can safely resume work when their sectors gradually re-open after the end of the circuit breaker period. The plan employs a mix of COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests and serological tests, and we will do this systematically across all the dormitories to ensure the health and wellbeing of every worker.

We are seeing lower numbers of new community cases daily, and we are making progress in our efforts to test the workers and clear the dormitories. We are also ramping up our testing capacity, and strengthening our contact tracing abilities. With these plans and enablers, we will be ready to gradually ease the circuit breaker restrictions and resume normal activities safely.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/controlling-the-outbreak-preparing-for-the-next-phase

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Singapore Ministry of Manpower(MOM) had issued advisories on enhanced precautionary measures in dormitories to minimise the risk of COVID-19 transmission. However transmissions within foreign worker dormitories have continued to rise and we are seeing more confirmed cases and workers who are ill. The S11 Dormitory @ Punggol (2 Seletar North Link) and Westlite Toh Guan dormitory (18 Toh Guan Road East) are of particular concern.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has decided that further measures are necessary to contain the risk of further transmission among the foreign workers within these two dormitories. This would keep the workers safe, as well as protect the wider community from widespread transmission from these clusters.

The S11 Dormitory @ Punggol and Westlite Toh Guan dormitory have been gazetted as isolation areas. Onsite medical support has been deployed, along with provision of food and essential supplies. Workers who are symptomatic have already been isolated. Within these two dormitories, precautionary steps have also been taken to protect workers who are well.

MOM is working closely with all dormitory operators, to implement similar measures within their premises with immediate effect.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/additional-measures-to-minimise-further-spread-of-covid-19-within-foreign-worker-dormitories

In the next few days, seniors above 70 years old will progressively receive notification to book appointments for their Covid-19 vaccination. Since late January, selected Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs) across the island have been providing COVID-19 vaccination to healthcare workers.

The PHPCs have been playing an integral role in the fight against COVID-19 pandemic, from providing subsidised consultation and treatment for acute respiratory infections to conducting COVID-19 swab tests to help us quickly detect cases.

As we ramp up our vaccination efforts, some of these will now play a new role as vaccination sites. These selected PHPCs, along with our 20 polyclinics and vaccination centres, ensure that everyone has convenient and easy access to COVID-19 vaccination.

Vaccination is crucial in protecting ourselves and our loved ones against COVID-19, as well as others who cannot be vaccinated due to medical reasons. When your turn comes, I strongly encourage you to get vaccinated if you are medically eligible! This collective protection will become more effective as more of us are vaccinated and will enable us to return to normalcy. Remember, no one is safe, unless everyone is safe!

HEALTHHUB.SG
Spring to Health This Chinese New Year

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
11 February at 08:00 ·

Happy New Year in the Year of the Ox! 牛年大吉！Here’s wishing all Singaporeans good health and happiness over the festive season.

It wouldn’t be Chinese New Year without our favourite treats and snacks. With some simple modifications, you can still enjoy them while keeping your health in check. When shopping for treats, choose those with the Healthier Choice Symbol as these have less sugar, salt or fat. Or prepare a healthier Yu Sheng (raw fish salad) with less oil, sauce and flour crisps. (Remember to wear a face mask while tossing Yu Sheng! And recite the usual auspicious phrases during Lohei in your heart but not aloud). You can also use healthier and/or fresh ingredients for your reunion dinner like wholegrains, lean meat, fish and vegetables.

This HealthHub article has more great ideas on how you can keep to a balanced diet even during the celebrations: https://www.healthhub.sg/live-healthy/194/spring_to_health_CNY

Do also stay safe during this festive period by keeping to the CNY safe management measures. Connecting digitally with your family and friends is encouraged, but if you’re going on physical visits, there is a cap of 8 visitors per household per day. Keep your house visits to family members and to not more than 2 other households a day.

You’re already familiar with these measures too: when dining out, wear a mask when not eating or drinking, and keep your voices down. Don’t make multiple table bookings (applicable to reunion dinners too), except for those from the same household, and even then, there shouldn’t be inter-mingling across tables.

By keeping to these measures, we can still enjoy our CNY celebrations while doing our part to keep the virus at bay!

新年快乐！牛年大吉！祝福所有国人身体健康，大家佳节期间都过得开开心心！

这几天如果没有吃到我们最喜爱的美食和零食, 就感觉不像在过年。其实你只须要做一些简单的调整，就可以健康地享用这些新年美食。在选购这类新年美食的时候，请记得找那些贴有“较健康选择”标签的食品，因为这些食品有比较少的糖、盐或者脂肪。如果要捞鱼生，也可以选择较健康的版本，少油、少酱料、少炸脆饼。大家也要记得捞起时还是要戴着口罩，在心中默念贺词，而不要大声说出来。大家吃团圆饭时也可以选择较健康或新鲜的食材，例如全谷类、瘦肉、鱼肉和蔬菜等。

你可以阅读这篇文章，了解如何在喜迎佳节时，做到饮食均衡。https://www.healthhub.sg/live-healthy/194/spring_to_health_CNY

假节期间，大家也要保障彼此的安全，遵守相关的安全管制措施。我们希望鼓励大家通过上网或虚拟的方式与亲友保持联系。如果你选择出外拜年，每户家庭每天只能接待最多八名访客。请尽可能只去和自己的家人亲戚拜年，一天内也不要去超过两户家庭拜年。

大家对其他的措施应该已经非常熟悉了，包括出外用餐时，如果不是在吃东西或喝饮料就应该继续戴着口罩，也要控制自己的声量。如果你不是同住的家人，就不能预定超过一张餐桌的位子，包括吃团圆饭也不行。就算是同住的家人，也不应该在不同餐桌之间来回。

大家配合遵守这些措施，我们欢庆佳节的同时，也能尽一份力去抑制病毒的传播。

MOH | News Highlights

1,033 general practitioner (GP) clinics, of which 758 are Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs), will be open at various times during the Chinese New Year public holidays from 11 to 14 February 2021.

If you feel unwell during the festivities, we encourage you to visit your GP or a 24-hour clinic for minor, self-limiting conditions. Seek medical treatment at a hospital’s Accident & Emergency (A&E) department only for serious or life-threatening emergencies, such as chest pain, breathlessness, and uncontrollable bleeding.

If you have symptoms of an acute respiratory infection (such as cough, sore throat and runny nose) as well as fever and loss of taste or smell, you are strongly encouraged to visit a PHPC and get swabbed early when advised by your doctor. It is important to test for COVID-19 early for early detection, management and containment to prevent further spread of the disease, to help protect your loved ones and vulnerable members of the community.

Check out the list of clinics open here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/over-1-000-general-practitioner-clinics-open-during-chinese-new-year-holidays

Wishing you and your family good health and happiness this Chinese New Year!

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation and will tighten border measures for travellers from Vietnam, given the increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vietnam. At the same time, with the improvement in the COVID-19 situation in New South Wales (NSW), Australia, we will adjust our border measures for travellers from NSW, Australia. In addition, to minimise the risk of potential incubating cases leaking into the community for travellers, we will tighten border measures for the Business Travel Pass (BTP) scheme.

From 12 February 2021, 2359 hours, Singapore Citizens (SCs), Permanent Residents (PRs) and Long-Term Pass holders entering Singapore with travel history to Vietnam within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will be subject to an on-arrival COVID-19 PCR test, 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities, and a PCR test before the end of the SHN period. Short-term travellers holding an Air Travel Pass (ATP) with travel history to Vietnam within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will not be allowed to enter Singapore. All travellers who are not SCs or PRs will need to take a COVID-19 PCR test within 72 hours before departure. These travellers will still be required to undergo an On-Arrival Test (OAT) and serve their SHN upon arrival and be tested at the end of SHN.

From 10 February 2021, 2359 hours, SCs, PRs and Long-Term Pass holders returning from NSW, Australia will undergo a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival at the airport in lieu of a 7-day SHN, and if the result is negative, they will be allowed to go about their activities in Singapore. Short-term visitors travelling from NSW, Australia can also apply for an ATP for entry into Singapore on or after 16 February 2021.

Travellers on the BTP scheme are now required to undergo COVID-19 PCR Tests on Day 3, Day 7 and Day 14 of their return. An additional serology test will also be required on Day 3.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-for-travellers-from-vietnam-new-south-wales-(australia)-and-business-travel-pass-scheme

I visited the COVID-19 vaccination centre at the former Hong Kah Secondary School yesterday and saw that the operations are proceeding well. A team of doctors, nurses and healthcare assistants from Parkway Shenton, which runs the vaccination centre, have been working closely to ensure a smooth process. Beyond the day-to-day operation, the team is also constantly looking at how to improve the experience for those coming in for their vaccinations, from planning for contingencies to minimising wait times and exploring how to ensure the centre is accessible for the elderly.

Our vaccination centres, alongside our polyclinics and selected Public Health Preparedness Clinics, will allow us to scale up our vaccination efforts as we progressively vaccinate our entire population. Each vaccination centre is able to perform 2,000 vaccinations per day on average. We will be setting up around 40 vaccination centres to ensure that everyone can be conveniently vaccinated. They will be located in high population catchment areas as well as along public transport routes for greater accessibility.

Getting vaccinated is critical to protect us and our loved ones against COVID-19. When your turn comes, we encourage you to get vaccinated, so that as a society, we can keep each other safe from COVID-19.

HEALTHHUB.SG
Screen for Life

Janil Puthucheary
4 February at 11:00 ·

Today is World Cancer Day. This year’s theme is #IAmAndIWill, which recognises that our commitment to act is key to progress in reducing the impact of cancer.

The Global Burden of Disease 2019 study found that cancer was the leading cause of mortality and ill health in Singapore. As cancer risk increases with age, the number of people with cancer would rise as our population ages.

An important part of fighting cancer is early detection and treatment, through regular screening. Our national screening programme Screen for Life provides subsidies for cervical, colorectal and breast cancer screenings for eligible individuals, to make screening affordable and accessible. The best time to go for screening is when you still feel fine, so do check out https://www.healthhub.sg/programmes/61/Screen_for_Life for more information.

Moving upstream, continued innovation and research are crucial in the fight against cancer. Cancer remains one of the priority disease areas of our Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2025 (RIE2025) plans, and the National Medical Research Council provides funding for programmes to advance our knowledge of various cancers and discover better ways to treat patients.

We will continue to support these programmes, to create better health outcomes for Singaporeans in the long run.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
3 February at 11:54 ·

With a Degree in Mathematics and Engineering and a Master of Science in Smart Product Design, Mr Jason Lim made an atypical career choice when he became an Occupational Therapist.

Jason spent most of his career outside of healthcare. He started out as an aircraft technician, before working as an engineer. Later on, as a researcher, he had many conversations with patients on how they were coping with their illnesses, and he was deeply inspired by their determination and strength. At the same time, he also volunteered to tutor children with cancer.

These experiences nudged him towards a career in healthcare. He found out about the healthcare Professional Conversion Programmes, and with encouragement from his wife, applied for the Professional Conversion Programme for Occupational Therapists (PCP-OT). He graduated in 2018, and began his journey as an Occupational Therapist at Ren Ci Hospital where he works now.

Jason said his switch was not without its challenges, but his passion for his work never wavered. “When work gets tough, I do ask myself why I made the switch. However at the end of the day, I still enjoy providing the therapy sessions, interacting with the patients and seeing them achieve their goals,” Jason shared.

If you are keen to make a mid-career switch into healthcare like Jason, consider applying for the Professional Conversion Programme for Allied Health Professionals (PCP-AHPs). Applications are open until 19 March, and these programmes provide training for mid-career PMETs to become a Physiotherapist, Occupational Therapist (OT) or a Diagnostic Radiographer. In addition to the current Accelerated PCP for Physiotherapy, we will be introducing a new Accelerated PCP-OT degree programme from this year, where eligible candidates will be able to complete their degree in three years instead of four.

You can find out more about the PCP here: https://go.gov.sg/pcp-ahp.

Janil Puthucheary
26 January at 00:43 ·

I was happy to be part of a panel discussion at the Singapore Perspectives 2021 Conference where the central topic of discussion was on the vision of politics we have for Singapore in 2030.

The politics of our country is determined by our people and the values we hold. In the years ahead, the partnership between citizens and the Government will play an even larger role to achieve our shared ideals and aspirations. We will need to continue having open discussions on various issues to recognise the diversity of opinions and be productive in seeking common ground and solutions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a test of our values. We came together as a country to fight the pandemic on various fronts - our healthcare and social workers have been stepping up to help those in need, we recognise the sacrifices of our front-liners as we rightfully should, we are looking into ways to help those whose livelihoods are affected by the pandemic and, at the same time, we are looking at the opportunities brought about by the pandemic. The unity, resolve and adaptability of our people give me hope for Singapore.

Years from now, I hope that we are able to look back at 2021 and recognise that we were in a bright spot in terms of our politics, economy, social issues and the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and be an even brighter spot in 2030.

Masagos Zulkifli
25 January at 14:00 ·

I visited the Community Care Apartments exhibition held at HDB Hub today with Sim Ann 沈颖 and Amy Khor and was happy to meet with some participants of the focus group discussions that were held earlier to gather feedback on this new public housing concept. We had a lively discussion and I was encouraged to learn that our seniors like the concept of communal living, with opportunities for social interaction – essentially fostering a ‘kampung spirit’.

Our seniors have also shared that they prefer to age-in-place independently within communities that they are familiar with – an aspiration that the Community Care Apartments aims to fulfil. To provide frailer seniors who need some support, there will be a Shared Caregiving Service too, a unique feature of the Community Care Apartments that provides round-the-clock assistance for seniors with moderate disability, as well as medical reminders and assistance with simple errands. To ensure such services are affordable and accessible, we will provide eligible seniors with up to 80% means-tested subsidies to offset the monthly service cost.

Glad to know that the exhibition has received healthy interest since its launch and I invite you to drop by to take a look too. The project will be launched in Bukit Batok West Avenue 9 and HDB will be releasing details in the Build-to-Order exercise in Feb 2021. You can click on the link below for more information or book an appointment to visit the exhibition at HDB Hub.

http://go.gov.sg/communitycareapartments

Lee Hsien Loong
23 January at 09:30 ·

The recent community cases remind us that the war against COVID-19 is far from over. With Chinese New Year coming up, we have decided to tighten up to keep everyone safe.

Starting next Tuesday, each household may only receive eight visitors per day. If you are visiting others, please limit yourself to visiting two households a day, and visit family members only. If tossing yusheng, please keep your masks on and don’t shout out the auspicious phrases – say them in your hearts instead.

These stricter measures will surely disappoint all of us looking forward to celebrating CNY. But we must psychologically prepare ourselves to celebrate CNY differently this year. Just look at the countries near and far experiencing repeated surges in cases, and you will see why we need to stay vigilant.

It’s exactly 1 year since our first confirmed COVID-19 case in Singapore. The year has gone by at breakneck pace, as we all struggled to cope with the unprecedented chaos and disruption to our lives. Through immense effort and sacrifice, we’ve got ourselves to a stable situation. Our vaccination programme is underway, with seniors starting to get their shots next week.

Let us continue to protect ourselves and our loved ones by adhering to all the measures. – LHL

Lawrence Wong
22 January at 15:08 ·

<Tightened Safe Management Measures>

It has been nearly a month since we entered Phase 3. We had anticipated then that there could be more cases in the community due to increased activities; and that we would need continued adjustments to our measures.

Indeed in the recent two weeks, new cases and clusters have emerged. They are likely the result of increased activities over the year-end period (typically new cases present themselves with a 1-2 week lag). Our vulnerabilities have gone up, and we cannot afford to take any chances. The situation can escalate rapidly especially with Chinese New Year coming up soon. Remember cases spiked after CNY last year, and we had many clusters then linked to CNY activities and gatherings.

So we are making a pre-emptive move now to tighten our measures. Under the current rule, home visits are allowed for up to 8 visitors at any time. From 26 Jan onwards, we will limit such visits to 8 distinct visitors per household per day. For those who are planning to go out visiting, we strongly advise that you minimise your physical gatherings. In particular over the CNY period, visit your family members only, and do not exceed more than two visits per day.

When dining out, keep your masks on if you are not eating/drinking, and refrain from singing or talking loudly. So during the lohei, masks must remain on, and there should be no shouting of auspicious phrases. For reunion dinners, keep to one table of not more than 8 pax and ensure there are no multiple table bookings, or intermingling across tables.

I know many will be disappointed at these new restrictions especially over the festive season. But I hope everyone understands why they are necessary. The virus is raging everywhere in the world. Many places in Asia that have successfully controlled the infection are now seeing a rise in cases. Places like China, Taiwan and Hong Kong have all imposed curbs on their CNY celebrations.

Likewise, we must be mentally prepared that CNY this year will not be the same as before. It will be quieter and more subdued. We will need to stay disciplined and vigilant. I seek everyone’s cooperation on these new measures. If we all do our part, we can continue to keep the infection under control until we roll out our vaccination programme and get everyone in Singapore vaccinated.

Lawrence Wong
18 January at 22:27 ·

We are seeing more new infected cases in the community in recent days. For the first time in several months we have a local cluster linked to a police para-vet. Unfortunately there were also several recent cases who did not seek medical treatment despite falling ill with flu-like symptoms.

Our contact tracers are working hard to identify all the possible contacts, ring-fence the potential cases and prevent them from spreading further. We are also monitoring the situation carefully and considering if additional measures are necessary to ensure the infection remains under control.

Meanwhile please cooperate with all the safe management measures - wear your masks, see a doctor when sick, and do your part to reduce transmission risks. The virus is still circulating silently within our community and we cannot afford to let our guard down.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce regularly reviews Singapore’s border measures to manage the risk of importation and onward local transmission from travellers. Given the resurgence of COVID-19 cases around the world, we will be putting in place more stringent measures for travellers to manage the risk of importation.

From 24 January 2021, 2359 hours, all travellers, including Singapore Citizens (SC) and Permanent Residents (PR), will need to take a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival in Singapore. The prevailing Stay-Home Notice (SHN) requirements, including the PCR test at the end of the SHN, will continue.

From 18 January 2021, 2359 hours, until further notice, all returning SCs and PRs from the UK and South Africa will be subject to an additional 7-day self-isolation at their place of residence, following their 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities.

From 31 January 2021, 2359 hours, visitors applying to enter Singapore under the Air Travel Pass and Reciprocal Green Lanes will need to have travel insurance for their COVID-19-related medical treatment and hospitalisation costs in Singapore, with a minimum coverage of S$30,000.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-and-travel-insurance

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
15 January at 02:45 ·

The COVID-19 pandemic has irrevocably changed the way we live and work, including the way we do business. But we should continue to find new ways to adapt and thrive in the new normal. I had the opportunity to hear from representatives from various healthcare and biomedical companies in Singapore about the challenges they face and to explore solutions to overcome them together, at the Emerging Stronger Conversation organised by MTI yesterday. This was part of a session hosted by DPM to engage the business community on the broader strategy moving forward.

In our exchanges, we talked about encouraging public-private partnerships to help companies internationalise and develop new care models; and supporting closer collaborations between local healthcare and biomedical companies. We also discussed a range of topics, including digitalising healthcare for future healthcare delivery; attracting global healthcare talent while continuing to cultivate our local core to drive innovation; and how regulators and regulations can catalyse medical technology innovation.

I would like to thank the representatives from the healthcare and biomedical companies for the fruitful discussion. The exchange yesterday has allowed us to better understand the challenges ahead, and identify opportunities and how we can stay nimble and ultimately emerge stronger together.

Janil Puthucheary
13 January at 12:00 ·

Getting vaccinated against COVID-19 not only protects yourself but also your loved ones.

This was the key reason why Ms Mabel Ong, Deputy Director of Nursing Administration at National University Polyclinics, decided to take the vaccination. Ms Ong was vaccinated yesterday by her colleague Senior Staff Nurse Kim Rui Ning, who was vaccinated last week, as part of the progressive rollout of vaccinations in our public health institutions.

In line with the recommendations of the Expert Committee on COVID-19 Vaccination, healthcare workers and COVID-19 frontline workers are prioritised for vaccination as they are at higher risk of being infected by COVID-19 and hence most in need of COVID-19 vaccination.

Vaccination is a key strategy in our fight against COVID-19, along with safe management measures, contact tracing, and testing. While vaccination is voluntary, we need to have as many people vaccinated as possible to prevent the spread of COVID-19, and protect those who cannot be vaccinated due to medical reasons.

We strongly encourage you to get vaccinated when your turn comes, to protect yourself, and your loved ones. Let’s work together for a safer and healthier 2021.
