Masagos Zulkifli
12 January at 06:30 ·

The Ministry of Health, Singapore launched the Action Plan for Successful Ageing in 2015, a national blueprint for population ageing. This year, we’re working to refresh the Action Plan, and we want to hear more from you and to tap on your insight and ideas to co-create initiatives and programmes so that we can continue to make Singapore a great place to age in together.

We kickstarted our first Focus Group Discussion (FGD) session on the Action Plan yesterday – and what a fruitful discussion we had! 💪 Many of you at the session shared your aspirations for a Singapore that cares for our seniors, an empathetic and enabling society that is able to walk in our seniors’ shoes while bringing our resources together to plan for ageing early. Many of you also expressed your desire to help seniors with mental health conditions, such as by ensuring that there is infrastructural support for seniors with dementia and their caregivers.

I’m very encouraged by the ideas shared today, and heartened to hear how some of you have stepped up to support seniors in your own ways. Your ideas, energy and commitment are critical to making Singapore a better place to age in, and the Government will work with you, together, to provide support to our seniors. A whole-of-society effort will help us to build an inclusive society that celebrates and embraces our seniors.

There will be more FGD sessions on the Ageing Plan in the next 2 months, where we will continue to seek views and co-create initiatives and programmes with many other participants. For those who joined the FGD yesterday, I encourage you to step forward and start deeper conversations with one another beyond today’s session. And to everyone else, I want to encourage you to join the conversation in your own way, whether with your family and friends, or in your workplace or neighbourhood.

Look forward to having more of you join this conversation in the coming weeks!

Masagos Zulkifli
11 January at 13:06 ·

The first vaccinations for nursing home staff started today, beginning with Ren Ci @ Bukit Batok St. 52. Other nursing homes and intermediate and long-term care (ILTC) providers will also progressively start vaccinations for their own staff in the coming weeks.

Our colleagues in the nursing homes and ILTC sector have been working hard in the past year to ensure continuity of care for our seniors throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, and I’ve been encouraged by the tremendous efforts and sacrifices made. Many of them are in direct contact with our seniors, who are vulnerable to severe complications should they fall ill with COVID-19. Hence staff across the nursing homes and ILTC sector are prioritised for COVID-19 vaccination, so they can be protected and have an additional line of defence as they continue to serve and care for our senior loved ones.

COVID-19 vaccination is a critical aspect of our fight to tackle COVID-19. While it is voluntary, I strongly encourage everyone who is medically eligible for vaccination to get vaccinated when the vaccine is offered to you, so that we can protect ourselves and our loved ones against COVID-19.

Meanwhile, let’s stay vigilant and disciplined in our fight against COVID-19, by continuing to observe safe distancing and safe management measures and wearing a mask when out of the home. I thank every one of you for doing your part in fighting the pandemic. I am confident Singapore will emerge from this crisis, stronger than ever.

Singapore General Hospital
9 January at 20:16 ·

We are aware that some netizens have asked whether it is necessary for staff performing the vaccinations to wear gloves.

According to WHO guidelines, the vaccinator does not need to wear gloves when giving the injection, unless the skin of the recipient is not intact for example when there is a rash, lesion, or cut. More importantly, the vaccinator cleans his or her hands with hand sanitiser containing 60 to 80% alcohol before and after touching recipient.

Janil Puthucheary
9 January at 16:17 ·

Yesterday, I joined clinicians and experts in maternal and child metabolic health at a conference organised by KK Women's and Children's Hospital to discuss the importance of promoting healthy lifestyle habits in children, mothers and mothers-to-be.

In recent years, more children are becoming overweight, putting them at risk of future health issues, such as diabetes, in adulthood. The probability of childhood obesity also increases when a mother is overweight before pregnancy. Nudging healthy behaviours earlier in the lives of children, their mothers, and mothers-to-be, can lead to more health benefits in the long-term, such as increasing the number of years lived in good health.

Over the past few decades, Singapore has made good progress in maternal and child health. We will continue to step up our preventive health efforts as there is still more to be done.

Lee Hsien Loong added 5 new photos to the album 1st day of COVID-19 vaccination at Public Healthcare Institutions.
8 January at 13:45 ·

Was at Singapore General Hospital this morning to take a look at the start of COVID-19 vaccinations for healthcare workers from public healthcare institutions today. I also got my first dose of the jab!

It was quite painless, with the tiny needle and the steady hands of Senior Staff Nurse Fatimah Mohd Shah. I was observed for 30 minutes after getting the vaccine but I am happy to report that I feel fine and have no side effects.

I am confident that the vaccine is safe and effective. We will have ample vaccines for everyone, so I hope Singaporeans and long-term residents will get vaccinated when your turn comes, and help keep everyone safer. – LHL

Lee Hsien Loong is at Singapore General Hospital.
8 January at 12:40 · Singapore ·

Got my first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine today, together with Director of Medical Services A/Prof Kenneth Mak. We got vaccinated early to show Singaporeans we are confident that the vaccine is safe and effective.

Prof Mak and I were monitored for 30 minutes after the jab, just in case we developed any side effects, e.g. allergic reactions. Happy to report that we both felt fine.

Today we started vaccinating healthcare workers from public healthcare institutions. We aim to start vaccinating elderly people from February, and then other Singaporeans and long-term residents.

Vaccinations are voluntary, but I hope that when it’s your turn, you will go for it. It will be free, it will protect you and your family, and it will help keep everyone safe. – LHL

2 January at 01:56 ·

If you’ve been using MediSave500 to pay for your chronic disease treatment, you could benefit from the higher withdrawal limits that kicked in yesterday. As part of our efforts to keep outpatient and primary care affordable for Singaporeans, the Ministry of Health, Singapore launched the MediSave700 scheme on 1 Jan 2021, to raise the yearly withdrawal limit from $500 to $700 for patients with complex chronic conditions. As many as 176,000 patients will benefit.

The new $700 limit applies to those who have had visits for two or more conditions under the Chronic Disease Management Plan (CDMP), or one CDMP condition with complications within a year. The CDMP covers 20 chronic diseases, including diabetes, hypertension, stroke and depression.

Under MediSave500 and MediSave700, you can use MediSave for other existing approved treatments, such as vaccinations and health screenings. You can also continue to tap on your own and family members' MediSave accounts, up to your own annual withdrawal limit.

We will continue to ensure that MediSave withdrawal limits remain adequate for Singaporeans. Find out more about MediSave500 and MediSave700 here: www.moh.gov.sg/cost-financing/healthcare-schemes-subsidies/medisave.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation and will be tightening border measures given the deteriorating situation in South Africa.

There have been recent reports of a potentially more contagious strain of the COVID-19 virus circulating in South Africa. To reduce the risk of spread to Singapore, we are putting in place new border restrictions for travellers from South Africa for further precaution.

From 3 January 2021, 2359 hours, until further notice:

a. All long-term pass holders and short-term visitors with recent travel history to South Africa within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Singapore, or transit through Singapore. This restriction will apply to those who have obtained prior approval for entry into Singapore.

b. Returning Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents will be required to undergo a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival in Singapore , at the start of their 14-day SHN. These test requirements do not apply to those who are only transiting through Singapore.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
31 December 2020 at 12:13 ·

As part of our efforts to help patients make more informed decisions about their care options in the private healthcare sector, the Ministry of Health, Singapore has published the Fee Benchmarks Advisory Committee’s (FBAC) recommendations on reasonable ranges for anaesthetist fees for about 190 procedures, and doctors’ inpatient attendance fees for their consultations and reviews of patients in different ward settings.

The fee benchmarks will give patients and payers, such as insurers, more complete information on the reasonable range of doctors’ fees for surgeries and hospital stays. They will also serve as a guide for private sector healthcare providers to charge appropriately.

Importantly, this latest move facilitates the delinking of private anaesthetists' fees from surgeon fees to better reflect the scope and complexity in managing anaesthetic risks in surgery. While anaesthesia fees have commonly been set as a proportion of surgeon fees, anaesthetists can now determine their own fees based on the risks associated with the surgery and any added complexity arising from the patient’s condition, independent of the complexity of the surgery.

Thank you to the members of the FBAC for your time and contributions in making this possible, and to all stakeholders who provided feedback through the numerous consultation sessions. The FBAC worked hard to ensure that the benchmarks reflect a fair range of professional fees that are representative of the risks and effort undertaken by doctors, while at the same time, ensuring that fees charged are fair and reasonable.

The latest fee benchmarks, together with the surgeon fee benchmarks for common surgical procedures published by MOH in 2018, will provide the public, the healthcare providers, as well as the insurers transparency, clarity and guidance. It is part of our larger strategy to ensure that healthcare costs remain affordable and our healthcare system sustainable. Find out more at: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moh-publishes-fee-benchmarks-for-private-anaesthetists'-and-inpatient-attendance-doctors'-fees. The latest fee benchmarks are available at the MOH website (www.moh.gov.sg/billsandfees).

As 2020 comes to a close, we take stock of the challenges that came with COVID-19 but also our fortitude to get through the crisis together as a nation.

Our journey amid this pandemic would not have been possible without the tireless efforts of all our unsung heroes – our healthcare and other frontline workers, and every Singaporean who has played your part to keep your loved ones and Singapore safe.

The fight is not over, but as we have done so as a nation when we met with setbacks in the past, we will rally, surmount difficulties in our way and emerge stronger as a nation.

Wishing all Singaporeans a Happy New Year! May 2021 herald better things to come!

As of 31 December 2020, 12pm, we have preliminarily confirmed 5 new cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. Based on our investigations so far, the cases are in the community, and there are no new cases in the dormitories. Of these, 2 are family members of Case 58810, and 3 are a family cluster involving a harbour pilot (Case 58817) who was detected from Rostered Routine Testing (RRT).

In addition, there are 25 imported cases, who had already been placed on Stay-Home Notice or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. Amongst them, 5 are Singaporeans or Singapore Permanent Residents, and 9 are foreign domestic workers. In total, there are 30 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.

We are aggressively tracing and testing the close contacts of the community cases so as to ringfence these cases and prevent further transmission. In addition, MOH will commence a special testing operations to test individuals who had boarded the ships that Cases 58810 and 58817 had recently worked on. We will also test harbour pilots, marine surveyors and ship repair workers in the coming days, regardless of their RRT schedule, to determine their COVID-19 status. In view of the recent cases involving the marine sector, we will review the need to tighten our precautionary measures for these workers.

We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
31 December 2020 at 02:00 ·

As 2021 beckons, it’s also an opportune time to take stock of the year’s happenings. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a far-reaching impact globally. Locally, our government agencies, including the Ministry of Health, Singapore have spared no effort in keeping Singaporeans safe from the virus.

While MOH’s focus was taken up substantially by COVID-19 efforts, we have also been driving other developments to better the health and lives of Singaporeans.

Since joining MOH, I’ve had the opportunity to work on effecting legal changes to build greater trust in the doctor-patient relationship; extending MediShield Life coverage to better support patients for large hospitalisation bills; and growing our healthcare workforce with new job opportunities. I’ve also met with important stakeholders like the Traditional Chinese Medicine community, General Practitioner leaders and fellow medical practitioners to foster closer partnerships and thank them for their hard work.

The coming year ahead will pose new challenges, but I’ve no doubt that with the resilience that Singaporeans have shown thus far, we will only get stronger. Wishing everyone a happy new year!

MediFund has been helping needy Singaporeans with their medical bills since 1993 and this year is no exception. From 1 April 2019 to 31 March 2020, a total of $159.1 million was disbursed to more than 1.2 million successful applications to assist Singaporeans who were unable to afford their medical bills, after receiving government subsidies and using their insurance and MediSave.

We have provided more assistance this year through MediFund, an increase of $2.6 million from the $156.5 million in FY2018. The increase was because of greater support extended to patients in the intermediate and long-term care facilities, including the elderly. I hope the assistance has supported them in focusing on their treatment and recovery, and alleviated their worries about their medical bills.

These key stats and more were shared in the Annual Report of the Medical Endowment Fund (MediFund) for FY2019, which colleagues at the @Ministry of Health, Singapore had submitted to Parliament on 28 Dec. To read more about the annual report, go to: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/medifund-continues-to-assist-needy-singaporeans-with-their-healthcare-needs-2020

Together with MediSave and MediShield Life, MediFund is a key component in our healthcare financing framework. It protects the right of every Singaporean to receive basic medical care.

Rahayu Mahzam
30 December 2020 at 07:26 ·

Research has shown that those who do not start smoking before 21 years of age are less likely to ever become smokers. And the younger one first starts smoking, the higher the probability of him or her becoming a habitual smoker.

Tobacco use continues to be one of the key contributors to ill health and premature death in Singapore. To encourage Singaporeans to stay smoke-free and to denormalise smoking among youths, we are raising the Minimum Legal Age (MLA) for the purchase, use, possession, sale and supply of tobacco products from 20 to 21 years old with effect from 1 Jan 2021.

For smokers, it is not too late to stub out now. You can call the national toll-free QuitLine at 1800-438-2000 to receive customised smoking cessation counselling from certified Quit consultants.

Besides the change in MLA, we remain committed to encourage tobacco-free living in Singapore through a comprehensive and multipronged approach which includes public education on the harms of tobacco use.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/minimum-legal-age-for-tobacco-raised-to-21-years-old-from-1-january-2021

If you are receiving acupuncture for lower back pain and neck pain at a specialist outpatient clinic in one of our public healthcare institutions, I’m happy to share that from today, patients like you will receive means-tested subsidies and MediSave coverage under a pilot arrangement by the Ministry of Health.

About 2,000 patients a year – or more than 70% of patients who receive acupuncture for lower back pain and neck pain – will stand to benefit from this.

Under the pilot, acupuncture treatment is subsidised by up to 70%, and Pioneer Generation and Merdeka Generation seniors get additional subsidies of 50% and 25% off their remaining bill. Patients can also use Flexi-MediSave, which allows those 60 and older to withdraw up to $200 per year from their own, or their spouse’s MediSave Account to pay for outpatient treatments. Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/pilot-for-extension-of-subsidy-and-medisave-for-acupuncture-at-public-specialist-outpatient-clinics

Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) plays an important complementary role in our healthcare system, and we hope this pilot will help make treatment more affordable.

We are also invested in nurturing the next generation of TCMPs in Singapore. Yesterday, I visited the NTU Chinese Medicine Clinic at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore to meet the administrators of the NTU Double Degree programme in Biomedical Science and Chinese Medicine. We discussed how the programme could be further enhanced to address challenges of the evolving healthcare landscape, including the need for more clinical research to support evidence-based practice. I look forward to more fruitful engagements with our partners in the TCM community, so that we can further advance the development of TCM in Singapore.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
23 December 2020 at 08:09 ·

I joined Public Free Clinic Society (PFCS) last Saturday to mark their 46th anniversary milestone, where I met some of their volunteer Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) practitioners who have been providing affordable and quality TCM services to lower-income families, and learnt more about their work.

I am also heartened to learn of PFCS’ efforts to further TCM research, which is important to help build up TCM research evidence to ascertain the efficacy of TCM treatments and advance TCM practice. PFCS recently upgraded their electronic clinical record system to kick off their research initiative to evaluate the efficacy of TCM treatments given to their patients. Efforts like this help to build a bridge between TCM and modern medicine, and will ultimately strengthen the complementary role of TCM in our healthcare system.

My heartiest congratulations to PFCS on its 46th anniversary, and I hope PFCS will continue to keep up the good work in the development of TCM in Singapore!

昨日有幸参加了大众医院欢庆46周年生日, 认识了一些为低收入家庭提供负担得起的优质中医服务的义务中医师，也让我对他们的工作有了更深的了解。

我欣闻大众医院通过其新的电子诊病系统，已为开拓中医药的调研工作踏出第一步，为传统中医学的疗效提供依据。这有助于建立中医药研究证据，确定中医治疗的成效，以及推动中医的执业。这也帮我们在中医和现代医学之间搭建桥梁，最终加强中医在我国医疗体系中的辅助作用。

我衷心祝贺大众医院成立46周年，也希望大众医院再接再厉，继续为本地中医药的发展尽一分力!

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation and will be tightening border measures given the deteriorating situation in the United Kingdom, and resurgence in the number of COVID-19 cases in New South Wales (NSW), Australia.

Given the increased cases observed in NSW, we will be tightening border control measures for travellers with travel history to NSW, Australia. From 23 December 2020, 2359 hours:

a. All travellers departing from Australia will be required to declare their travel history at airline check-in prior to their flight to Singapore.

b. Singapore Citizens (SCs), Permanent Residents (PRs) and Long-Term Pass holders entering Singapore with travel history to NSW, Australia within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will be subject to a 7-day SHN at their place of residence with a COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test before the end of the SHN period.

c. Short-term travellers holding an Air Travel Pass with travel history to NSW, Australia, within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will not be allowed to enter Singapore.

There have been recent reports of a potentially more contagious strain of the COVID-19 virus circulating in the UK. To reduce the risk of spread to Singapore, we are putting in place new border restrictions for travellers from UK for further precaution. From 23 December 2020, 2359 hours, until further notice:

All long-term pass holders and short-term visitors with recent travel history to the UK within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Singapore, or transit through Singapore. This will also apply to all those who had obtained prior approval for entry into Singapore.

Returning SCs and PRs will be required to undergo a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival in Singapore, at the start of their 14-day SHN.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-for-travellers-from-united-kingdom-and-new-south-wales-australia

The Government has accepted the MediShield Life Council’s recommendations on the MediShield Life 2020 review, and will implement them in March 2021. The changes will ensure that MediShield Life continues to provide adequate and meaningful protection to Singaporeans in light of medical advancements and healthcare cost inflation.

The key enhancements are:

- Refreshing and refining the claim limits to provide better coverage;
- Raising the policy year claim limit from $100,000 to $150,000; and
- Higher daily claim limits for the first two days of acute hospital stays.

The actuarially determined premium adjustments are necessary to support the rising number of claims and payouts as well as the enhanced benefits, and will ensure that MediShield Life remains sustainable in the coming years.

The government has committed about $2.2 billion for premium subsidies and support over the next three years to help Singapore residents with their MediShield Life premiums, including a $360 million COVID-19 subsidy for all Singapore Citizens for two years. This will keep the net premium increases for Singapore Citizens to no more than about 10% in the first year.

We understand Singaporeans’ concern about the premium increases given the economic impact from COVID-19. MediShield Life premiums can be fully paid using MediSave, and the vast majority of Singaporeans have sufficient MediSave for their premiums. Nonetheless, to further allay concerns about premium payment during this exceptional period, we will defer premium payment until end December 2021 for Singapore Residents who have insufficient MediSave balances and are unable to pay their premiums. The financially needy are encouraged to apply for Additional Premium Support for assistance with their premiums. No one will lose their MediShield Life coverage due to inability to pay.

We will also enhance the annual MediSave top-ups for Pioneer Generation (PG) seniors, so that all PG seniors who are 86 years old and above in 2020 will continue to have their MediShield Life premiums fully covered by the special PG premium subsidies and MediSave top-ups, while younger PGs will have about two-thirds of their MediShield Life premiums covered.

We would like to thank the Council for the time and effort committed to the comprehensive review.

Read on for more information on the accepted recommendations: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/government-accepts-medishield-life-council-s-recommendations-and-commits-2.2-billion-for-premium-subsidies-and-support

Masagos Zulkifli
18 December 2020 at 08:30 ·

With the COVID-19 outbreak, some of our community care service providers have accelerated their use of technology to deliver tele-rehab services and tele-consultations for their patients, so that patients can continue their recovery journey safely even during the pandemic.

SATA CommHealth was one such example. To ensure the smooth delivery of services, their therapy assistants would give seniors a phone call days before their therapy session, and guide them to set up the programme. Through Zoom, patients walked through their home environment with the therapists to ensure it’s suitable for tele-rehab. This also meant that therapists had to think out of the box, guiding patients to repurpose items found at home - like canned food or chairs - for their strength-training exercises. Over time, the team at SATA CommHealth ironed out the kinks and their tele-consultations have allowed seniors to continue with their treatment while saving them time and avoiding unnecessary visits to the physical centres.

These efforts were made possible by the Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore’s Video Consultation Infrastructure Fund under the #ReadyTogether initiative – aimed at helping home and centre-based community care service providers leverage technology as another means to engage their clients, especially during this COVID-19 period. So if you’re a community care provider on the look-out for digital solutions as you pivot your services for your clients, do reach out to our AIC colleagues or find out more on their website. We will continue to work closely with and support our community care providers as they care for our loved ones.

Lee Hsien Loong
14 December 2020 at 19:19 ·

It has been a long year. But because of our collective efforts against COVID-19, we are ready to enter Phase 3 on 28 December. This is only possible because everyone has made so many sacrifices, to bring our situation under control.

We will be providing free, voluntary vaccinations for all Singaporeans and long-term residents. We have approved the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for pandemic use, and the first batch will arrive this month. We also have other vaccines on order, and by 3Q2021 should have enough to vaccinate everyone.

I encourage you to get vaccinated, to protect not just yourself but also those around you.

The announcement of Phase 3 will bring some year-end cheer to us all, but please stay vigilant as the virus is not yet eradicated. It might be a year or more before we are in the clear, but at least we can see light at the end of the tunnel. – LHL

(MCI Photo by Chwee)

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation, and will be tightening border measures given the deteriorating outbreak situation in Hong Kong.

All travellers entering Singapore from 13 December 2020, 2359 hours, who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Hong Kong will now be required to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated SHN facilities. COVID-19 tests will continue to be administered before the end of the SHN.

All travellers (except Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents) entering Singapore from 18 December 2020, 2359 hours, who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Hong Kong will be required to take a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test within 72 hours before departure. Travellers will need to present a valid negative COVID-19 test result as a condition of approval to enter Singapore.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-for-travellers-from-hong-kong

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
11 December 2020 at 03:02 ·

I joined Minister Chan Chun Sing and Minister Josephine Teo for a visit to the NUS Alice Lee Centre for Nursing Studies yesterday. We had the opportunity to see some of our Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) nursing students in action as they simulated emergency care rendered to a patient who is injured in a road traffic accident. The teamwork they demonstrated brought back memories of the times I had to respond to trauma activation in the ER as a surgeon.

A job in healthcare is not a ‘career’, it is a ‘calling’. Our frontline healthcare professionals are driven by values and ethos in giving their best everyday to make an impact in the lives they touch. Everyday brings new challenges; every patient is a new opportunity to serve.

This year, against the backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic, we are seeing more mid-career individuals interested in joining our nursing PCPs. In the last 3 years, an average of 90 mid-career locals enrolled in our nursing PCPs each year. In comparison, the total enrolment this year is over 130, nearly 1.5 times more. To cater for more mid-career switchers to enter into nursing and allied health roles, we plan to open up close to 900 training places over the next three years.

The next PCP intake would be the degree-level PCP-RN intake in August 2021, and applications will start later this month. If you are interested, I encourage you to attend Workforce Singapore - WSG's virtual Career Previews to learn more about the PCPs available, and to consider a meaningful career in the healthcare. You can find out more about it here: www.go.gov.sg/pcp-rn-deg.

The hiring outlook for healthcare also continues to be positive. Employment opportunities in healthcare will continue to rise as we build more healthcare facilities, and also due to an ageing population and rising chronic disease incidence. Find out more about the latest Jobs Situation Report on the healthcare sector here: https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-releases/2020/1210-jobs-situation-report-15th-edition

Janil Puthucheary
10 December 2020 at 16:00 ·

The SARS epidemic in 2003 was a trial-by-fire for Singapore – we saw how an epidemic can threaten social stability and regional economies, and it showed us the importance of Urban Health Emergency Preparedness.

At the WHO European Healthy Cities Annual Business Meeting and Technical Conference organised by WHO Regional Office for Europe, I spoke about how the SARS experience shaped the attitudes of Singaporeans and informed our policies on emergency preparedness. Many of our SARS policies were precursors for our COVID-19 responses, such as implementing the public health principles of timely tracing, testing, quarantine, isolation and treatment in preventing COVID-19 transmission.

We will learn from past experience, here in Singapore and from around the world. Being connected to the global community means that we can benefit from international expertise and best practices.

As we continue on the long road ahead of us in the fight against COVID-19, let’s continue to work together and stay vigilant to keep our fellow Singaporeans safe.

This year, 95 healthcare professionals, caregivers and volunteers were honoured at the Healthcare Humanity Awards 2020, organised by The Courage Fund. The annual awards are a continuing legacy of the Courage Awards that were first given out in 2003 following the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in Singapore and pay tribute to healthcare workers, caregivers and volunteers who go the extra mile in caring for patients. This year’s awards recognise the winners for their contributions made in 2019.

President Mdm Halimah Yacob and Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong spoke at the virtual award ceremony to congratulate the award recipients and recognise their courage and efforts in providing care and comfort to the sick and infirm.

The recipients’ inspiring stories of compassion and selflessness remind us that even as we embrace technology and innovation to bring quality care to all, what often makes the biggest difference to the lives of the ill and frail is the human touch. Learn more about their stories at the awards ceremony here: https://www.facebook.com/108971197669853/videos/143504503876121

Masagos Zulkifli
8 December 2020 at 07:56 ·

Longer life expectancy is a gift to celebrate, and we can do more of the things we enjoy if we stay fit and healthy. Starting from 2021, seniors can look forward to a new baseline service at eldercare centres that will be rolled out nationwide. As part of the service, each eldercare centre will serve as the go-to point for all seniors in their community and provide a comprehensive “ABC” suite of services which include Active ageing programmes, Befriending or buddying, and information and referral to Care services.

With the new baseline service model, seniors will have more opportunities to stay active and take charge of their health. Seniors and their caregivers will also be better able to navigate the social and health support available. I look forward to eldercare centres adding to the vibrancy of each community, and seniors participating or volunteering actively to help other seniors in their midst.

To allow eldercare centres sufficient time to ramp up their resources and level up their capabilities before transiting to the new model, eldercare centres will be brought on board the new model in phases from 2021 to 2024. We will also incorporate feedback from stakeholders to refine the model and its services along the way.

Read more here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/implementation-of-new-baseline-service-at-eldercare-centres-for-all-seniors

The Seoul Garden restaurant located in Tampines Mall has been ordered to suspend its full operations (inclusive of both dining in and take-away) for 10 days between 5 Dec and 14 Dec 2020, with both dates inclusive, after investigations revealed that the restaurant had failed to ensure safe management measures (SMMs) on its premises.

We commenced investigations in respect of potential breaches of SMMs upon receiving information that Case 58401 had tested positive for COVID-19 infection after having dinner with 12 other family members at the restaurant on 21 Nov 2020. Investigations against the restaurant, as well as Case 58401 and his family members are ongoing, and further enforcement action may be taken pending the outcome of investigations.

We will not hesitate to take enforcement action against operators and individuals who fail to comply with the safe distancing and safe management measures. We urge everyone to continue to exercise social responsibility, and to comply with the prevailing measures. A resurgence of COVID-19 cases and clusters can easily emerge in our community if we let our guard down and become lax in adherence to SMMs.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/seoul-garden-restaurant-in-tampines-mall-to-suspend-operations-for-breaching-safe-management-measures

Masagos Zulkifli
1 December 2020 at 06:19 ·

The TraceTogether app and token as well as SafeEntry have become essential digital tools for us to get around amid the COVID-19 pandemic. But this transition may not be that simple for some of our seniors.

That’s why since October when outreach activities resumed, our Silver Generation (SG) Ambassadors from the Silver Generation Office have been hard at work visiting our seniors at home, to help them adapt to the new normal by embracing digital tools and staying connected with the community. For seniors whose lives were impacted by COVID-19, the SG Ambassadors also connect them to available support grants to help them to tide over this challenging period.

Our SG Ambassadors are easily identified by their Silver Generation Office (SGO) Polo T-Shirts and photo ID tags. They adhere strictly to safe management measures, such as wearing masks, keeping a safe distance inside seniors’ homes and taking temperature twice-daily, to keep these engagements safe for our seniors.

So the next time you see our SG Ambassadors on the streets or along the corridor, say ‘hi’ to them or find out more about the support and services available for seniors. Build a meaningful relationship with our SG ambassadors today and together we can stay active, healthy and connected!

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
29 November 2020 at 11:00 ·

Yesterday, I met general practitioner (GP) leaders and representatives from the College of Family Physicians Singapore and Singapore Medical Association virtually to thank the primary care community for their hard work in fighting the COVID-19 pandemic. We had a candid discussion on our continued efforts to battle the pandemic and GPs’ role in anchoring care in the community.

GPs are the first point of contact with patients and our first line of defence against COVID-19. They have been providing care and also swab tests, which have helped us to detect, isolate and provide early care for persons with COVID-19. So if you are unwell, do visit a GP and get swabbed if advised to do so.

Beyond COVID-19 efforts, GPs are the frontline of care in providing accessible care for patients – for their acute and chronic conditions, regular health screenings and coordinating their care needs with other providers. Since 1 Nov 2020, GPs on the Community Health Assist Scheme provide free childhood developmental screenings and subsidised recommended vaccinations for Singaporeans of all ages.

Having a regular family doctor is important for the continuity of care across various stages of life. The Ministry of Health, Singapore will continue to work closely with GPs to bring affordable and quality healthcare to Singaporeans. A big thank you to all the GPs in Singapore, who are working tirelessly to take care of us!

I attended a virtual conference with the Palestinian Authority’s Health Minister Mai Al Kaila on Tuesday, to exchange our experiences on managing the COVID-19 situation. We had a fruitful discussion and reaffirmed our warm relations. The Palestinian Authority also thanked Temasek Foundation for donating 3,000 COVID-19 Fortitude 2.0 tests to the Palestinians in July 2020.

I shared that the majority of our cases now are imported and all detected during their isolation period. The number of community and dorm cases has remained low.

This was made possible as Singapore’s fight against COVID-19 is a whole-of-society effort, with active participation and support from the wider Singapore community. We implemented “Circuit Breaker” measures on 7 April when cases spiked and since then, we have been taking a phased approach for the safe resumption of activities.

As we are continue in our journey towards Phase 3, to allow for more events and activities with larger group sizes, we hope Singaporeans will continue to work together to adhere to safe distancing and safe management measures, and support one another to keep Singapore and our loved ones safe.

Many of my medical colleagues have been troubled by the methods adopted by DoctorXDentist (DxD) to promote doctors who paid for their services. It is also unclear whether some of the patient “reviews” on the DxD website are genuine and consistent with the relevant rules and regulations. Following discussions with the Ministry of Health, Singapore, Singapore Medical Association and Singapore Medical Council, DxD will now remove all doctors and dentists from their website listing unless the doctor or dentist has opted in.

MOH and SMC are continuing to monitor the situation and will make further investigations into the DxD website where appropriate. We will not hesitate to take further action if necessary. We must safeguard the integrity of the profession and protect the interests of patients.

In the meantime, I urge all doctors, dentists and in particular patients to be cautious and circumspect when using the DxD website and any other platforms purporting to present reviews or directories of medical practitioners. Many of these doctors and dentists have not, in fact, been consulted to be listed, and there may be inaccurate or outdated information presented.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
25 November 2020 at 07:59 ·

Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) plays an important complementary role in our healthcare system, and Ministry of Health, Singapore has been working closely with the community to improve the industry’s standards and professionalism.

I met some of our TCM community partners virtually last month where we discussed the growth of the TCM community and how to raise the standards of TCM in Singapore for the benefit of patients. It was a fruitful exchange and we also took stock of what we have done so far this year. We implemented the Compulsory TCM continuing professional education earlier this year to support TCM practitioners in their professional upgrading. We have also supported the Academy of Chinese Medicine Singapore to set up a TCM Research Office that will provide strategic direction and promote TCM research. To further raise the standards of TCM practice, the TCM Practitioners Board has also set up working committees to start the review of TCM acupuncture practice standards.

All these would not have been possible without the support of the TCM community, and I look forward to many more opportunities to work with our partners and the community.

中医药在我国的医疗体系中扮演重要的辅助角色。卫生部一直以来都与中医药界密切地合作，致力于提高中医药业界的专业水平。

我上个月在线上与一些中医药界的社区合作伙伴进行交流，讨论有关中医药界在本地的发展方向以及如何提高本地中医的水平，好让病人从中受惠。我们也总结了今年所落实的措施。我们推行了强制性中医延续教育，协助中医师提升专业水平。另外，我们支持新加坡中医研究院.设立了中医药研究办事处, 为中医研究提供战略方向，以及推动中医药研究。此外，中医管理委员会也成立了工作小组，着手检讨中医针灸的行医水平。

中医药界的鼎力支持，让这些计划得以落实。我期待接下来有更多的机会能与中医药界及合作伙伴们携手合作，再结硕果。

Community transmission of COVID-19 in Singapore has been very low the past few weeks. This has been no accident, and is the result of everyone’s efforts in adhering to safe distancing and safe management measures. As we resume more activities and work towards Phase Three, we need to continue to work together to fight COVID-19.

While it has been more than 10 months since Singapore saw our first case, I know there are still many questions about COVID-19 on our minds - Why must we continue to wear masks? When will Phase Three start? Is a vaccine the silver bullet to end the pandemic?

I chatted about these and more with Warna 94.2FM DJs RZ and TG on their Dinamika Warna programme, alongside A/Prof Lim Poh Lian, Senior Consultant from the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. Catch our discussion today at 5pm, where we will share more about Singapore’s COVID-19 situation, the new-normal, as well as Singapore’s COVID-19 vaccine strategy.

Tune into Warna 94.2FM here: http://bit.ly/warna942melisten. Don’t miss it!

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
20 November 2020 at 10:56 ·

Nurses are our everyday heroes, touching the lives of their patients through their dedication and care. Yesterday, we honoured 10 of these heroes at the 14th Tan Chin Tuan Nursing Award for Enrolled Nurses, which recognises promising and talented Enrolled Nurses (ENs) who are dedicated to advancing the nursing profession locally.

One of the award winners was Ms Fatimah Binte Taha Suhaimi, a Principal Enrolled Nurse at Changi General Hospital (CGH). Fatimah once cared for a patient who had suffered injuries from a road traffic accident, and she remained in contact with the patient even after discharge so as to provide her with support and reassurance. Her passion in nursing has even inspired both her children’s choices of careers in nursing and social work!

ENs like Ms Fatimah play an integral role in our healthcare system. Not only do they touch their patients directly with their care, they also help to ensure safe and patient-centred clinical care for all patients.

My warmest congratulations to all of the 10 award recipients! As we continue to battle the COVID-19 pandemic, I hope your stories will inspire your peers to continue to persevere in doing their best.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation and will be tightening border measures given the resurgence of cases in Malaysia and Japan.

All travellers entering Singapore from 22 November 2020, 2359 hours, who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Malaysia will now be required to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated SHN facilities. This also applies to travellers entering Singapore to work under the Periodic Commuting Arrangement and returning Singapore-based travellers under the Singapore – Malaysia Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL).

All travellers, except Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents, entering Singapore from 27 November 2020, 2359 hours, who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Malaysia will be required to take a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test within 72 hours before departure.

All travellers entering Singapore from 22 November 2020, 2359 hours, who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Japan will be required to serve a 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities, even if they have obtained approval to opt out earlier. The 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities also applies to returning Singapore-based travellers under the Singapore – Japan RGL.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updated-border-measures-for-travellers-from-malaysia-and-japan

Masagos Zulkifli
16 November 2020 at 04:21 ·

Nearly half a billion people across the globe live with this diabetes. In Singapore, 1 in 3 individuals is at risk of developing this invisible chronic disease in their lifetime and among those with diabetes, 1 in 3 is not aware that they have it.

On Sunday, I joined Diabetes Singapore at their #WorldDiabetesDay celebration, which seeks to raise awareness of diabetes as a major public health concern. Even as we continue our fight against the COVID-19 pandemic, we must not lose sight of our war on diabetes. I’m glad that we have community partners such as Diabetes Singapore standing with us in this fight. To commemorate World Diabetes Day, they organised a series of activities, including health screenings for the community. They also launched BE SMART, an evidence-based community programme that motivates seniors to make sustainable lifestyle changes.

All of us can contribute to the War on Diabetes. We can take greater responsibility of our own health and encourage our family and loved ones to adopt a healthy lifestyle, and go for regular health screening, which is now more affordable and accessible through the Screen for Life programme. For individuals living with diabetes, let’s encourage and support them to better manage their disease, to avoid further complications.

As a nation, I believe we will triumph over diabetes as long as we work together and look out for one another. Together, let’s beat diabetes!

S Iswaran
16 November 2020 at 00:35 ·

A very good Monday morning to all!

A busy start to the week as my colleagues and I join some 200 industry and community partners onsite and 300 others virtually at the inaugural MCI Insights Conference today.

It’s apt that the conference is themed "Creating new opportunities, forging a thriving digital future for all" today. As we gradually move into a new normal, more events will resume. So for our inaugural MCI-Insights Conference, we piloted the Antigen Rapid Test (ART) for all physical attendees as their health and safety remains our top priority. A relatively painless process, the ART involves a nasal swab to obtain a sample from the lower part of the nose, which will be sent for an onsite analysis. The result will then be released via a text message in less than 30 minutes.

A big thank you to the group of swabbers from Jaga-Me, who put our participants at ease and ensured a smooth process. I am also grateful for the cooperation from our onsite participants for this pre-event testing. They had to come a little earlier for the pre-test but were happy to do so all in the name of safety and doing our part to regain some normalcy in our lives. This speaks volumes of the resilience of Singaporeans and I look forward to a fruitful day of discussions ahead!

#MCI #InsightsConference #SingaporeTogether #SGDigital

Residents in the East, especially in Bedok, can look forward to a new integrated general hospital and community hospital in Bedok North, which is expected to be ready around 2030. The new hospital will be located next to the Bedok North MRT station, bounded by Bedok Reservoir Road and Bedok North Road.

Minister Gan Kim Yong announced the location of the new integrated hospitals today on the sidelines of his visit to Outram Community Hospital (OCH). OCH is one of SingHealth Community Hospitals, and is one of the latest additions to the SingHealth family. SingHealth will also operate the new general hospital in Bedok North.

The development of the new hospital in Bedok North is part of the Ministry of Health’s continued efforts to improve Singaporeans’ accessibility to healthcare services. We will continue to invest in our healthcare infrastructure and facilities so that we continue to meet Singaporeans’ projected and current healthcare needs, as well as enable the public to continue to conveniently access affordable and quality care.

Read more about this new hospital at https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/new-integrated-general-and-community-hospital-in-bedok-north.

Stay one step ahead, just like Uncle Lee! (English)

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
10 November 2020 at 04:05 ·

Many are excited to read about the positive outcomes of the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine trials. While we await the final results of the trial, getting vaccinated today against vaccine-preventable diseases can reduce the risk of outbreaks in the community. Like how Uncle Lee, in this video by Health Promotion Board, Singapore stays ahead of vaccine-preventable diseases by getting vaccinated: https://bit.ly/36p7Yec

Over the years, the Ministry of Health, Singapore has also made it more affordable for Singaporeans – young and old alike – to get nationally recommended vaccinations. From 1 November 2020, we have extended subsidies for vaccinations under the National Childhood Immunisation Schedule (NCIS) and National Adult Immunisation Schedule (NAIS), which were previously available at polyclinics, to all Community Health Assist Scheme general practitioner clinics.

At CHAS GP clinics, eligible Singaporean adults only have to pay these amounts, after subsidies, for the range of nationally recommended vaccinations:

- Pioneer Generation cardholders: capped at $9 to $16 per vaccination dose
- Merdeka Generation, CHAS Blue and Orange cardholders: capped at $18 to $31 per vaccination dose
- Other eligible adult Singaporeans: capped at $35 to $63 per vaccination dose

At polyclinics, eligible Singaporean adults will receive up to 75% subsidy for NAIS vaccinations. Pioneer Generation and Merdeka Generation seniors will receive an additional 50% and 25% subsidy off their subsidised vaccination bills respectively.

All eligible Singaporean children enjoy full subsidies for NCIS vaccinations and childhood developmental screening at CHAS GP clinics and polyclinics, to ensure that they receive the necessary developmental assessments together with their childhood immunisations from their family doctor.

Do make appointments with your preferred clinics for vaccinations before visiting!

Find out more: www.healthhub.sg/vaccinate

Rahayu Mahzam
9 November 2020 at 10:01 ·

Did you know that the global symbol for diabetes awareness is a blue circle? It signifies the unity of the global diabetes community in response to the diabetes epidemic. It is also the logo of World Diabetes Day, which falls on 14 November this year. I’m glad to join Diabetes Singapore in lighting the Singapore Flyer in blue, to show support for those living with diabetes, and raise awareness of the importance of diabetes prevention and management.

We also flagged off the inaugural 5K Virtual Run which will take place from 6 to 15 November 2020. This is a meaningful symbolic endeavour as a healthy and active lifestyle is key to preventing and controlling diabetes.

Diabetes is an invisible chronic disease that requires us to work together as a nation to fight it. We can encourage one another to make healthier food choices and stay active. We can also remind our loved ones to go for regular health screenings, which are now more affordable and convenient, to better monitor and manage their health.

All of us can contribute to the War on Diabetes. Let us work together to create a healthier Singapore for all, and help those with diabetes to manage their condition well!

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation. As there has been a sharp increase in cases in Estonia and Norway in the past week, all travellers entering Singapore from 8 November 2020, 2359 hours who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Estonia and Norway will be required to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated SHN facilities, even if they have obtained approval to opt out earlier.

This is revised from our announcement on 27 October 2020 that travellers from Estonia and Norway were allowed to serve their 14-day SHN at a suitable place of residence.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Travellers are advised to visit the Safe Travel Office website (https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/health) to check for the most updated border measures before entering Singapore and be prepared to be subjected to the prevailing border measures upon entry, including payment for their stay at dedicated SHN facilities, tests and treatment.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
4 November 2020 at 02:05 ·

Ever since joining Ministry of Health, Singapore in July, I’ve had the opportunity to witness the resilience, strength and professionalism of our healthcare colleagues. The healthcare fraternity is a diverse community united by a shared calling to care for the ill and frail, and to help the well remain healthy. And this community of ours is growing.

As our population ages, Singapore’s healthcare needs are expanding. Correspondingly, the sector continues to offer meaningful employment opportunities. If you share our passion to serve and care, do consider joining the healthcare sector! On Monday, we launched the Healthcare Virtual Career Fair page – a one-stop platform for jobseekers, featuring over 2,000 jobs in public healthcare and community care, as well as a variety of mid-career training opportunities. You can also take a peek into what various healthcare roles are like through informative videos.

Working in healthcare gives you the chance to make a difference in people’s lives. Our healthcare institutions and partners are looking fill a wide range of positions, from nursing, allied health and support care roles to administrative and ancillary positions. They are open to fresh graduates and mid-career jobseekers from both healthcare and non-healthcare backgrounds alike.

If you would like to join our community of caring, find out more at: https://vcf.mycareersfuture.gov.sg/healthcare

Janil Puthucheary is with Sentill Ananthan.
2 November 2020 at 03:02 ·

Spent a pleasant evening with 50 passionate citizens where we discussed how we can age well in the “new normal”, as part of the SG Together Emerging Stronger Conversation (ESC). The participants were from diverse walks of lives, and shared their varied experiences and views as healthcare providers, caregivers, active volunteers and concerned members of the public. We had a lively and rich discussion on what we can do individually and collectively as a society to make Singapore a good place for us to age healthily, meaningfully and gracefully. From improving intergenerational bonding to bridging the digital divide, all participants shared their personal experiences and aspirations on how we can enable our seniors to leverage the opportunities brought about by COVID-19 to participate digitally and stay connected to their loved ones, in this “new normal”.

Let us journey together to co-create the Singapore that we want for our children and their children.

Be part of the Emerging Stronger Conversations today. Sign up for the Conversations at https://go.gov.sg/ESconversations

Share your reflections at the online portal - https://www.singaporetogether.gov.sg/reflect

Engage with friends and family using this digital conversation deck – https://go.gov.sg/sgtogetherxsmoltok

#SingaporeTogether #EmergingStronger

Masagos Zulkifli
1 November 2020 at 13:49 ·

Earlier today, I had the opportunity to offer my well wishes to newlyweds Aishah and Sufian at their wedding, which was also one of the events where pre-event testing was being piloted. Other than the safe management measures in place, the couple and all guests also underwent COVID-19 antigen rapid tests before the wedding. The process was smooth and straightforward, with most guests receiving their results within half an hour.

As we gradually resume more community activities in a safe manner, Ministry of Health, Singapore is currently conducting pre-event testing on a small number of weddings for couples who have voluntarily agreed. MOH will work together with the couple to understand their wedding plans and other considerations, to ensure that their special day will continue to run smoothly. So far, we have received positive feedback regarding the process for pre-event testing from attendees at other public events where this was carried out. We hope that pre-event testing paves the way for larger weddings to take place in the future.

For the moment, pre-event testing is only required for weddings that are involved in our pilots. Weddings can be held safely with 100 people as long as appropriate safe management measures are adopted. If you are planning an upcoming wedding, you can find out more at www.rom.gov.sg and www.romm.gov.sg.

I’d also like to reassure couples that there’s no need to delay marriage (and parenthood plans too!) because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The uncertainties of today remind us all to cherish our loved ones even more.

My heartiest congratulations again to Aishah and Sufian on this happy occasion in celebration of their union! Thanks to them and the guests for stepping forward to pilot the antigen rapid tests at this joyous occasion too.

(Photo credits: MCI)

30 October 2020 at 14:37 ·

Happy Community Care Day! 🎉 This year has no doubt been a challenging and unprecedented one, and I am proud to say that our community care sector has remained committed, dedicated and resilient. You responded swiftly to changing requirements, rallied one another, and came up with new ways to reach out to seniors under your care, such as through the use of technology. You even found ways to improve on processes to better safeguard the health and wellbeing of our seniors and improve care delivery during the COVID-19 pandemic.

It was heartening to hear your stories and motivations for going beyond the call of duty and connecting deeply with our seniors at today’s Community Care Day 2020 virtual celebration. To each and every one of you: thank you for your personal sacrifices and for your sustained and extraordinary contributions in caring for Singaporeans! And my heartiest congratulations to all recipients of this year’s Community Care Excellence Awards for the well-deserving recognition of your efforts.

I’m also glad to know that many supporters and friends have stepped up to journey with the community care sector in various ways. The Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore introduced a new Friends of Community Care Awards this year, to pay tribute to these supporters. I want to congratulate and thank all award recipients for their efforts and support. Everyone can play a part, and such whole-of-society efforts help ensure that the good work of the sector continues to reach those in need of help. I encourage more to step up and to support the sector in our own ways, for no effort is too small.

Click on to find out more about what I shared at the event: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/speech-by-mr-masagos-zulkifli-minister-for-social-and-family-development-and-second-minister-for-health-at-community-care-day-2020-virtual-celebration-30-october-2020-11.30am

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
30 October 2020 at 02:00 ·

This year, we recognised five outstanding healthcare professionals and a team who have made significant achievements in advancing healthcare, improving the standards of patient safety and driving research and education, which ultimately improve people's lives. My congratulations to the winners of the National Medical Excellence Award (NMEA) 2020!

Among the NMEA 2020 winners are Associate Professor Sum Chee Fang, who was recognised for excellence in clinical care, given his exemplary contributions to developing and advancing diabetes and endocrinology care. In the area of research excellence, the NMEA honoured Professor Yong Eu Leong, whose research in women’s health and human fertility pushed the frontiers of knowledge in the area.

This year’s awards also recognised Associate Professor Keson Tan, for his vision, passion and dedication in developing future generations of dentists; Associate Professor Nicholas Chew, for his exemplary contributions in advancing graduate medical education; and Dr Chow Mun Hong, for his dedication in advancing system-wide quality and safety for patients.

The KKH team comprising Dr Chua Mei Chien, Dr Pooja Agarwal Jayagobi and Ms Wong Anng Anng, was also lauded for establishing a national Donor Human Milk Bank programme to help premature and critically-ill babies in Singapore.

Their commitment to excellence and sense of purpose will no doubt inspire the wider healthcare family. Find out more about the award winners at: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/national-medical-excellence-awards-2020

Janil Puthucheary
28 October 2020 at 14:04 ·

Singapore ranks first globally for life expectancy (LE) at birth and healthy life expectancy (HALE) at birth, with the lowest Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) per 100,000 population in the world. This was based on the findings of the Global Burden of Disease 2019 study, which quantifies the magnitude of ill health and premature deaths due to diseases, injuries and risk factors across countries and through time.

Singapore has the highest LE at birth (84.9 years) and HALE at birth (73.9 years) in the world in 2019. This is an increase from 1990, when Singapore was ranked 26th in the world for LE (75.6 years) and 16th for HALE (66.6 years)

In line with the improvement in Singapore’s HALE at birth, Singapore also has the lowest age-standardised DALY burden, at 15,045 per 100,000 population in 2019.

Non-communicable diseases made up approximately 80% of the total disease burden in Singapore in 2019. Importantly, the study also found that approximately 35% of the DALY burden in Singapore can potentially be reduced by early intervention on modifiable risk factors such as smoking, poor diet, low physical activity and high blood pressure.

We will continue to work with our partners and stakeholders to further reduce disease burden among Singaporeans, by strengthening our existing initiatives and developing health interventions. Together, we can continue to keep ourselves healthy over our lifetime, stay disease-free, and foster a healthier Singapore.

Find out more about the GBD 2019 study findings: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/global-burden-of-disease-2019-study-findings

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce regularly reviews our border measures to manage the risk of importation and onward local transmission from travellers.

With the enhanced surveillance regime in place, we will also adopt a risk-based approach and allow more travellers from Estonia, Fiji, Finland, Japan, Norway, Republic of Korea, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Turkey to opt out of dedicated SHN facilities and serve their 14-day SHN at their place of residence, if they fulfil the following criteria:

a. Travelled to no other country than above-mentioned countries, in the last consecutive 14 days prior to entry; and
b. Are occupying their place of residence (i.e. residential address) alone, or only with household members who are also persons serving SHN with the same travel history and duration of SHN.

Travellers from the abovementioned countries may apply to opt out of dedicated SHN facilities from 2 November 2020, for arrivals on or after 4 November 2020. All travellers who opt to stay at their place of residence for SHN must remain in their declared place of residence at all times. They will be subject to close monitoring of their whereabouts and strict enforcement action will be taken against those who breach the requirements of the SHN or make false declarations.

From 1 January 2021, all incoming travellers will also be required to pay for their stay at dedicated SHN facilities, and will be responsible for their inpatient medical bills if they have onset of symptoms of COVID-19 within 14 days of their entry to Singapore. This includes all returning Singapore Citizens/ Permanent Residents/ Long-Term Pass Holders travellers who last left Singapore before 27 March 2020.

Singapore’s border measures will evolve as the global situation changes. We will continue to monitor the global health situation closely and update our border measures in accordance with the public health risk assessment.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-to-stay-home-notice-and-charging-policy-for-travellers

The Ministry of Health is advising that use of two influenza vaccines – SKYCellflu Quadrivalent and VaxigripTetra – should be temporarily ceased. This is a precautionary measure following reported deaths after influenza vaccination in South Korea. No deaths associated with influenza vaccination have been reported in Singapore to date. MOH and the Health Sciences Authority are monitoring the situation closely.

As a precautionary measure while HSA is assessing the implications of the reported deaths in South Korea, MOH has informed healthcare providers and medical practitioners to temporarily stop the use of these two vaccines. Healthcare providers and medical practitioners may continue to use the two other influenza vaccines that have been brought into Singapore for the Northern Hemisphere 2020/21 influenza season.

Persons recommended to receive the influenza vaccination, including those recommended under the National Childhood Immunisation Schedule (NCIS) and National Adult Immunisation Schedule (NAIS), may continue to receive their influenza vaccination using other brands of influenza vaccines.

MOH and HSA will continue to monitor the situation closely for any concerns related to influenza vaccination and keep members of the public updated on new developments.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/temporary-cessation-of-use-of-two-influenza-vaccines

Looking forward to sharing more about developments in the energy sector and how we intend to develop Singapore into a Bright Green Spark during my keynote speech at SIEW tomorrow. CCS

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
22 October 2020 at 07:58 ·

Ms Zabrina Kng took to the skies for 14 years as an air stewardess, but has always harboured an interest in healthcare since she was young. The patience and dedication of the nurses who cared for her mother when she was hospitalised left a lasting impression on her. In 2018, she enrolled in the Professional Conversion Programme for Registered Nurses (Diploma) – an accelerated two-year mid-career conversion programme and today is a staff nurse with Woodlands Health Campus. She is currently deployed at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) while the campus is being built.

“Nursing is not only a stable career but one with career growth and opportunities,” Zabrina shared. “Being a nurse also has its merits at home because I am in a better position to care for my family should the need arise.”

The Professional Conversion Programme for Registered Nurses (Diploma) helps and supports mid-career PMETs to acquire the relevant training to be registered nurses. It is offered by Workforce Singapore - WSG, in conjunction with Ministry of Health, Singapore and supported by MOH Holdings. Funding will be provided by WSG, MOH and a co-sponsoring organisation for successful candidates to undergo the Diploma in Nursing (Accelerated) at Nanyang Polytechnic. Trainees will also receive training allowances ranging from $1,700 to $2,050 per month throughout the two-year training period, pegged to their years of prior work experience.

Applications for the programme’s April 2021 intake is ongoing and will close on 30 Oct 2020. You can find out more about it here: https://conversion.mycareersfuture.gov.sg/Portal/ProgramDetails.aspx?ProgID=P00000188

Masagos Zulkifli
20 October 2020 at 11:26 ·

One of the biggest misconceptions Ms Bay Teck Cheng had about osteoporosis was that it only affects older people. But after she attended an online workshop on bone health, she realised that it was important to start ‘saving up’ calcium from young to build strong bones and avoid this condition in old age.

Ms Bay is one of 300 Bone Health Ambassadors who will be trained by the Health Promotion Board, Singapore (HPB) and Osteoporosis Society of Singapore (OSS) to support community events and public education sessions by healthcare professionals. The inaugural online workshop, held last month, saw some 120 participants learn more about bone health through interactive talks and role-play.

These ambassadors will be deployed at community events where they will play an important role in raising awareness of fall prevention among those over the age of 50, with information such as nutritional tips for good bone health and simple weight bearing exercises, as osteoporosis can increase the risk of fractures in older people.

As we commemorate World Osteoporosis Day today, let’s start practising these key habits to prevent osteoporosis: 1️⃣ increase your intake of calcium-rich foods, 2️⃣ exercise regularly, 3️⃣ avoid smoking and excessive alcohol. Health is wealth, and it’s never too early or too late to work towards a fit and fab you!

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
19 October 2020 at 11:08 ·

The MediShield Life Council has recommended that the Medishield Life scheme be enhanced and the premiums be adjusted to taken into account these enhancements as well as claims experiences over the last 4 years.

MediShield Life is a not-for-profit, universal scheme that provides Singaporeans with basic lifelong protection against large healthcare bills. Premiums collected are placed in the MediShield Life Fund and used solely for policyholders’ benefit and scheme administration.

Premiums are actuarially determined based on not only current claims but also future commitments, hence total premiums are higher than current payouts. This is because some diseases currently under treatment will require multi-year care, such as renal failure and cancer. Policyholders also pay more premiums during their working age, which are set aside for future premium rebates to moderate premium increases in their old age. This goes some way in making premiums more affordable when we are older.

The average Incurred Loss Ratio (ILR) of the Fund from 2016 to 2019 was 104%. This means premiums collected were slightly less than total monies required for current claims and future commitments. If you are interested, you can refer to the table for further breakdown of the premiums collected, claims paid, change in required reserves and ILR of MediShield Life Fund. In fact, about 40% of the premiums were contributed by the Government through premium subsidies for the lower- to middle-income and various other premium support. These info are already made public and you can also read more at https://www.moh.gov.sg/home/our-healthcare-system/medishield-life/what-is-medishield-life/about-the-medishield-life-fund.

It is expected that premiums rise with age because we are more likely to make claims when we get older. Among seniors above 65 years old, about one in six received MediShield Life payouts last year, compared to about one in 30 for the rest of the population. They also tend to have more serious conditions that result in larger bills. Their average payout per claim was $1,620, compared to $1,420 for the rest of the population.

The MediShield Life Council has suggested premiums adjustments and changes to ensure that MediShield Life remains relevant and sustainable.

- More Singaporeans are claiming, and claiming more from the scheme. Over the last four years, Annual payouts have increased by 40%. Number of claimants has increased by 30% and average payout per claimant has increased by 7%. Bulk of the premium increases are due to this and healthcare cost increases as we have not adjusted the premiums for 5 years.
- Revision of claim limits to ensure adequate coverage for the majority of subsidised bills.
- Enhanced benefits, including several that had been rolled out previously without adjusting the premiums such as extension to cover inpatient hospices, serious pregnancy complications and higher, more granular claim limits for surgical procedures.

We are mindful of the impact of COVID-19 but we hope Singaporeans can understand that we need to keep MediShield Life sustainable. As we have not adjusted the premiums for 5 years, delaying the premium increase further would only result in even higher premium increases down the road to catch up. Hence, we decided to instead cushion the impact of the premium increase with an additional COVID-19 subsidy for all Singapore Citizens over the next two years. Net premium increases after subsidy will be no more than about 10% in the first year.

We will continue to hold to our commitment that premiums will be affordable and no Singaporean will lose their MediShield Life coverage due to financial difficulties.

Janil Puthucheary
19 October 2020 at 09:46 ·

Visited Ang Mo Kio Polyclinic this morning, to thank our healthcare workers for their efforts in our nation’s fight against COVID-19.

During the visit, I announced that there will be a new polyclinic in Bidadari, located near the Alkaff Lakeview HDB cluster along Upper Aljunied Road. It will be developed as part of an integrated development with a nursing home, to serve the needs of residents in the vicinity of the upcoming Bidadari estate. The nearest MRT station is Woodleigh station about 500m away. We expect that it will be ready by 2027.

Including Bidadari, Singaporeans can look forward to 12 new polyclinics by 2030, which will bring us to a total of 32 polyclinics in Singapore.

Now that we are seeing fewer COVID-19 cases daily, more of our colleagues at the polyclinics can now focus on providing preventive and chronic care, treating patients for a variety of ailments and helping patients manage their chronic conditions. Their role is a critical one, especially as our population ages and chronic disease prevalence increases. We will ensure that Singaporeans continue to have access to affordable healthcare in the community.

More details on the polyclinic in Bidadari here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/polyclinic-in-bidadari-to-be-located-along-upper-aljunied-road

One’s youth is no barrier to dedication and a strong desire to serve. Mr Khairul Rusyaidie, who assists physiotherapists in conducting exercises for seniors at Vanguard Healthcare’s Woodlands Care Home, is one such shining star. A recipient of this year’s Community Care Manpower Development Awards (CCMDA), Khairul is pursuing a Work-Study Diploma in Rehabilitation Care at the Institute of Technical Education.

Khairul was inspired to join the community care sector when he saw how a therapist helped his grandmother regain her ability to walk after an extended period of severe osteoarthritis.

Community care staff like Khairul play a critical role in the recovery journey for our seniors. Whether in frontline roles like nurses, doctors or therapists, or back-end support functions such as administration and executive roles, all our community care staff are part of an important ecosystem to ensure seamless and holistic care for our seniors. Kudos to them!

I attended the CCMDA ceremony on 16 Oct. This is the first time the ceremony is held virtually – the COVID-19 situation hasn’t held us back in recognising our community care staff. I am touched that our community care staff are all united by a common purpose, that drives the kind of work that they do every day.

Despite busy schedules, many of them continue to engage in lifelong learning, so that they can provide better care for our seniors. To continually support our community care staff in enhancing their skills and knowledge, the CCMDA covers a range of programmes in clinical and non-clinical areas.

Congratulations to the award recipients! I hope your passion and spirit to serve will inspire many more to join the community care sector.

We are offering these tests to selected groups whose work involves more frequent interaction with the public, like stall holders and food delivery riders.

I visited the COVID-19 screening centre at Blk 402 in Ang Mo Kio today, and was glad to see many coming forward to be swabbed. Beyond AMK, the testing operations will also be progressively rolled out to other parts in Singapore. This testing exercise requires the joint efforts of multiple agencies working closely together with community partners. Thank you to all the teams managing this, and keep up the good work! – LHL
