Janil Puthucheary
15 October 2020 at 11:35 ·

Spoke in Parliament yesterday about the GPFirst programme, which helps our hospitals’ Emergency Departments (EDs) focus on attending to patients with life-threatening and critical conditions.

We piloted GPFirst at Changi General Hospital (CGH) in January 2014 to encourage patients with non-emergency conditions to seek treatment at GPs rather than at EDs. If patients are subsequently assessed by GPs to require emergency care, they will be referred to the ED, where they will get priority to be seen earlier, and receive a $50 subsidy on their ED bill.

With the pilot, we saw a reduction of about 8.5% in the self-referred attendances at CGH’s ED from 2014 to 2017. This may be attributed in part to GPFirst.

The Ministry of Health, Singapore has since expanded GPFirst. It now includes GPs around Khoo Tech Puat Hospital and the new Urgent Care Centre @ Admiralty. By end 2021, the initiative will also be implemented in regions surrounding Sengkang General Hospital, National University Hospital - NUH and Ng Teng Fong General Hospital

Go to the ED only for emergencies that are urgent and life-threatening. For non-emergencies and milder to moderate conditions, do go to your #GPFirst!

Watch my reply in Parliament here: https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/parliament/videos/october/janil-puthucheary-on-expanding-gpfirst-programme-13281284

Masagos Zulkifli
13 October 2020 at 12:05 ·

The COVID-19 pandemic has changed the way we work, live and learn. Our seniors are no exception. Many face-to-face courses and activities for seniors have gone online to ensure that they can continue to participate in their courses safely from their home.

I understand that embracing technology can be a challenge for some seniors who aren’t digital natives. But help is available, and many providers have gone the extra mile to lend a helping hand to our seniors as they transit to virtual activities.

For example, the SG Digital Office under Infocomm Media Development Authority - IMDA mobilised 1,000 Digital Ambassadors to provide one-on-one coaching on digital skills – such as making video calls and using smartphone apps. To date, over 21,500 seniors at 34 SG Digital Community Hubs in Community Centres/Clubs have benefitted from this initiative.

Our colleagues at Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore’s (AIC) Silver Generation Office (SGO), together with IMDA, are also working on reaching out to more seniors in the heartlands through the digital clinics at the SGO Satellite Offices.

As with learning anything new, some things may seem difficult at first, but with some practice, you will get the hang of it in no time! Meanwhile, the Ministry of Health, Singapore will continue to work with our stakeholders to ensure that seniors with a passion for lifelong learning can continue to benefit from the myriad learning opportunities available.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce had earlier announced that travellers from Malaysia are allowed to serve a 7-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at their place of residence. As there has been an increase in cases in Sabah recently, all travellers entering Singapore from 14 October 2020, 2359 hours, who have a travel history in the past 14 days to Sabah will be required to serve a 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities. This also applies to returning Singapore-based travellers under the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL), as well as Malaysian Citizens and PRs entering Singapore under the Periodic Commuting Arrangement. We are monitoring the situation across other states and federal territories closely, including Kuala Lumpur, Selangor and Putrajaya.

To reduce the importation of cases from Indonesia and the Philippines, travellers who are not Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents and who have recent travel history to Indonesia or the Philippines within the last 14 days prior to entry will be required to take a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test within 72 hours before departure. Travellers will need to present a valid negative COVID-19 test result as a condition of approval to enter or transfer through Singapore. This requirement will take effect for those arriving in or transferring through Singapore from 19 October 2020, 2359 hours.

As Hong Kong is a low risk region, we will reduce the SHN period from 14 days at dedicated SHN facilities, to 7 days at their place of residence, for travellers from Hong Kong, from 14 October 2020, 2359 hours.

As COVID-19 testing is an integral element to the safe resumption of travel, we will make COVID-19 testing more accessible for travellers. There are currently over 150 clinics that provide pre-departure testing to eligible travellers. We will increase the number of clinics and providers who can administer the COVID-19 PCR tests for pre-departure testing.

Singapore’s border measures will evolve as the global situation changes. We will continue to monitor the global health situation closely and update our border measures in accordance with the public health risk assessment.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-and-covid-19-testing-for-travellers

Masagos Zulkifli
10 October 2020 at 11:32 ·

Ivan Lim held a stable job and finances were nary an issue for him. It appeared that Ivan had everything, yet nothing, as he never knew what happiness felt like. Due to marital problems, he turned to alcohol every night even after he crashed his car while asleep at the wheel. It was only when his mum found him almost unconscious, that she set up an appointment with a psychiatrist. In 2001, the 34-year-old was diagnosed with depression.

It is important to seek professional help early for your mental health condition. If you are worried about stigma or don’t know where to start in seeking help, try the online tool mindline.sg, developed by MOH Office for Healthcare Transformation, the Institute of Mental Health, MSF Singapore and NCSS Singapore. It is a useful and convenient website that has a comprehensive list of resources and a self-assessment tool to connect you to the right resources based on your needs. The self-assessment results will guide you along appropriate pathways of intervention and support. You can also choose to talk to someone if you prefer personalised assistance while remaining anonymous.

Another resource you can turn to is the “My Mental Health” microsite (www.stayprepared.sg/mymentalhealth/), which provides tips on stress management and information on mental health-related programmes.

The road to recovery for mental health patients may be a long one. But as we commemorate World Health Mental Day, I want to assure you that you don’t have to walk this journey alone. Through the Community Mental Health Masterplan launched in 2012 and further enhanced in 2017, the Ministry of Health, Singapore, has significantly increased its outreach and care for those with mental health conditions and will continue to strengthen its services and programmes.

Ivan, who is now 54, has kept his condition under control after a series of therapy sessions and medication. He is now happily married with a teenage son. He finds joy in spending time with his family and playing music. So if you feel like your world is bleak, take the first step and reach out for help. We must remember that for every storm that passes, the sun will rise again.

AIC Born To Care campaign 2020

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
10 October 2020 at 11:00 ·

We all grow old some day and hope to be cared for when we are in need. The community care sector is an integral part of our healthcare system, ensuring that those with healthcare needs can be cared for at home and in the community. It is also an area that has growing manpower needs, as our population ages and chronic disease burden grows. In August, we announced that 7,500 jobs, and about 1,600 traineeships, attachments and skills training opportunities will be made available in healthcare, including in our growing community care sector.

Community care workers help people who need medical care and support to live as independently as possible while minimising social isolation. You could say that they were born to care, as this video by the Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore shows: https://youtu.be/k9WRuQTd4rM. Their roles range from clinical (nurses, allied health professionals and support care staff), to non-clinical (administration/ancillary and operations). Job seekers with no medical or healthcare background are also welcome to join the community care sector.

Check out the current job opportunities available at AIC’s website: www.borntocare.sg. You can also find out more from Workforce Singapore - WSG’s MyCareersFuture job portal, and various job fairs and recruitment platforms.

If you are living with chronic conditions, regular follow-up with your family doctor is key to managing your health. I am happy to share that you can now tap on CHAS Chronic subsidy and MediSave to offset the cost of video consultation, related drugs and investigations for all 20 chronic conditions under the Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP). This is up from 7 conditions covered under the scheme when we first introduced it in April 2020. We hope that this will help support even more patients with stable chronic conditions to benefit from receiving care while avoiding a trip to the clinic.

Even with the consultations carried out remotely, we want to ensure our patients’ safety and wellbeing. Healthcare professionals who provide these video consultations are trained to do so. Ministry of Health, Singapore also has guidelines for providers to only carry out video consultations for suitable patients who have been assessed that they do not require an in-person physical examination. If your doctor assesses that there is a need to visit the clinic for a physical consultation, you will be advised to do so.

To find out which healthcare institutions provide this service, please visit www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vc.

You can also read on for more information at: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expansion-of-chas-chronic-subsidy-and-medisave-for-video-consultation-to-all-chronic-conditions-under-the-chronic-disease-management-programme

COVID-19 has reminded us of the world’s interconnectedness and interdependency. Tackling this pandemic must be a collective effort built on the principles of multilateralism and international cooperation. This is a challenge that no single country can confront on its own.

Singapore stands in solidarity with the WHO and Member States against this global threat. Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
6 October 2020 at 11:17 ·

Two Amendment Bills were passed in Parliament today. The amendments to the Civil Law Act (CLA) will uphold clarity, certainty and consistency in the taking of informed consent, while amendments to the Medical Registration Act (MRA) seek to strengthen the medical disciplinary process.

The practice of medicine is centred on the doctor-patient relationship, which in turn is built on trust. Patients need to be able to trust that their doctors will do their best for them. Doctors also need to be able to trust that the disciplinary system they operate in is a fair and transparent one which produces consistent outcomes, and which sets and applies clear standards on what is required of doctors.

I look forward to the new statutory test under the CLA, which will set out a healthcare professional’s duty in giving medical advice to his patient. This new test will uphold the principle of self-regulation in the medical profession and at the same time preserve the principle of patient autonomy. It acknowledges the reality that the doctor and the patient are in fact on the same side, working towards the same outcome - the good health and recovery of the patient.

Much thanks to the 12-member Workgroup appointed by Ministry of Health, Singapore in March 2019 for coming up with the wide-ranging recommendations to improve the medical disciplinary process and the taking of informed consent. They had engaged widely last year to canvass views from various stakeholders, and some of their recommendations will come into effect following the legislative changes passed today. I look forward to continued partnership with them, and the wider healthcare fraternity, to build stronger trust in the doctor-patient relationship, which will ultimately benefit both patients and doctors.

For those who are interested to know what these amendments are and why we are making them, you can read more at: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/amendments-to-medical-registration-act-and-civil-law-act.

Masagos Zulkifli
1 October 2020 at 05:59 ·

As the adage goes – age is but a number as it’s not the years in your life that count but the life in your years.

This phrase is especially meaningful today, as the world comes together to celebrate the International Day of Older Persons, to mark the contributions of our seniors.

By 2030, 1 in 4 Singaporeans will be above the age of 65 and we will have over 900,000 seniors. To ensure that seniors stay healthy even as they live longer, we launched the Action Plan for Successful Ageing in 2015, aimed at enabling them to live their silver years meaningfully and confidently. But our work doesn’t stop here and we will be reviewing our Action Plan, to help more Singaporeans add quality years to their life.

Take for example 67-year-old Sebastian Lim, who never let his age be a setback. When he found out that he had high cholesterol, it ignited his desire to stay healthy and he turned to Aikido, Brazilian Jiu-jitsu and Chinese martial arts. Over time, his tenacity paid off as he got rid of his high cholesterol. Besides sport, he has a passion for learning and just last year, he completed a certificate in business analytics at the Singapore University of Social Sciences. He’s now setting his sights to pursue a certificate course in photography at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts.

Like Sebastian, we must remember that ageing is not lost youth, but a new stage of opportunity and strength. You can log on to the I Feel Young SG website, and choose from a wide array of volunteer opportunities, active ageing programmes, skills-based courses, and even enjoy senior discounts to attractions!

Ministry of Health, Singapore will continue its efforts to transform Singapore to a “City of All Ages”, where seniors can continue to grow and achieve their fullest potential. You too can do your part by staying active!

(These photos were taken before the COVID-19 outbreak)

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
1 October 2020 at 03:50 ·

Today, two new schemes which better support Singaporeans in their long-term care come into effect. CareShield Life, our national long-term care insurance, provides lifetime monthly cash payouts for as long as one is severely disabled. Payouts increase over time, starting at $600 per month in 2020 and increasing annually until age 67 or when a successful claim is made, whichever is earlier. MediSave Care enables those aged 30 and above who are severely disabled to withdraw cash of up to $200 per month from their and/or their spouse’s MediSave account for long-term care expenses.

We hope that these schemes will make life a little easier for Singaporeans like Mr Ivan Lim and his family. Ivan, 30, has autism, severe intellectual disability and visual impairment. His mother, Mdm Esah, has been his main caregiver since he was born. Ivan, who attends the SPD Day Activity Centre programme on a part-time basis, is fully dependent on her for most of his daily activities. His sister is the sole breadwinner of the family and they have been benefitting from the Home Caregiving Grant. Mdm Esah says the CareShield Life payouts will help to lessen the burden on her daughter and also gives her peace of mind for Ivan’s future expenses.

Applications for CareShield Life and MediSave Care open today. Applicants will need to undergo a severe disability assessment by an MOH-accredited severe disability assessor and submit the application to AIC. The list of assessors has been expanded to include trained therapists and nurses.

For more information on CareShield Life and MediSave Care, visit:
https://www.aic.sg/CareShieldLife
https://www.aic.sg/MediSaveCare

Lee Hsien Loong
1 October 2020 at 02:37 ·

COVID-19 has been particularly tough for the elderly. Not only are they most at risk from the virus, but the necessary social distancing precautions have had a detrimental effect on old people, especially those living alone and the less digitally savvy.

During the circuit breaker, the Silver Generation Office (SGO) stepped up its care for the most vulnerable seniors. It mobilised SG Ambassadors to assist seniors in various ways – distributing food packs, shopping for groceries and collecting medication, so that seniors could stay home safely. SG Ambassadors also called them regularly by phone, to monitor their well-being, and most importantly, assure them someone was looking out for them.

Many volunteers stepped forward to support SGO’s efforts, including 500 public officers. Since February when the COVID-19 outbreak began, SGO has engaged more than 83,000 vulnerable seniors and responded to close to 3,000 requests for assistance.

1 October is the International Day of Older Persons. I am glad that we are also paying tribute to SG Ambassadors and all who volunteered at SGO during this difficult period. You can read their stories in #SGOCares (go.gov.sg/sgocares), an e-book that was launched by SGO.

Thank you SGO and our SG Ambassadors, for your service and care towards our seniors, especially during these challenging times. – LHL

#SGUnited
#SGAmbassadors
#AICEngages

This World Heart Day, take the first step towards a healthier heart, by eating healthily and leading a healthy lifestyle!

In 2018, ischaemic heart disease was the third most common cause of death in Singapore. This includes acute myocardial infarction (AMI), commonly known as heart attack.

Heart attack patients tend to have common risk factors, such as high blood pressure, high blood cholesterol, overweight, diabetes and being current or ex-smoker. This is why it is important to make healthier lifestyle choices to prevent a heart attack. Choose to eat healthily, exercise, stop smoking, manage your chronic conditions if you have them, and go for regular health screening for early detection.

Check out this infographic by the Health Promotion Board, Singapore to learn how to spot common symptoms of heart attacks and how you can lower your risk of heart attack.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
25 September 2020 at 08:52 ·

Last week, I shared about the recently opened Urgent Care Centre at Kampung Admiralty (UCC@Admiralty) which eases the load on hospital Emergency Departments (EDs) by tending to patients who need urgent care for non-life-threatening conditions.

Complementing this effort is our GPFirst programme, which encourages patients with non-emergency conditions to see their general practitioners first, instead of heading straight to the ED. If patients are assessed by GPs to need ED care, they are immediately referred to the ED and will be prioritised over other non-emergency cases. They also receive a $50 subsidy for their ED bill, in recognition of having incurred initial charges at the GP.

GPFirst helps EDs to focus their resources on attending promptly to critically ill patients. Patients with non-emergency conditions also benefit from quicker access to care at GPs.

GPFirst was piloted in 2014 at Changi General Hospital (CGH), whose partner GP network includes Tampines, so Tampines residents can tap on this programme! We are progressively expanding the programme to other partner hospitals and GPs, including residents in the North.

Remember, visit the EDs only for serious, urgent and life-threatening emergencies. If you have these mild to moderate conditions, you can consult your GP:
- Abdominal pain or indigestion
- Insect bites and stings
- Mild burns and scalds
- Nausea and vomiting
- Strains and sprains
- Sore eyes

For more information on GPFirst, check out the Facebook page GPFirst.

Want to thank our Community Care heroes?

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
23 September 2020 at 02:02 ·

Being a community care worker takes more than just medical know-how. You also need a lot of heart – as exemplified by this video by the Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore about a team of community care staff who went the extra mile to make sure a patient could attend his daughter’s wedding.

That’s why I find AIC’s Thank You Project (https://www.thankyouproject.sg/) particularly meaningful – you can leave a thank you message and choose a sponsored gift to show your appreciation to the community care workers in our midst. These are our allied health professionals (including therapists, medical social workers and dietitians), support care staff (such as healthcare assistants, nursing and therapy aides), community care nurses, as well as administration and operations staff. They work hard every day to ensure that Singaporeans can be cared for closer to their homes.

The community care sector is one of the key areas where we are ramping up manpower to meet Singapore’s growing healthcare needs. The Ministry of Health, Singapore is setting aside $150 million over the next three years to support community care institutions to make salaries more competitive for up to 4,000 local nurses and support care staff. We are also continuing efforts to attract fresh graduates and mid-careerists to join the healthcare fraternity and bring non-practising nurses back to our healthcare family.

If you would like to take up a career in community care, check out the opportunities available at Workforce Singapore - WSG MyCareersFuture job portal, and various job fairs and recruitment platforms.

Masagos Zulkifli
21 September 2020 at 14:27 ·

One in ten seniors aged 60 years in Singapore and above is estimated to have dementia, and we expect this number to rise with Singapore’s ageing population. This also means that the burden on caregivers will get heavier, and they will need stronger support.

Since 2012, Ministry of Health, Singapore has been strengthening mental health care under the Community Mental Health Masterplan. Besides increasing services and resources available, we also work closely with community partners to reach out to those with dementia and their caregivers through their public education programmes.

But building an inclusive environment for those with dementia requires a whole-of society effort. Our dementia community is multi-faceted and their diverse stories are aptly represented in this colourful Lego mural unveiled by the Alzheimer's Disease Association - ADA today to commemorate World’s Alzheimer’s Day.

The journey of a caregiver and those living with dementia is never easy. We will walk this journey with you and continue to increase capacity and improve service quality for our dementia care services.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
18 September 2020 at 08:05 ·

[New Models of Delivering Healthcare]

Each time we develop a new regional health system, it allows us the opportunity to break new grounds and push out new models of patient care. This is the third week of operations of the Urgent Care Centre at Kampung Admiralty (UCC@Admiralty). Patients who require urgent medical attention for conditions that are not life-threatening can now seek treatment at UCC@Admiralty. The UCC care model sits between primary care (such as GP Clinics and Polyclinics) and the hospital Emergency Department (EDs).

UCC@Admiralty is sited in the community, and is manned by a multi-disciplinary team of family physicians, medical officers/residents, nurses and allied health professionals. It has on-site radiology services and provides minor surgeries and procedures such as stitching of wounds.

Remember, visit the EDs only for serious, urgent and life-threatening emergencies. For common illnesses, such as cough, colds or simple sprains, do continue to consult your family doctor. To know when you should visit the GP clinic, UCC or ED, check out Woodlands Health Campus’s (Woodlands Health Campus) site for some common conditions and recommendations on where you should go to seek medical attention: www.whc.sg/FeelingUnwell

Heng Swee Keat
17 September 2020 at 13:42 ·

Health and finance have always been closely intertwined, and in a pandemic, this is even more so. Earlier this evening, Gan Kim Yong and I participated in the Joint Finance and Health Ministers Meeting hosted by G20 Saudi Arabia. We thank our Saudi colleagues for their leadership. COVID-19 is a global crisis, so international cooperation is critical. The #G20, which covers nearly 80% of the world’s economy, and the World Health Organization (WHO) have key roles to play.

Countries, International Organisations and the private sector are joining forces to accelerate vaccine development, maximise manufacturing capacity, and ensure equitable distribution. Singapore is an early supporter of the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access Facility. Switzerland and Singapore are also co-chairing the “Friends of the COVAX Facility” to promote vaccine multilateralism.

At the same time, as we restart our economies in a safe manner, countries need to coordinate our resumption of activities. As we restart air travel, testing will be key to give assurance to travellers and public health authorities. We must work together to develop international standards, and share test results quickly including through electronic means.

We must also continue to identify gaps and strengthen our health and financial resilience against future outbreaks.

(MCI Photos by Betty Chua)

Lawrence Wong
9 September 2020 at 15:10 ·

<Strengthening Measures for Safer Reopening>

To enable the safe resumption of more activities, we are enhancing our TraceTogether programme and SafeEntry. In particular, we will deploy SafeEntry together with TraceTogether (TT). This means that in certain venues with higher-risk activities, you can only enter with TT. This “TT-only SafeEntry” will be piloted initially at selected venues like B2B events. Over time, we intend to expand to more venues, especially in settings where there are large groups of people, close interactions, and where masks are not worn, eg hotels (for wedding functions), F&B outlets, cinemas, gyms and certain workplaces. In parallel, for those who do not have smartphones to download the TT app, we will be commencing nation-wide distribution of TT tokens from 14 Sept. We will start in the areas with a higher concentration of elderly who may have more challenges using the TT app.

We are also monitoring closely the situation at F&B outlets. Dining out is an activity that involves considerable risks, because people are gathered in an enclosed space, without their masks on, and for a prolonged duration. That’s why we have in place a whole series of safe management measures to ensure safety. While the majority are complying with these measures, we continue to observe breaches at some F&B outlets. We will therefore step up spot checks and enforcement actions. So far agencies have issued warnings for the first offence. By now sufficient time has been given for everyone to adjust. So with immediate effect, agencies will take enforcement action even for first offenders. This will be in the form of a fine or even a closure of the premise depending on the severity of the offence.

Our ability to continue on this path of safe reopening depends on our ability to control the infection, and to uphold all the required safe distancing measures. We need everyone to cooperate and do their part, so that we can continue to resume more activities over time in a safe and sustained manner.

From 9 September 2020, more senior-centric activities will resume carefully as community infection rates have remained generally low and stable.

Small group activities of up to 5 pax may resume for senior-centric programmes organised by the People’s Association, Health Promotion Board, Sport Singapore, and the Council for Third Age. They will also be allowed to resume in eldercare facilities, such as Senior Care Centres, Active Ageing Hubs and Senior Activity Centres.

Proactive outreach by Silver Generation Ambassadors, Senior Activity Centres, Community Resource, Engagement and Support Teams, and diabetes outreach activities will also resume with safe distancing measures in place.

As more activities resume, we urge seniors to remain vigilant, conscientiously practise hand hygiene and safe distancing and to continue to keep to a small regular circle of contacts when going out.

We will continue to monitor the situation closely, with the aim of continuing to ease measures until we reach a new normal in Phase Three.

Read more here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/further-resumption-of-activities-for-seniors

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce (MTF) has been closely monitoring the local and global COVID-19 situation. While local community transmission is currently low, we cannot let our guard down.

We remain very concerned about Safe Management Measures (SMM) breaches at F&B outlets. We will continue to step up enforcement checks at F&B outlets and will take appropriate action against businesses and individuals who breach the SMMs. With immediate effect, agencies will take enforcement actions even for the first offenders. This will be in the form of a fine or a closure of the premise, depending on the severity of the offence.

To enable more workers to return to workplaces safely, MOM is working with tripartite partners on the next phase of SMM for workplaces. Employers need to implement flexible workplace hours, so that a good part of workers are able to travel off-peak hours, to mitigate the risk of crowding in public places and office buildings. It is critical that employers implement their safe management measures seriously, and ensure that safe distancing is adhered to.

To keep Singapore COVID-safe, everyone, including individuals and business owners, will need to play their part, by adhering to the safe distancing measures and SMMs in place. Together, we can ensure continued safe reopening of activities, while keeping ourselves and our loved ones safe.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/strengthening-measures-for-safe-re-opening-of-activities

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
9 September 2020 at 08:05 ·

If you are looking for a career switch into the community care sector, Ren Ci Hospital is looking for those with a passion for caring for seniors to join them as Resident Care Associates.

The community care sector is growing, as we expand our healthcare sector hiring to meet rising healthcare needs due to Singapore’s ageing population. Last month, we announced that 7,500 jobs, and about 1,600 traineeships, attachments and skills training opportunities in the healthcare sector will be made available.

The Resident Care Associate role was created by Ren Ci two years ago, as part of a job redesign initiative – enabled by Ministry of Health, Singapore's Healthcare Productivity Fund – to complement the model of care at its Ang Mo Kio nursing home. Resident Care Associates work with therapists, nurses, social workers and other allied health professionals to manage various aspects of residents’ care, and focus on getting to know the residents to better understand their needs and improve their quality of life.

It is a complex task, but Mr Mizahairi Mahadi can attest to the level of fulfilment it brings. He became a Resident Care Associate after spending many years in the music industry teaching youths. While the learning curve was steep at first, Miza persisted because he wants to give back to the community and gain a better understanding of the diverse roles of the community care support worker. With the support from his colleagues and residents’ next-of-kin, Miza has been helping seniors with their daily activities and is happy to support them to live meaningfully.

If you want to explore a switch to a fulfilling and purposeful career in the healthcare sector, do find out more from Workforce Singapore - WSG’s MyCareersFuture job portal, and various job fairs and recruitment platforms.

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
4 September 2020 at 11:25 ·

One of the changes that COVID-19 has brought about is the increase in online shopping and utilization of delivery services for food and groceries.

Did you know that since 2003, patients at our public healthcare institutions have been able to get their medication delivered right to their doorstep?

This service has since been enhanced, thanks to the partnership between our public hospitals and polyclinics, and the Agency for Logistics Procurement and Supply, which was set up by the Ministry of Health, Singapore.

With the ongoing COVID-19 situation, we have increased our delivery capacity tenfold – from 320 deliveries per day before the start of the pandemic to an average of 3,200 deliveries each day. In fact, over 400,000 medication deliveries were made from 1 February to 25 August 2020. This is something that we hope to encourage and continue for the long term.

Besides medicine delivery services, some polyclinics also provide the option for patients to collect their medicine at their convenience from Pilbox lockers, selected parcel deposit lockers or certain retail pharmacy outlets.

Find out more from the pharmacy staff at our public healthcare institutions if you would like to arrange for medication delivery or collection. Let’s get more convenience while keeping safe during this COVID pandemic!

Masagos Zulkifli
2 September 2020 at 11:08 ·

This month, the Silver Generation Office (SGO) is celebrating its 6 years of reaching out to seniors and linking them up with the help that they need. Set up in 2014, the SGO has played an active role in connecting our seniors to the ABCs: active ageing programmes, befrienders, and care and support programmes. To date, it has conducted more than 1 million engagements with seniors!

Powering SGO’s outreach are the 3,000-strong Silver Generation Ambassadors, who volunteer their time to check in on our seniors across Singapore and connect them to services and assistance to meet their needs. With the COVID-19 pandemic, SGO’s usual face-to-face engagements have been largely replaced by tele-engagements, with brief visits conducted only when a tele-engagement is not possible.

Mr Kong Seet Kiang is one of the many volunteers who make SGO’s extensive outreach possible. After retiring as a shopkeeper at a Chinese medicinal hall, he decided to volunteer as a Silver Generation Ambassador as he enjoys listening to seniors’ stories. These days, he checks in on the wellbeing of seniors in his area via tele-engagement. If seniors need help with basic needs such as buying groceries or medication, volunteers will step in to assist. He also refers seniors to SGO’s community partners so they can receive the support they need.

To our Silver Generation Ambassadors, thank you for your dedication and care in improving our seniors’ lives. Your spirit of volunteerism is inspiring.

If you would like to find out how to volunteer as a Silver Generation Ambassador, do approach the Silver Generation Office. Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore

MOH and SFA are investigating a recent uptrend in the number of Group B Streptococcus (GBS) cases.

In July 2020, MOH received reports of 50 GBS cases from public hospitals. This compares with an average of 25 GBS cases per month from January to June 2020. Further laboratory investigations showed that 18 of the cases reported in July were GBS Type III ST283. This compares with an average of 4 cases per month from April to June 2020.

As GBS infections have previously been associated with the consumption of raw freshwater fish, we advise members of the public who choose to consume ready-to-eat (RTE) raw fish to exercise caution. Raw food is likely to contain more bacteria compared to well-cooked food. Cooking raw food well is still the most effective way to kill bacteria. As a general precaution, vulnerable groups of people, especially young children, pregnant women, elderly persons, or people with chronic illness such as diabetes, may be more susceptible and should exercise caution by avoiding the consumption of raw food. Individuals can also reduce their risk of infection by:

• Thoroughly cooking food;
• Washing hands and kitchen utensils such as knives and cutting boards thoroughly before handling food; and
• Using separate sets of knives and cutting board for raw and cooked food.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/advisory-on-the-increase-in-the-number-of-invasive-group-b-streptococcus-cases

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce will expand the COVID-19 testing regime to identified community groups in the upcoming weeks. These tests will be offered to these groups to provide a better picture of population prevalence and facilitate the early containment of any cryptic cases in the community.

For a start, we have plans to provide testing on a one-time basis to community groups such as taxi and Private Hire Car (PHC) drivers, food delivery personnel, key vendors servicing foreign worker dormitories, as well as stallholders at hawker centres, markets and similar F&B establishments such as coffeeshops.

We strongly encourage individuals in the identified community groups to come forward and utilise the tests offered. The costs of the tests will be fully borne by the government.

The Taskforce also recommends that makeshift face coverings such as bandanas, scarves, and neck gaiters should not be used. As these makeshift coverings may not have a good fit around the person’s nose and mouth and are made from materials that are not specific for disease prevention, they may not perform as well as purpose-built masks.

Everyone has a role to play to ensure the safe resumption of social and economic activities. Together, we can continue in our fight against COVID-19 to protect ourselves, our loved ones and our community.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/expanded-covid-19-testing-to-specific-community-groups-and-updated-guidance-on-use-of-masks

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
29 August 2020 at 08:08 ·

In the last 24 years as a doctor, I’ve observed that it is often those who needed medical insurance who doesn’t have it. This is especially when the patients have disabilities that made it difficult for them to earn an income to support their medical needs. Hence, a national level insurance scheme that is affordable and takes care of those who are most vulnerable is crucial in an aging population where 1 in 2 persons will require long term care towards the final years of their life journey.

Yesterday, Ministry of Health, Singapore announced the launch of CareShield Life and MediSave Care on 1 October 2020.

CareShield Life is a national insurance scheme that will provide payouts for as long as one is severely disabled. These payouts increase every year until you start claiming, or until age 67 if you don’t claim. The younger generation of Singaporeans – those aged 30 to 40 this year - will be joining the scheme first. Those aged 30 and above with severe disability will also benefit from MediSave Care, where they will be able to draw on their and/or their spouse’s MediSave savings for their long-term care needs.

Eligible individuals can start applying for claims from 1 October 2020. Interested applicants should arrange for a disability assessment by a MOH-accredited severe disability assessor and submit the application to AIC.

The first group of Singaporeans joining CareShield Life can also look forward to getting their welcome package very soon! Comprising a welcome booklet and letter, you’ll receive it by 2 September 2020 or up to two months before your 30th birthday.

To learn more about CareShield Life and MediSave Care in the meantime, click on these links:
https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/launch-of-careshield-life-and-medisave-care-on-1-october-2020
https://www.aic.sg/CareShieldLife
https://www.aic.sg/MediSavecare

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Two years ago, we announced that a new, national long-term care insurance scheme was in the works to provide all Singaporeans with universal coverage for severe disability. We also shared our plans to extend the use of MediSave for long-term care needs. We are pleased to share that CareShield Life and MediSave Care will be launched on 1 October 2020. The first batch of policyholders will be Singapore Residents aged 30 to 40, who will be automatically enrolled this year.

With CareShield Life, Singaporeans will receive monthly cash payouts for life should they become severely disabled. We will keep CareShield Life premiums affordable, through means-tested subsidies for lower- to middle-income residents and additional premium support for Singaporeans who need further help.

We have appointed the CareShield Life Council to oversee the administration and ensure the sustainability of CareShield Life. The Council is made up of 14 members from a variety of fields and is chaired by Ms Jeanette Wong, a veteran in the banking sector and Board Member of UBS Group AG.

Through MediSave Care, Singaporeans will have another option to support their long-term care expenses. Those who are 30 and older and severely disabled can withdraw up to $200 in cash monthly from their own and/or their spouse’s MediSave.

Together, CareShield Life and MediSave Care will provide greater assurance and support to Singaporeans for their long-term care needs.

We will start mailing out welcome packages soon for the first group of Singaporeans joining CareShield Life and they will receive it by 2 September 2020 or up to two months before their 30th birthday. Do keep a look out for it!

For more information on the two schemes, click on these links:
https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/launch-of-careshield-life-and-medisave-care-on-1-october-2020

Masagos Zulkifli
26 August 2020 at 11:31 ·

In Ministry of Health, Singapore’s addendum to the President’s Address, we outlined our commitment to ensuring everyone can benefit from a healthy life well-lived.

Singapore’s population is ageing rapidly. By 2030, one in four Singaporeans will be aged 65 and above, compared to the current one in seven. Singaporeans’ life expectancy is also the highest in the world, at almost 85 years. That is why it is important that we empower our seniors to stay active and healthy, so that we delay the onset of frailty and keep seniors in good health for as long as possible. We also need to create opportunities for seniors to contribute to and stay connected with the community, so that they can enjoy their silver years purposefully.

The ongoing review of the Action Plan for Successful Ageing, a national blueprint that spans over 70 initiatives, seeks to help our seniors achieve this. Over the years, we have introduced various active ageing programmes, enhanced our aged care services, and expanded the reach of preventive health services to seniors in the community. We have also built up strong networks of care and support for seniors, connecting seniors to the help they need and strengthening support for family caregivers.

We will continue to build on the progress made in the coming years, and work with Singaporeans to create a caring and inclusive community that is conducive for our seniors to age actively and happily.

Longevity is an opportunity and blessing, so let’s work together to help our seniors stay healthy and happy!

(These photos were taken before the COVID-19 outbreak).

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the COVID-19 situation in the Republic of Korea. There have been reported clusters in gatherings at places of worship that have spread to workplaces. Authorities in the Republic of Korea have warned of a possible nationwide outbreak. Across the Republic of Korea, stricter social distancing measures have been imposed.

Given the resurgence in the number of cases in the Republic of Korea, we will adjust our border measures. Travellers entering Singapore from 29 August 2020, 0000 hours, who have recent travel history, including transit, to the Republic of Korea, within the last 14 days will be required to serve a 14 day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated SHN facilities instead of their own place of residence. They will also need to undergo a COVID-19 test before the end of their SHN, as is the current requirement.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updated-border-measures-for-travellers-from-the-republic-of-korea

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨 is with Min Sheng.
25 August 2020 at 10:59 ·

As Singapore’s population ages, we continue to grow our healthcare workforce to meet the current and anticipated rise in demand for healthcare services. Happy to share that we are inviting more individuals with a passion to care for patients to join the healthcare family. From now to the end of 2021, the healthcare sector will be offering up to a total of about 7,500 jobs, and about 1,600 traineeships, attachments and skills training opportunities.

There will be a range of vacancies available for both our fresh graduates and mid-career job seekers, including nurses, allied health professionals and support care roles. Managerial and executive roles are also available for those who may have relevant administrative experience or training outside the healthcare sector.

No worries if you do not have prior training in healthcare, as you can also tap on the traineeships, attachments and skills training opportunities, to acquire the relevant working experience and work-ready skills. Workforce Singapore - WSG and SkillsFuture SG are working with our healthcare and community care providers in the public and private sectors, as well as training institutions and the healthcare union, to offer these opportunities.

Job seekers will be able to access these opportunities through WSG’s MyCareersFuture job portal, and various job fairs and recruitment platforms. You can find out more at: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/7-500-job-vacancies-and-1-600-traineeship-attachment-and-skills-training-opportunities-available-in-the-healthcare-sector

Janil Puthucheary
22 August 2020 at 17:11 ·

Mental health and resilience are important - and more so in these difficult times.

The Community Mental Health Masterplan was launched in 2017 to increase outreach, develop early detection processes and provide care and support to those living with mental health conditions in the community. Close to 900 counsellors, psychiatrists, social workers or public officers have stepped forward to volunteer to man the the National CARE Hotline. The hotline has handled approximately 28,000 calls

Many social service agencies, including the Brahm Centre, have continued to provide their services and programmes.

I explained these points at the Singapore Mindfulness Conference 2020, organised by the Brahm Centre and many other partners today.

MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has reviewed our border measures to manage the risks of importation and onward local transmission from travellers.

We have monitored the situation and assessed that there are several countries/regions where the virus situation is well under control and the risk of importation is low, and will therefore update our border measures accordingly. From 1 September 2020, 0000 hrs:

- Travellers from Brunei Darussalam and New Zealand will be subject to a COVID-19 test upon arrival, in lieu of a Stay-Home Notice (SHN).

- We will also reduce the SHN duration from 14 days to 7 days for travellers from low risk countries/regions, and allow ravelers to serve the SHN at their place of residence. These low risk countries/regions are Australia (excluding Victoria State), Macao, Mainland China, Taiwan, Vietnam and Malaysia. The COVID-19 test will continue to be administered before the end of the 7-day SHN.

- All other incoming travelers will continue to serve their 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities and will be subject to a COVID-19 test before the end of the SHN.

We will also update the travel advisory to allow the following:

- General travel to Brunei Darussalam and New Zealand. Travellers to Brunei Darussalam and New Zealand are advised to check the entry requirements imposed by these countries, and take the necessary precautionary measures.

- Travel for studies for students pursuing academic qualifications overseas, and where distance-learning is not offered as an option by the education institution.

We will continue to monitor the global health situation closely and update our border measures in accordance with the public health risk assessment. Pls check the MOH website regularly for the latest updates.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-and-community-measures

20 August 2020 at 22:59 ·

As we learn to carry on and live with COVID-19 amidst a new normal, we must continue to stay vigilant and look out for the vulnerable among us, especially our seniors. Let’s support one another to care for our seniors’ wellbeing. Check in frequently on the seniors in your life – be it your family and loved ones, or your neighbours. Take some time out and check how they are doing, or connect them to help where needed.

Sometimes all it takes is a simple phone or video call, and a warm voice saying “hello, how is your day?” or “have you eaten?”, to spark off a meaningful connection.

Our colleagues at the Health Promotion Board, Singapore have come up with these simple conversation starters to brighten up our seniors’ day. Try them out and let’s help one another to #StayWellToStayStrong

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
20 August 2020 at 02:07 ·

[New Job Opportunities]

A few days ago I shared about how our SIA aircrew helped as Care Ambassadors in our hospitals during this period when the aviation sector is impacted by COVID-19. Some have asked me how they can switch over from other industry sectors to seek permanent employment in healthcare.

The Professional Conversion Programmes for Enrolled Nurses or Registered Nurses help mid-career Professionals, Managers, Executives and Technicians (PMETs) in acquiring relevant training to be Enrolled or Registered Nurses. Funding is provided by Workforce Singapore - WSG, Ministry of Health, Singapore and a co-sponsoring organisation for successful candidates to undergo either a 2-year NITEC in Nursing at ITE, or a 2-year Diploma in Nursing (Accelerated) at Nanyang Polytechnic or an accelerated 2-year Bachelor of Science (Nursing) at NUS. The various healthcare Professional Conversion Programmes offer a training pathway for those seeking a second career in healthcare and have helped to supplement the growth of our local healthcare workforce.

Ms Goh Ling Ling, 40, is a Staff Nurse at St Luke's Hospital - Singapore. But she hasn’t always been a nurse – she used to work in quality assurance and quality control before she took the leap to nursing. 10 years ago, a friend showed her an advertisement for a Diploma in Nursing Programme under the Professional Conversion Programme. Ling Ling had always aspired to care for the less fortunate and sick, especially after personally experiencing the care of nurses following a motorcycle accident. In her words, “The desire to help others who are suffering from illness and those who are experiencing caregiver stress affirmed my decision to switch careers.”

Today, besides general nursing care, Ling Ling also works as a dementia care nurse to help to manage patients’ behavioural and psychological symptoms. Knowing that she has made a difference in the lives of her patients and their family members gives her much happiness. If you feel inspired by Ling Ling’s story to join the nursing profession, click on these links to find out more:

https://conversion.mycareersfuture.sg/Portal/ProgramDetails.aspx?ProgID=P00000178
https://conversion.mycareersfuture.sg/Portal/ProgramDetails.aspx?ProgID=P00000188
https://conversion.mycareersfuture.sg/Portal/ProgramDetails.aspx?ProgID=P00000189

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
18 August 2020 at 08:05 ·

These last few months, the COVID-19 pandemic has grounded planes, but some 500 Singapore Airlines cabin crew have been hard at work as Care Ambassadors at our hospitals. They have been supporting nurses in administrative and non-clinical aspects of patient care. With the positive feedback and the COVID-19 situation lasting longer than expected, we are extending the initiative for a year, and opening up another 1,000 opportunities to cabin crew.

The Care Ambassadors have been adjusting well to their new roles. Ms Melannie Wong, an SIA Chief Stewardess who is now a Care Ambassador at Khoo Teck Puat Hospital, said she is glad to have made a difference and finds the experience rewarding. Another Care Ambassador, Mr Kenneth Tan, who is now deployed at Ren Ci Hospital, is motivated by his desire to give back to society. He treats his patients the same way he treats his passengers – “with an attention to detail, a warm human touch, and sincere service from the heart”.

Kudos to our Care Ambassadors who have been bringing their warmth and graciousness to patients, and lending a much needed helping hand to healthcare workers!

Gan Kim Yong is with Chua Chu Kang and 7 others.
10 August 2020 at 01:23 ·

I was at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases this morning for the Anthem Moment. The choice of the location is particularly meaningful for us as it is a recognition of the role the healthcare family plays, especially in our fight against COVID-19, not just in NCID, but all over Singapore and in all healthcare institutions.

Over these past months, our healthcare workers have persevered in playing their part to be at the frontline of Singapore’s fight against COVID-19. I want to thank each and every one of them for their dedication, courage and resilience.

I am confident the COVID-19 virus will not break our Singapore spirit. Let's renew our pledge to stay resolute and press on together to build a brighter future for Singapore. Just as we have triumphed over past adversities, we will similarly emerge stronger from this crisis – because we are Singapore, and we are Singaporeans.

Happy National Day! 🇸🇬🇸🇬

Koh Poh Koon - 许宝琨
9 August 2020 at 19:44 ·

Today I want to celebrate not just Singapore’s 55th birthday, but also the tenacious efforts of our healthcare workers in the COVID-19 fight. Thank you for keeping us safe! It is one of the toughest battles our nation has faced – with no vaccine yet, we have to continue to be vigilant. The battle ahead is long, but I know that the resilience of our nation and our sense of unity will see us through the challenges that may come, and we will emerge from this stronger, together.

To my fellow healthcare workers: you are the backbone of this fight. We will continue to count on you, from testing and detecting the virus, to healing patients and saving lives. It makes me proud to have shared the National Anthem Moment at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases today. Stay strong – we are in in this together! 🇸🇬

#TogetherStrongerSG
#OurHeartforSG

The Anthem Moment at Tan Tock Seng Hospital and the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID), one of eight locations chosen to host the event this year.

Joined my colleagues from the Healthcare family this morning. Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, our healthcare workers have had to adapt to the situation to fight COVID-19. I’m thankful for their personal sacrifices in the pursuit of saving lives and taking care of our patients.

We can play our part to fight COVID19 alongside our healthcare workers by staying socially responsible.

Wishing all Singaporeans a Happy National Day. #MajulahSingapura!

As of 6 August 2020, 12pm, we have preliminarily confirmed an additional 301 cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore, the vast majority of whom are Work Permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories. Based on our investigations so far, there are 4 cases in the community, of whom 3 are Singaporeans/ Permanent Residents and 1 is a Work Pass holder.

In addition, there are 4 imported cases, who had all been placed on Stay-Home Notice upon arrival in Singapore.

We continue to aggressively test the final batch of dormitory residents, and remain on track to clear all the dormitories by 7 August, except for a few standalone blocks in the dormitories that serve as quarantine facilities. Depending on the prevalence of COVID-19 at the remaining dormitories whose residents are being tested, the daily case counts may vary. We expect the number to remain volatile in the coming days, before tapering down thereafter as the Inter-agency Taskforce completes the dormitory clearance.

We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.

https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/301-new-cases-of-covid-19-infection

As of 5 August 2020, 12pm, we have preliminarily confirmed an additional 908 cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore, the vast majority of whom are Work Permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories. Of these, the vast majority are dormitory residents who were tested during their isolation/quarantine period, even though they are asymptomatic. They are amongst the final batch of workers being cleared and they come from dormitories with a relatively high prevalence of COVID-19. Hence we expect the daily case counts to be high for the coming days, before tapering down thereafter as the Inter-agency Taskforce completes the dormitory clearance.

Based on our investigations so far, there are 4 cases in the community, of whom 3 are Singaporeans/ Permanent Residents and 1 is a Work Pass holder.

Wishing all of our nurses a Happy Nurses’ Day!

The World Health Organization has designated 2020 the Year of the Nurse and Midwife. 2020 is also the 135th anniversary of nursing in Singapore. What will also define 2020 for many of our nurses, is the COVID-19 pandemic, as they fight at the frontline of the battle.

In appreciation of our angels in white, Minister for Health, Mr Gan Kim Yong has recorded a special video message for them.

To all of our nurses, thank you for your dedication to your patients, and your resilience and perseverance.

Stay safe, and stay well. Happy Nurses’ Day!

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

As of 25 July 2020, 12pm, we have preliminarily confirmed an additional 513 cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore, the vast majority of whom are Work Permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories. Based on our investigations so far, there are 2 cases in the community, both of whom are Work Pass holders. In addition, there are 6 imported cases who had been placed on Stay-Home Notice upon arrival in Singapore.

The Inter-agency Taskforce is on track to clear all the dormitories by the beginning of August 2020, with the exception of 17 standalone blocks in 8 Purpose Built Dormitories, which serve as quarantine facilities for 28,000 workers still serving out their isolation period. This last batch of workers come from dormitories with a relatively high prevalence of COVID-19, and will be subject to a final test before they complete their isolation periods. We therefore expect the daily case counts to be high for the coming two weeks, before tapering down thereafter.

We are still working through the details of the cases today, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.

Amy Khor
22 July 2020 at 02:43 ·

Always at the forefront of care delivery, our nurses form the backbone of our healthcare system and are a critical part of a patient’s care journey. During this COVID-19 pandemic, our nurses have also stepped up to answer their call of duty, working tirelessly with other healthcare professionals to keep our loved ones and Singapore safe.

Today, we celebrate 5 nurses who are the winners of the President’s Award for Nurses 2020, the nation’s highest honour for nurses. To Ms Chin Soh Mun, Dr Alice Chua, Ms Kala D/O Narayanasamy, Ms Tay Yee Kian and Ms Patricia Yong, congratulations on winning the President’s Award for Nurses 2020 and thank you for your immense contribution to the noble profession.

These nurses’ exemplary leadership and selfless service to the community illustrate the essential role of nurses in our healthcare system. They show us the deep skills and professionalism required of nurses, and the passion, resilience and strength that drive many more like them to help patients towards recovery and better health.

The year 2020 also marks the 135th year of nursing in Singapore. This is a timely occasion for us to look back on the achievements of the nursing community and to show our gratitude for their contribution. I hope you will join me in thanking our nurses for their dedication to our patients and for their service to generations of Singaporeans.

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Five nurses have been honoured with the President’s Award for Nurses this year, the highest accolade in Singapore’s nursing profession.

Our heartiest congratulations to Ms Chin Soh Mun (Dover Park Hospice ), Dr Alice Chua (National Cancer Centre Singapore), Ms Kala d/o Narayanasamy (Woodlands Health Campus), Ms Tay Yee Kian (National University Health System - NUHS) and Ms Patricia Yong (Singapore General Hospital)! Thank you for your dedication and professionalism.

These nurses have shown sustained outstanding performance and contributions to patient care delivery, education, research and administration in their respective nursing fields over the years. They have also shown us the multi-faceted roles our nurses play today – from caregiver to educator, and even friend.

We hope their stories of service and leadership will inspire fellow and future nurses alike. Read more on the 5 award winners in our press release https://bit.ly/2ZM6j05.

As of 14 July 2020, 12pm, we have preliminarily confirmed an additional 347 cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore, the vast majority of whom are Work Permit holders residing in foreign worker dormitories. Based on our investigations so far, there are 7 cases in the community, of whom 1 is a Singaporean and 6 are Work Pass holders. In addition, there are 2 imported cases who had been placed on Stay-Home Notice upon arrival in Singapore.

We have to date tested and cleared more than 215,000 workers (or two-thirds of those living in dormitories). Work is ongoing to prepare these dormitories to be declared cleared, and for workers to resume work. We are on track to clear about 80% of workers staying in the dormitories by end-July, and to complete the testing of dormitory residents around mid-August.

In the next few days, we have a larger population of migrant workers in various purpose-built dormitories completing their isolation period and being tested for COVID-19. As some of them came from dormitories with higher prevalence of COVID-19 infection, we can expect a higher number of confirmed cases in the next few days from this group of migrant workers.

We are still working through the details of the cases today, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the COVID-19 situation.

- The total daily new cases has been on the decline since the Circuit Breaker, and efforts to clear migrant worker dormitories are continuing.
- While there has been some imported cases, our border controls remain tight. Travellers are isolated under Stay-Home Notices on arrival, and this prevents community transmission.
- While there has been an uptick in community cases, the majority are linked cases detected early by aggressive ring-fencing.
- Close to half of unlinked cases in the community are past infections, and many are in construction or construction-related occupations.

Proactive measures are in place to uncover and contain cases early. Linked cases are detected and isolated quickly through aggressive ring-fencing. Unlinked cases are picked up early from active surveillance and routine testing of targeted groups, and expanded testing for those diagnosed with acute respiratory infection.

As we resume more activities under Phase Two, we must be prepared for the number of cases to increase. Apart from the early detection and isolation measures in place, continued vigilance and adherence to safe management measures on everyone’s part are important to reduce the spread of infection and protect our loved ones. Through everyone’s collective efforts, we can keep COVID-19 under control while we progressively resume activities safely.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/controlling-the-infection-in-phase-two-of-re-opening

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

On Monday, Co-Chairs of the Multi-Ministry Taskforce, Mr Gan Kim Yong, Minister for Health, and Mr Lawrence Wong, Minister for National Development, met with the medical teams deployed at the Community Care Facility (CCF) at Singapore EXPO & MAX Atria to thank them for their hard work in the ongoing battle against COVID-19.

Since the CCF at Expo was first set up in early April, the medical teams – from SingHealth, Woodlands Health Campus and the SAF – have been tirelessly caring for the residents as they recover from COVID-19, many of whom have mild symptoms. The teams’ work at the Expo CCF is also enabled by the use of technology as a force multiplier to deliver the same or enhanced outcomes with less time and resources. This includes a system developed by IHiS for residents to input their own vital signs to help the medical teams monitor residents’ condition and the use of robots to allow doctors and nurses to communicate with residents.

As more COVID-19 patients recover and are discharged from our community facilities, we will progressively put into reserve some of the CCFs as part of broader efforts to optimise resources. These CCFs will continue to stand ready to be re-activated should there be a need for them, and we can also swiftly deploy the necessary medical, service and ancillary manpower needed to support the operations.

Running a CCF involves complex and extensive operations to make sure every resident is taken care of. It would not be possible without the close collaboration between the public and private sectors, with each party bringing their expertise to the project. The various CCFs we have set up over the past months exemplify the whole of society effort required in tackling the COVID-19 outbreak and we are grateful for the teamwork displayed. #SGUnited

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Tobacco use is the second-highest contributor to ill health and premature death in Singapore. As part of our continued efforts to discourage non-smokers from picking up smoking, encourage smokers to quit and to encourage Singaporeans to adopt a tobacco-free lifestyle, from 1 July 2020, all tobacco products sold in Singapore will be subject to standardised packaging and enlarged graphic health warnings.

Tobacco products can no longer have logos, colours, images and promotional information on their packaging (other than brand names and variant names displayed in a standard colour and font style); and the minimum size of the mandatory graphic health warnings of all specified tobacco product packaging surfaces must increase from the existing 50% to 75%.

This complements a range of other measures including public education, taxation, smoking cessation programmes, bans on tobacco advertising, the point-of-sale display ban and the institution of a minimum legal age for tobacco.

We can all take charge of our health and the health of our loved ones, with a tobacco-free lifestyle. Stay smoke-free, quit smoking and support your loved ones who are on their quit journey.

For more information, please visit https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/standardised-packaging-enlarged-graphic-health-warnings-mandatory-for-all-tobacco-products-in-singapore-from-1-july-2020

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
25 June 2020 at 13:32 ·

In the last 4 months, our Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs) have been at the frontline detecting and managing COVID-19 infections in the community, playing a crucial role in Singapore’s efforts to contain the outbreak.

Happy to share that the Ministry of Health, Singapore will provide a one-off COVID-19 Business Grant, totalling $10,000 each, in recognition of the role that PHPCs play in supporting our efforts in combating the COVID-19 pandemic. The grant will be disbursed in December 2020 to all eligible PHPCs.

To date, more than 900 PHPCs have provided subsidised consultation and treatment for Singaporeans, Permanent Residents and eligible Work Permit holders diagnosed with acute respiratory infections. This grant is to support PHPCs in their active role in caring for patients with respiratory symptoms, and defray additional costs that they may have incurred in doing so.

About 400 PHPCs have also come onboard the Swab and Send Home Programme (SASH) to provide COVID-19 testing services to eligible individuals, playing an important role in testing and diagnosing COVID-19 cases in the community. MOH will provide a one-time start-up grant of $1,200 to all PHPCs on SASH, in recognition of the costs and effort incurred in stepping up to support our national COVID-19 testing effort.

We are grateful for the commitment that our PHPC partners have displayed in responding to the evolving situation, as well as the hard work that all our healthcare workers have put in. We would like to thank all of them for their continued support and effort as we work together to keep Singapore safe from COVID-19.

#SGUnited #SGTogether
#TogetherWeCan #FightAgainstCoVid19!

Amy Khor
20 June 2020 at 06:36 ·

The SG Healthcare Corps supports our healthcare workforce in the fight against COVID-19. I met many of the volunteers who were receiving training in wearing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and masks properly, and how to perform nasopharyngeal swabs. This training is essential to equip our volunteers with the knowledge of proper infection control, before deploying them to support healthcare operations or roles in community care.

I had a short dialogue session with the trainers, who were volunteers themselves. Many of them were experienced ICU-trained nurses who have retired or are no longer in active practice. Some of them had worked as nurses in wards during the time of SARS, and are back to volunteer as trainers this time. Others are dentists from the CGDP College of General Dental Practitioners Singapore
and Singapore Dental Association who had stepped forward to contribute their expertise in performing nasopharyngeal swabs. What encouraged me was their enthusiasm and passion to impart knowledge and empower other volunteers.

To all the volunteers, thank you for your dedication and for stepping forward to support and augment our healthcare workforce, in the spirit of #SGUnited and #SGTogether. For those of you who would like to play a part in caring for our community during this time, visit the SG Healthcare Corps website (www.healthcarecorps.gov.sg) to sign up!

Heng Swee Keat
17 June 2020 at 03:10 ·

Next month, Pioneer and Merdeka Generation seniors will be receiving their MediSave top-ups. PG seniors will get between $200 to $800, while MG seniors will get $200. Eligible seniors will get their notification letters by the end of June. Seniors can use the MediSave top-ups to pay for their MediShield Life premiums and other applicable medical expenses.

The $255 million MediSave top-ups are part of the benefits under the Pioneer and Merdeka Generation Packages — to thank our Pioneer and Merdeka Generation seniors for their contributions to Singapore. Altogether, we had set aside more than $14 billion for these packages, to cover about one million seniors for life.

Our Pioneer and Merdeka Generations weathered difficult storms in the early years of Singapore, and contributed to Singapore’s growth. We owe them a debt of gratitude for their hard work and dedication. Let us continue to support them to stay active and healthy.

You can refer to the Ministry of Finance (Singapore) and Ministry of Health, Singapore press release for more details: go.gov.sg/mofpgmgpayout.

#SGUnited

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce will be implementing progressive changes to border measures as we re-open to international travel.

Since 21 March 2020, all incoming travellers, including Singapore Citizens, Permanent Residents and Long Term Pass holders, have been required to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN). Besides the SHN, we will now put in place a testing regime for all incoming travellers before the end of their SHN. The testing regime will apply to all travellers entering Singapore from 17 June 2020, 2359 hours.

From 17 June 2020, 2359 hours, all travellers entering Singapore, and who had remained in Australia, Brunei Darussalam, Hong Kong, Japan, Macao, Mainland China, New Zealand, Republic of Korea, Taiwan and Vietnam in the last consecutive 14 days prior to their entry, will no longer have to serve their SHN at dedicated SHN facilities:
a. Singapore Citizens and PRs may serve their 14-day SHN at their place of residence.
b. Long Term Pass holders may serve their 14-day SHN at a place of residence that they or their family members own or are sole tenants of; or in suitable accommodation such as a hotel, at their own cost.

All other travelers entering Singapore will continue to serve their 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities, for now.

All Singaporeans and residents of Singapore are still advised to defer all travel abroad. However, essential business and official travel will be permitted under Green/ Fast Lane arrangements.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/gradual-re-opening-of-travel-and-changes-to-border-measures

Amy Khor
14 June 2020 at 00:21 ·

Today is World Blood Donor Day, when we commemorate the generous and crucial contributions of blood donors. Last year, I had the chance to meet many of you at the World Blood Donor Day 2019 ceremony, and listen to the stories and motivations behind your commitment and contributions.

On behalf of the more than 30,000 patients who receive life-saving blood transfusions each year, I would like to say, a Happy world Blood Donor Day, and a big thank you for your generosity and steadfast dedication to blood donation!

Sustaining the nation’s blood supply is important to save lives in times of emergencies. I am heartened to see that your commitment to the national blood programme remains unchanged – especially and even throughout this COVID-19 period. Many of you have continued to rally loved ones, colleagues, neighbours and the wider community to respond quickly to the news that blood stocks were at critical levels in February this year, and again when blood donations dropped in April. This sense of perseverance, togetherness and selflessness is what defines the blood donor community – truly exemplary of our #SGUnited spirit!

To ensure that our blood supply remains sustainable, we need more to come forward and donate blood, so that blood will always be available to all patients who need it, when they need it – whether in peacetime or in times of crisis. I want to encourage everyone to take that step forward, donate blood, and save lives.

Visit www.giveblood.sg to find out more about blood donation. Information on upcoming community drives can also be found at https://redcross.sg/give-blood/covid-19-updates.html.

#WBDD2020 #sgwbdd2020
Singapore Red Cross

(Photos taken with blood donors, blood donation recipients and their families at the World Blood Donor Day 2019 ceremony in June 2019.)

Lawrence Wong
9 June 2020 at 10:17 ·

<Regional Screening Centres>

As part of our scaled-up testing regime, the Health Promotion Board will be setting up Regional Screening Centres across the island. We now have five Centres at the Old Police Academy, The Float@Marina Bay, Bishan sport hall, Bukit Gombak sport hall and the former Sepak Takraw sport hall in Bedok, and we will set up more venues over time to support the testing needs in the community.

For now, the Centres will not take in walk-in requests for testing. Instead all workers with higher risk of exposure (eg those working in construction, marine and process industries, as well as those in our frontline Covid-19 operations) will be identified, and will go to the Centres for periodic testing. Doctors will also provide referral letters to their patients with acute respiratory infections, and they can go to these centres for testing. Over time as our testing capacity expands, we will include more groups to be tested.

Testing is a critical part of our strategy to control the infection, and the Regional Screening Centres will play a critical role in the implementation of our national testing strategy

Edwin Tong
6 June 2020 at 02:39 ·

[Launch of CareShield Life and MediSave Care]

We explained in Parliament yesterday that the launch of CareShield Life for Singaporeans born in 1980 or later, and MediSave Care, which provides cash withdrawals for long-term care needs, will be deferred slightly till end 2020. Both schemes were originally planned for launch in mid-2020. The launch of CareShield Life for Singaporeans born in 1979 or earlier will also minimally be deferred till end 2021, instead of the earlier plans for launch in mid-2021. The Ministry of Health, Singapore will review the ongoing situation and announce more details when ready.

The resources taken up to tackle the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact has meant a reduced pace of development and testing work being undertaken by our implementing agencies and vendors. This has caused a delay in the completion of IT systems needed to implement both CareShield Life and MediSave Care.

We would like to assure disabled Singaporeans and their caregivers who require assistance that they can continue to receive help from existing disability assistance schemes via the Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore. If they require additional support for living costs, they can also tap on other schemes such as ComCare, the Temporary Relief Fund and the COVID-19 Support Grant.
