At the invitation of WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong attended the weekly WHO briefing session for Member States on 27 March. Mr Gan shared Singapore’s experience in managing the COVID-19 pandemic. The session also included sharing by the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea.

Mr Gan said that Singapore’s strategy is to slow down the infection rate and to keep it as low as possible. Case detection and contact tracing remain important for us to ring-fence the spread and to preserve our healthcare capacity to cope with the outbreak in the long term. He emphasised the need for trust and open communication between people and the governments. Mr Gan expressed deep appreciation for healthcare workers around the world, who have been tirelessly working around the clock to protect the health of our people.

As we continue to fight this battle, Mr Gan urged global citizens to stay calm and stand united with their governments and with the rest of the world. Only together, can we overcome COVID-19.

#SGUnited #WorldUnited #TogetherWeCan #FightAgainst CoVid19!

Enterprise Singapore
27 March 2020 at 23:34 ·

[Rumour of Safe Distancing Ambassadors imposing fine]

There is a rumour circulating on social media and via text messaging platforms claiming that an Enterprise Singapore safe distancing ambassador had imposed a fine on an individual, for sitting on a seat that was marked out as not to be occupied.

This is FALSE.

Safe distancing ambassadors are deployed by various government agencies to guide and ensure that businesses implement and comply with the safe distancing measures. They do not impose fines.

Businesses that are found to have violated the Infectious Diseases Act and regulations promulgated thereunder may be liable for an offence and charged.

We advise members of the public to avoid spreading unverified information.

Heng Swee Keat
26 March 2020 at 07:54 ·

[ IMPACT OF COVID-19 ]

DPM Heng: The COVID-19 outbreak is a battle on many fronts — medical, economic, and social. On the medical front, we are doing everything we can to keep you and your families safe. Yet measures on the medical front to contain the pandemic, both in Singapore and around the world, have made the second front of the battle — the economic front, even more difficult. Our latest GDP growth is forecasted to be between -4.0% and -1.0%. On the social front, we need Singaporeans to be strong, and ride through these challenges together.

Last month, I committed $6.4 billion in the Unity Budget towards the Stabilisation and Support Package, the Care and Support Package, and to support our frontline Agencies. Today, I am introducing measures worth over $48 billion in this Resilience Budget, to deal decisively with the COVID-19 situation.

Altogether, we are putting $55 billion to support our people, amounting to 11% of our GDP. This is a landmark package, and a necessary response to a unique situation.

The Resilience Budget will focus on three key areas:

1. Save jobs, support workers, and protect livelihoods

2. Help enterprises overcome immediate challenges

3. Strengthen economic and social resilience so that we can emerge intact and stronger

#SGBudget2020
#SGUnited

Heng Swee Keat
26 March 2020 at 01:19 ·

Five weeks ago, we had the Unity Budget. I had called for all Singaporeans to remain united, and to each play our part in overcoming COVID-19 together.

COVID-19 has since turned into a global pandemic, one that will be with us for many months to come. We must remain resilient as we brave the difficult times to come. This is why I have named the supplementary budget the Resilience Budget.

Our resilience as a country, as a society, is being put to the test as we face our biggest challenge in more than a decade. I still remember vividly the Global Financial Crisis in 2008, when I was heading up the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Those were dark days, but we bounced back. This time around, we face not just an economic crisis, but also a global pandemic.

The road ahead will not be easy, but with the Resilience Budget — we will help save jobs and support companies, with more for those who have been hardest hit. Households will also receive additional help to tide through this difficult period.

Various analysts and business leaders have been guessing about the size of the Budget, and its reach. It is important not to have excessive expectations or merely focus on the headline numbers. What is more important is that all of us do our part and make the best use of whatever we have.

Together, we can weather the storm and emerge stronger as one Singapore.

You can catch the ‘live’ broadcast of the Ministerial Statement on CNA, on CNA938, on the CNA website and on Mediacorp’s MeWatch interactive service.

We announced several measures, including:

Heng Swee Keat
25 March 2020 at 13:25 ·

Today in Parliament, we put in place stricter safe distancing guidelines. We are organised into two teams — Red and Blue. Our seats in the Chamber were also spaced out — a first in Parliament’s history.

I hope people understand that we must all do our part. As Gan Kim Yong and Lawrence Wong pointed out in their Ministerial Statements today, all the measures we have in place will only be effective if we all do our part and are socially responsible. Our frontline healthcare workers, together with our public officers, are giving their all, working around the clock looking after patients, protecting Singapore and our people.

38,000 people are now serving their Stay Home Notices (SHN). Many of them have returned from countries that are hard hit by COVID-19. More will return in the coming days. We expect the number of new cases to go up.

K Shanmugam Sc told the House of several cases of irresponsible behaviour — a few individuals who were on SHN were unwell, but still went to work and even participated in social gatherings. The police will be investigating these cases and those caught flouting their SHN will be charged in court.

Do your part — practise safe distancing, seek medical attention promptly if you do not feel well, stay at home if you are supposed to. Only when each of us does our part, can we protect our loved ones and the people around us.

Lee Hsien Loong
25 March 2020 at 12:56 ·

Gan Kim Yong updated Parliament today on the COVID-19 situation and what lies ahead. The strict measures we have taken — border controls, restricting travel, safe distancing, suspending religious services, and closing of entertainment outlets and tuition centres — are meant to curb the spread of the disease, to flatten the curve, and slow down the infection rate.

Around the world, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to worsen. We too expect to see more cases, as more overseas Singaporeans return home. It is crucial for these returnees to comply strictly with their Stay Home Notices. You must protect your families and everyone else, in case you turn out to be infected, which unfortunately some returnees will be. Glad that many are behaving responsibly by staying home, but some are not. Please comply — it is irresponsible to gallivant off to eat local food you miss, or to go partying with friends, when you are supposed to stay at home and isolate yourself. You will also be breaking the law.

Lawrence Wong spoke for us all when he gave heartfelt thanks to our healthcare workers, public officers, volunteers, and many unsung heroes who are fighting hard against COVID-19. Everyone has a part to play — be socially responsible, keep a safe distance apart from others, maintain high levels of hygiene, and heed the government advisories. It is a sombre time, but if we work together as one people, we will overcome this challenge, as our pioneers have done before.

Singapore Tourism Board
25 March 2020 at 05:02 ·

[Joint statement by the Singapore Tourism Board, Enterprise Singapore and Singapore Police Force]

Following yesterday’s announcement that all entertainment venues will be closed from 26 March, 2359 hours till 30 April, we are aware a number of nightlife operators intend to host “farewell” events tonight that could result in large numbers of people congregating. These events undermine the fight against COVID-19 and increases risk to public health. If you are planning to attend, we urge you to seriously reconsider, if not for your own health, then for the health of those around you.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce’s decision to enforce stricter safe distancing measures aims to significantly reduce the risks of seeding new local COVID-19 clusters, which could strain our healthcare system further.

From now until the stricter measures kick in on 26 March 2020, 2359 hours, nightlife operators must continue to strictly implement safe distancing measures announced by the Ministry of Health on 20 March 2020. Events with 250 or more participants must be suspended, while operators of events with fewer than 250 participants must implement all necessary precautionary measures, including ensuring a distance of at least a metre between all participants and reduce mingling amongst participants.

These safe distancing measures are enforceable. Officers from government agencies including the Singapore Police Force will be on the ground to monitor the situation and carry out enforcement action over the next two days. The Traffic Police will also be conducting island-wide enforcement operations against drink-driving during this period. We will not hesitate to take action against anyone who fails to comply.

During this time, we appeal to Singaporeans to exercise good judgement and social responsibility. This will play an important part in keeping fellow Singaporeans and our loved ones safe in the midst of this global pandemic.

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
25 March 2020 at 05:08 ·

Yesterday, I co-chaired the second Singapore-Malaysia Joint Working Group (JWG) for COVID-19 with Malaysia Deputy Health Minister YB Dato Dr. Haji Noor Azmi Ghazali.

We updated each other on the current COVID-19 situations and had discussions on “how to flatten the epidemic curve”. In Singapore, we adopt a whole-of-government and whole-of-society approach towards managing COVID-19. A coordinated national response with community support is crucial for us to respond effectively against the outbreak. Our enhanced surveillance efforts have helped us in our overall containment efforts by “leaving no stones unturned” in detecting cases.

The JWG also discussed on joint border measures and agreed to continue entry screenings by both countries, align screening protocols by applying the same temperature cut-off (>37.5 degree Celsius) for febrile travellers, and implement reciprocal arrangements for the transfer of symptomatic travellers detected at entry screening back across both the land and sea checkpoints.

Singapore and Malaysia are working closely together during this pandemic to ensure the health protection of our people crossing the land and sea border.

#JWGforCOVID19 #TogetherWeCan #FightAgainstCoVid19

Further Measures to Help Companies Cope with COVID-19 Situation

Josephine Teo is in Singapore.
24 March 2020 at 13:28 · Singapore ·

MORE HELP FOR OUR COMPANIES AND WORKERS

Many businesses have been impacted by the evolving #COVID19 situation. Through our conversations with business leaders and the trade chambers and associations, we recognise that companies, in particular the small and medium enterprises (SMEs) as well as certain sectors, may need further support.

Singapore Ministry of Manpower will thus introduce further measures to help companies tide over this period. In helping the companies, we are in fact helping Singaporean workers to keep their jobs too.

With immediate effect, MOM will provide a three-month extension of levy payment timeline for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). This applies to levies incurred in 2020 and will benefit around 60,000 companies.

Additionally, in view of the widespread travel restrictions and difficulties workers may face in returning to Singapore, MOM will extend the levy waiver period to up to 90 days with immediate effect for foreign workers who are currently on overseas home leave. Employers may also consider sending their foreign work pass holders back home to wait out the situation.

The construction sector in particular has been hard hit by work disruptions due to delays in overseas supplies and entry of foreign construction workers. As a result, construction firms are unable to fully utilise the Man-year Entitlements (MYE) allocated for their projects. Together with The Singapore Contractors Association Ltd and Building and Construction Authority (Singapore), we have worked on a temporary scheme to refund unutilised MYE due to work disruptions from COVID-19. For six months starting from 1 April 2020, firms will have the flexibility to use the refunded MYE within one year to hire new workers or renew existing ones.

We will continue to support our businesses and workers during this difficult time. – Jo Teo

Ong Ye Kung
22 March 2020 at 14:01 ·

I realised that my last post cannot be shared properly because of a link. I have removed the link and reposted. Wasted 900 shares but more important to get the message out. Learn something everyday.
==========================================================

School is re-opening tomorrow.

I have received many emails and messages from parents. Some asked why not extend the March holidays, especially given the rising numbers of imported cases and impending border closures. Others, including several students, urged MOE to keep schools open as they would like to go to school.

I have personally replied to many parents and students. Actually, part of the reason for the tougher border measures is to ensure we keep Singapore as safe as possible, so that daily activities, like going to work, eating out and attending school, can go on.

But let me lay out MOE’s thinking on why school will open tomorrow, but with more precautionary measures. There are three key considerations.

First, science. With the virus being around for several months now, there is a body of scientific evidence showing that COVID-19 does not affect the young very much as compared to adults. Parents will be familiar with this concept, as this is the case for other diseases such as chicken pox.

Neither is there evidence to show that the young are vectors or spreaders of the virus. The reverse appears to be the case, where the young get infected by adults at home. This is the advice of Prof Dale Fisher, Group Director of Medicine at NUHS and Chair of the WHO Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network.

Indeed, for the small handful of our students (including those from Institutes of Higher Learning) who were infected, every single one caught it outside of their schools.

In this context, it may not be a bad idea for our children to spend the bulk of their day in school, where lessons and activities are arranged such that they mingle only with their classmates, who are less susceptible to the virus than adults. They will be quite a resilient group. If we close schools, many will not stay home, but may run around in the community and mingle with a lot more people, exposing themselves to more risk.

In that sense, schools remain safe places for children, especially as they seem to be more resilient against the virus.

Second, disruption. Closure of schools will disrupt many lives, especially parents who are both working, with no domestic help, and have limited childcare options. We are particularly concerned about parents who are healthcare workers and providers of essential services.

Keeping our healthcare system strong is paramount in the fight against COVID-19. Our frontline warriors will be much more assured if their children are in school, meaningfully engaged, in a safe and healthy environment.

Third, precautions. Notwithstanding that the young are more resilient to COVID-19, there is no place for complacency. We have consulted our healthcare experts and put in place many significant additional precautionary measures to safeguard the entire system, to maintain the calm situation we enjoyed before the March holidays.

We have implemented a Leave of Absence/Stay Home Notice policy, with the result that come Monday, every student, teacher, staff, canteen stall operator in school would not have gone overseas since the start of the March school holidays. As a further precaution, there will be 100% checks on their travel history at the gates.

Also, students will only spend their time with two groups - their class and their CCA. All other activities that involve mingling have been suspended. With CCA suspended for two weeks, their only social group is their class.

Another significant precaution is that every morning, every student who is not feeling well, be it with a cough or sore throat, and not just fever, will have to be in an isolation room or sent home.

In class, students will sit apart, just like during exams. Teachers and students will continue to upkeep the highest standards of hygiene. There is constant supervision (for the younger students) and reminders for all students to wash their hands properly and regularly, and avoid touching their faces.

Implemented together, these measures will serve as a robust layer of system defence, complementing the natural defence children may already have, to enable school to continue.

21 March 2020 at 05:42 ·

Despite our best efforts, we have two deaths from COVID-19. My deepest condolences to their families.

My deepest appreciation too to all our healthcare workers who had worked so hard looking after them and who must be deeply affected by the loss.

They must not be disheartened as they have done their best and because of that many others who were infected had recovered and were discharged from our hospitals and safely returned to their families.

As individuals and collectively, we could do a lot more to keep ourselves, our friends, neighbours and families safe.

If you have private events with large numbers, like weddings or other social gatherings, which are absolutely necessary for whatever reasons, please help to keep your guests safe by following the social distancing measures recommended by the MOH. If such gatherings can be delayed, that would be better until the risk has passed.

Please remember too that no age group is invincible. The World Health Organisation has recently made a special call to young people to be vigilant because of the concern that many think that COVID -19 only infects older people. The virus infects everyone except that older people are more vulnerable because of lower immunities and pre-existing conditions. Also, infected young people can spread the infection to others who are more vulnerable.

So, let’s do this together. Let’s do whatever it takes to beat COVID-19.

MOH | News Highlights

Ong Ye Kung
19 March 2020 at 02:09 ·

Before the March school holidays, we were in a stable situation, with few new COVID-19 cases a day, most of which were traceable to known clusters.

Our schools had effective precautionary measures - sending home students who do not feel well (including those with cough and sore throat), inculcating better personal hygiene habits, and limiting mingling to largely students’ classes and CCA groups - to limit the spread of COVID-19.

Separately, many parents and students were asking if we can resume some activities, such as the suspended National School Games, which they having been training very hard for. Quietly, MOE was closely watching the situation, with some hope that we could resume some non-contact, small scale activities.

However, I am afraid this is now not possible. The past week saw rising infections around the world, including in Southeast Asia. This resulted in a surge in imported cases in Singapore. We have been very vigilant in picking up infections amongst this group, and most did not have a chance to mingle in the community. To protect our society further, the Government has stepped up travel restrictions.

Unfortunately, this development coincided with the March school holidays. Thousands of our students and their families have travelled overseas and have returned, or are now making their way back.

Our priority must be to protect the education system and keeping students safe. By protecting the system robustly, it can remain open, and lives need not be disrupted. Otherwise, many parents, including those working in hospitals and providing essential services, will not be able to go to work.

Hence, after much discussion with the Ministerial Task Force and medical experts, we have decided to subject all students and school staff who have returned from overseas on or after 14 March 2020 to 14 days Leave of Absence (LOA). This is on top of the Stay Home Notice that the MOH has just announced. The day you arrive will be considered Day 0 of your LOA.

We have also decided to suspend CCAs for two weeks and defer the SYF Arts Presentation. The National School Games will continue to be suspended until the end of the June holidays.

I know many students, parents and coaches will be disappointed. And many students and parents will be inconvenienced. I hate to have to do this, but it is critical that we protect the system, and keep everyone who has overseas exposure to the virus away from the school population. Then we can possibly return to the calm we enjoyed before the March school holidays. We need to do our best to maintain that.

I know many have rushed back to Singapore earlier this week because of all the travel restrictions. So for many, your LOA from school may have already started. This means that you may not miss school for the full two weeks, so I hope this won’t be too much of an inconvenience.

For students who are not able to be in school, your school will support you through home-based learning. There will be a few schools where teachers have travelled and will have to be absent. MOE will do our best to support these schools and ensure that lessons are not interrupted.

We have done what we can to protect the system. Let’s keep calm and carry on. Continue to monitor your temperature, see a doctor if you’re sick and wash your hands regularly. I thank you for your understanding.

(Read more about our measures here:
https://www.moe.gov.sg/news/press-releases/schools-and-kindergartens-to-re-open-with-enhanced-precautionary-measures)

Desmond Lee
19 March 2020 at 06:06 ·

<<Measures for preschools and student care centres>>
In the past week, we have seen a rising number of imported COVID-19 cases, as Singaporeans and residents get infected overseas and are picked up when they return home. Those who are abroad for work or studies are also coming back to Singapore. On 13 March, before the school holidays, ECDA had strongly advised families with pre-schoolers and preschool staff against overseas travel, given the escalating COVID-19 situation globally. We similarly advised all student care centre staff and children against overseas travel. We are appreciative that many took heed and decided not to travel. Nevertheless, quite a number of families still travelled abroad, and have returned or are returning home.

Yesterday, MOH announced that all returning Singapore residents, Long Term Pass Holders and short term visitors will be issued with Stay-Home Notices (SHNs).

We will need to take further steps to safeguard our preschoolers and our students. After careful deliberation with my colleagues in the Ministerial Task Force, we have decided to implement a 14-day Leave of Absence (LOA) for students and staff of preschools and student care centres who had returned from overseas on or after 14 March (which is the start of the March school holidays). This was not an easy decision as this enhanced precautionary measure will bring great inconvenience to some families. But given the volatility and the worsening global situation, we must keep those with overseas exposure temporarily away from our preschool and school community to ensure everyone’s health and safety. By protecting the system well, our preschools and student care centres can then remain open so that we can go about our lives as normally as possible.

This new measure will apply to children and preschool/student care staff who have returned to Singapore from abroad on or after 14 March 2020. On return to Singapore, they will need to undergo LOA (i.e. stay away from preschool/centre and remain at home) for 14 days. Count the day you return as Day 0, and you can return to the preschool/student care centre on Day 15.

This measure will kick in from tomorrow morning, 20 March. This to give parents some lead time to make alternative arrangements. For those who are already back in Singapore, we strongly encourage you to start your LOA immediately. But if you need some time until tomorrow to make alternative childminding arrangements, the preschools and student care centres are making arrangements to limit potential exposure today.

Similar measures have been announced by MOE for schools, and MSF for social services that serve vulnerable communities such as the elderly.

My colleagues and I apologise for the inconvenience that this tighter measure will cause our parents, pre-schoolers, children, preschool and student care operators and staff. We seek your understanding and support during these unusual times, and thank you for playing your part to keep our infants, children, clients and staff safe and healthy. During this difficult period, we urge employers and colleagues of affected parents and caregivers to support them with flexible work arrangements if they need to be at home to care for their children and family members during this period.

Let us continue to look out for one another.

#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether

Given an increase of imported COVID-19 cases in Singapore, Minister for National Development, Lawrence Wong, announced that starting 20 March 2020, all Singaporeans, Permanent Residents, Long Term Pass holders and short-term visitors entering Singapore from all countries will be issued a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN).

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has also raised the advisory for Singaporeans to defer all travel abroad with immediate effect.

He was speaking at a media doorstop interview on 18 March 2020.

Ong Ye Kung
19 March 2020 at 02:09 ·

Before the March school holidays, we were in a stable situation, with few new COVID-19 cases a day, most of which were traceable to known clusters.

Our schools had effective precautionary measures - sending home students who do not feel well (including those with cough and sore throat), inculcating better personal hygiene habits, and limiting mingling to largely students’ classes and CCA groups - to limit the spread of COVID-19.

Separately, many parents and students were asking if we can resume some activities, such as the suspended National School Games, which they having been training very hard for. Quietly, MOE was closely watching the situation, with some hope that we could resume some non-contact, small scale activities.

However, I am afraid this is now not possible. The past week saw rising infections around the world, including in Southeast Asia. This resulted in a surge in imported cases in Singapore. We have been very vigilant in picking up infections amongst this group, and most did not have a chance to mingle in the community. To protect our society further, the Government has stepped up travel restrictions.

Unfortunately, this development coincided with the March school holidays. Thousands of our students and their families have travelled overseas and have returned, or are now making their way back.

Our priority must be to protect the education system and keeping students safe. By protecting the system robustly, it can remain open, and lives need not be disrupted. Otherwise, many parents, including those working in hospitals and providing essential services, will not be able to go to work.

Hence, after much discussion with the Ministerial Task Force and medical experts, we have decided to subject all students and school staff who have returned from overseas on or after 14 March 2020 to 14 days Leave of Absence (LOA). This is on top of the Stay Home Notice that the MOH has just announced. The day you arrive will be considered Day 0 of your LOA.

We have also decided to suspend CCAs for two weeks and defer the SYF Arts Presentation. The National School Games will continue to be suspended until the end of the June holidays.

I know many students, parents and coaches will be disappointed. And many students and parents will be inconvenienced. I hate to have to do this, but it is critical that we protect the system, and keep everyone who has overseas exposure to the virus away from the school population. Then we can possibly return to the calm we enjoyed before the March school holidays. We need to do our best to maintain that.

I know many have rushed back to Singapore earlier this week because of all the travel restrictions. So for many, your LOA from school may have already started. This means that you may not miss school for the full two weeks, so I hope this won’t be too much of an inconvenience.

For students who are not able to be in school, your school will support you through home-based learning. There will be a few schools where teachers have travelled and will have to be absent. MOE will do our best to support these schools and ensure that lessons are not interrupted.

We have done what we can to protect the system. Let’s keep calm and carry on. Continue to monitor your temperature, see a doctor if you’re sick and wash your hands regularly. I thank you for your understanding.

Lawrence Wong
19 March 2020 at 00:50 ·

<New Travel Advisory and Restrictions>

We are all concerned about the sharp rise in infected cases today. The majority of these cases are Singaporeans and residents returning from overseas. In the coming weeks, we expect more to do so, including Singaporeans/residents studying or working in Europe and the US.

Singapore cannot shut its doors to our own citizens and residents. So we have to take extra precautions.

First, we advise everyone to defer ALL travel. Second, for those who are already overseas (anywhere in the world), they will have to meet a full 14-day stay at home requirement when they come back to Singapore. In other words they have to self-isolate for 14 days at their place of residence.

With these precautions we can ensure that all returnees are isolated and that those who are infected can be treated promptly, without causing a broader spread of the virus in our community.

Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH)
18 March 2020 at 11:17 ·

Our Department of Laboratory Medicine operates 24/7 round the clock every day to ensure rapid turnaround of COVID-19 testing. Their tireless work of testing and sending accurate and prompt results is crucial in providing timely care for confirmed cases and reducing anxiety amongst suspect patients. With 500 to 700 samples coming in for testing daily from TTSH, NCID and other institutions, we've had to train additional staff in running the COVID-19 tests, which involve numerous steps. While some services have been reduced to ramp up our support for NCID, our lab work still continues for tests such as Haematology, Biochemistry, Microbiology, Blood Transfusion, MERS, or Avian Flu. Even with this workload, our lab is scaling up through process re-design in anticipation of processing more COVID-19 tests in our fight against the virus.

Another team crucial in our battle is our Intensive Care Unit. They've been working their hearts out making critical decisions and care interventions to save a more vulnerable group of patients severely impacted by the virus while ensuring that more critical care is readily available with the evolving situation.

We are encouraged to have Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong this morning at our Laboratories and Intensive Care Units, to thank our staff for their dedication and to listen to their needs. Thank you Minister for reminding us that we are #StrongerTogether.

#HealthcareHeroes #COVID19 #SGUnited

In view of the heightened risk of importation of COVID-19 cases into Singapore, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will implement additional measures for all travellers entering Singapore.

• Singaporeans are advised to defer all travel abroad with immediate effect. The expansion of the travel advisory is to reduce the risk of Singaporeans being infected with the virus when abroad, and spreading it to other Singaporeans when they return.

Chan Chun Sing
18 March 2020 at 06:37 ·

Malaysia has implemented its Movement Control Order. I am glad to see that the supply of fresh food has not been fully disrupted and most of our wholesalers and retailers managed to receive their goods as per normal since this morning.

Other goods such as pharmaceuticals and infant diapers have also managed to come through to Singapore. We are aware that some companies have provided feedback that trucks not containing food have not been allowed to come in. We are monitoring the situation closely and are in touch with our Malaysian counterparts to ensure that food and other supplies will be able to come through to Singapore as agreed by Malaysian PM Muhyiddin Yassin in his phone call with PM Lee yesterday.

I also spoke to my counterpart Senior Minister and Minister of International Trade and Industry Azmin Ali this afternoon. I thanked him for facilitating the flow of goods and supplies into Singapore during this period and told him that we will continue to work closely with Malaysia to slow down the spread of COVID-19. We both noted that it is in our mutual interest to ensure that supply chains remain robust and in working order, and agreed that we must maintain confidence in our people and businesses in order to successfully overcome the challenges posed by COVID-19.

Some of our companies have also activated alternative transport arrangements via sea and air freight to bring their goods from Malaysia to Singapore. Our economic agencies are working with our companies, in particular those dealing with essential products and services, to minimise disruption to their supply lines.

Most of our companies have also managed to secure the necessary accommodation for their Malaysian workers who will be staying in Singapore for the next two weeks to work. It must not be an easy decision for them to leave their homes and families to stay in Singapore during this period. We thank the Malaysian workers who decided to make this personal sacrifice to ensure that business operations and essential services can continue in Singapore. CCS

Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong had a virtual meeting yesterday with Health Minister YB Dato’ Sri Dr Adham Baba and his senior officials from both the Ministry of Health Malaysia and Johor State Health Department. Dr Adham Baba informed us that Malaysia had to make a serious announcement on 16 March night to implement a Movement Control Order to curb the spread of COVID-19. With rapid increases in cases seen in many countries, the COVID-19 outbreak is now a global pandemic and it is concerning to us.

As the situation is evolving quickly, we agreed that Singapore and Malaysia should continue to work closely together. Senior Officials under the Singapore-Malaysia Joint Working Group (JWG) are in close communication and are sharing information with each other on COVID-19 to facilitate timely response and contact-tracing of confirmed cases. We will work together to find solutions to minimise the impact on the lives of our people and protect them from COVID-19.

Chan Chun Sing
17 March 2020 at 01:37 ·

This morning I spoke with our media to provide more details on our supplies of food and essential items.

While I did not reveal the actual numbers as it will affect our ongoing negotiations with overseas suppliers, I shared that we are using a strategy combining stockpiling and local production to buy us time to bring in alternative supplies should our usual supply lines be disrupted.

For carbohydrates, like rice and noodles, we have more than three months’ worth of stockpile at the national level. For proteins like meat, and vegetables, we use a combination of fresh, frozen and canned options to meet our demand and we have more than two months’ worth of supplies at normal consumption patterns. As for eggs, we have our local production and we are also activating air freight options to substitute the Malaysian supplies should they be disrupted.

A disruption of supplies from Malaysia is a contingency scenario we have planned for many years. We have put in place robust plans to manage this scenario and will continue to review our strategies to ensure that Singaporeans never run out of food or essential supplies.

While we may have to make some adjustments to our choices in the short term, we have sufficient food supplies for all Singaporeans as long as all of us buy responsibly.

Once again, I would like to express my deep appreciation to all the staff who worked through the night to replenish our shelves and also a big thank you to all Singaporeans who have stayed calm throughout all the recent announcements and developments.

While we may be anxious individually, we can draw strength from the fact that we are all in this collectively, working as one united Singapore. CCS

Singapore will implement additional precautionary measures to further reduce the risk of importation of COVID-19 to Singapore. These include travel advisories against all non-essential travel abroad, and further restrictions on travelers coming into Singapore.

• From 16 Mar 2020, 2359 hours, all travelers (including Singapore Residents, Long Term Pass holders, and short-term visitors) entering Singapore with recent travel history to ASEAN countries, Japan, Switzerland, or the UK within the last 14 days will be issued with a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN). In addition, they will have to provide proof of the place they will serve the SHN. They may also be swabbed for testing for COVID-19, even if asymptomatic.

• From 16 Mar 2020, 2359 hours, all short-term visitors who are nationals of any ASEAN country will have to submit requisite information on their health to the Singapore Overseas Mission in the country they are resident before their intended date of travel. The submission will have to be approved by Singapore’s MOH before travel to Singapore, and the approval will be verified by the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority officers at the Singapore checkpoints. Short-term visitors who arrived in Singapore without the necessary approval will be denied entry into Singapore.

• As previously announced, residents and long-term pass holders returning from mainland China (outside Hubei province), Iran, Italy, France, Germany, Republic of Korea, and Spain will continue to be issued a 14-day SHN upon return to Singapore, while short-term visitors from these areas will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore.

With immediate effect, Singaporeans are advised to defer all non-essential travel abroad. This advisory will apply for 30 days, and will be reviewed thereafter.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/additional-precautionary-measures-to-prevent-further-importation-of-covid-19-cases

Entry Approval and Stay-Home Notice Requirements For All New and Returning Foreign Domestic Workers

Josephine Teo is in Singapore.
15 March 2020 at 12:01 · Singapore ·

PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES TO PROTECT HOUSEHOLDS

Foreign domestic workers (FDW) play an important role in supporting Singaporeans with domestic work and caregiving needs. They live with employers and their families, and many look after young children and the elderly.

In view of the #COVID19 situation, we will now require employers and employment agencies to obtain approval from Singapore Ministry of Manpower before their FDWs enter #Singapore. These measures will apply to all new or returning FDWs arriving in Singapore from 16 March 2359 hours. The FDWs will be placed on a mandatory 14-DAY Stay-Home Notice (SHN) upon arrival in Singapore.

Employers I have spoken to understand this is a necessary measure to protect their families and the wider community. MOM is prepared to support employers whose existing FDWs are not in Singapore but will be required to serve the SHN when they return. If they wish to arrange for their FDW to serve her SHN outside of their homes, they can apply for $60 support and levy waiver for every day of the SHN.

Additionally, with the introduction of social distancing measures, employers should discuss alternative rest day arrangements with their FDWs. FDWs may choose to take their rest day on a week day when it is less crowded or choose to spend their rest day at home. FDWs planning to go on home leave should also be encouraged to postpone their plans.

We thank everyone for their cooperation during this period. Let’s try our best to keep each other safe. – Jo Teo

Lawrence Wong
15 March 2020 at 10:29 ·

<Additional Travel Restrictions>

Globally, the number of infected cases is rising rapidly. We are also seeing more imported cases in Singapore. Many of them are our own residents returning from overseas. Hence the Taskforce has issued an advisory to defer all non-essential travel abroad with immediate effect.

Besides returning residents, we have a few cases from ASEAN countries, coming here for the sole purpose of seeking medical treatment. It is hard for us to cope with this additional demand during this critical period when our healthcare resources are stretched, and need to be prioritised for Singaporeans.

We have therefore decided to put in place tighter border control measures:

- All travellers with recent travel history in the UK, Switzerland, Japan, and ASEAN countries will be served a 14-day stay home notice. In other words they have to self-isolate or self-quarantine for a full 14 days at their place of residence.

- All short term visitors who are nationals of ASEAN countries will have to submit health information to our Overseas Missions, and the submission will have to be approved by our MOH before they travel. Those without the necessary approval will be denied entry.

These arrangements will not apply to Singaporeans and Malaysians using our sea and land crossings daily. Precautions are needed at these checkpoints but they need to be considered separately given the high volume of people, and the high level of interdependency between our two countries. Officials on both sides are now discussing separate arrangements for these checkpoints through the Joint Working Group on COVID-19

The new measures will impose greater inconveniences, especially for those planning to travel, or who are already overseas. But I seek the understanding of Singaporeans that they are necessary moves to limit the number of imported cases and to keep all of us safe.

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
14 March 2020 at 04:41 ·

COVID-19 is a novel disease and there is still much to be learned about it. Based on existing information, the most likely modes of transmission are through droplets and fomites (touching of contaminated surfaces).

There has been quite a lot of discussion about social distancing of late. So what is the value of social distancing in the context of this current COVID-19 pandemic?

Social distancing practices are changes in our human behavior that prevent disease transmission by reducing physical contact rates between susceptible individuals and the infected individuals. The coronavirus does not infect us though the air we breathe in. It has to reach us through close contact via droplets from coughing, sneezing or even talking, or through contaminated surfaces where our hands laid on and then subsequently accidental touching of our mouth, nose and eyes.

Social distancing measures have been shown to reduce the severity of an epidemic, but the benefits of social distancing will depend on the extent and magnitude to which it is applied by both the individual and the community.

Social distancing practices can range from the simplest modification of behaviour, such as the way we greet one another, ie. no shaking of hands; sitting / standing with a reasonable separation of about a metre apart; avoiding crowded places and minimising socialisation duration to preferably less than 30mins. Or it can be more extensive involving a whole of community or society, like telecommuting, cohorting of employees, cancellation of mass events or social activities, school closures or even a total lockdown of cities / countries, such as in Wuhan, Hubei province, Italy and Denmark.

The applications of such social distancing measures will depend on various factors such as the severity of the epidemic, the extent of the community transmission, and the availability and adequacy of the medical resources in dealing with the severely ill.

Social distancing is about protecting not just yourself, but everyone in the community. By slowing the spread of the disease, it helps protect people who are at higher risk of developing more severe illness or death, including the elderly, those with pre-existing medical conditions and the immunocompromised.
Social distancing also helps communities “flatten the curve” - slowing the spread allows the health care system to more adequately respond to an influx of patients, especially those who require respirators or intensive care facilities.

Effective as it may when applied appropriately, it must be accompanied by both personal hygiene and social responsibility. We must constantly keep our hands clean by frequent washing with soap and water or the use of hand sanitisers. This will help minimise the risk of transmission through fomites. We must also exercise social responsibility by putting on a mask when unwell and to consult a doctor for medical assessment, and avoid doctor-hopping. When unwell, please stay away from work, school or participating in other social activities. Many of the large clusters we see recently were due to irresponsible behaviour by the infected individuals, resulting in further transmission of the disease.

Singapore has done reasonably well as a nation in preventing a massive uncontrollable outbreak in the community. We should not be complacent and must continue to stand united (with some safe physical separation 😄) in this #FightAgainstCoVid19. I believe if we can all play our part, we will get through this together and emerge stronger as a people, as a nation.

Ministry of Health, Singapore

Lawrence Wong
13 March 2020 at 18:13 ·

<Social Distancing and Travel Restrictions>

The Taskforce announced more social distancing measures today. This includes limiting the size of gatherings to 250 people and having seats placed further apart in workplaces and public venues, where possible. We are starting this new practice even for our media conferences.

At the same time, we remain vigilant against the import of new cases. That’s why we are restricting travellers with recent travel history from the whole of Italy, France, Germany and Spain - countries with very high numbers of cases and very high rates of increase. We are also requiring all visitors with fever or respiratory symptoms to serve a full 14-day stay at home (or hotel) requirement, in addition to undergoing a swab test.

We will continue to do everything we can to limit the number of imported cases and slow down the spread of the virus in Singapore.

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Heng Swee Keat
13 March 2020 at 09:26 ·

In response to the rapid increase of COVID-19 cases across Europe, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce announced the implementation of additional travel restrictions for visitors from Italy, France, Germany and Spain. From 15 March, all visitors who have visited these countries within a 14-day period will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore. Singaporeans and PRs coming back home from these countries will have to serve a 14-day Stay Home Notice. This is on top of the swab testing conducted at our checkpoints. We will also cease port calls for all cruise vessels with immediate effect.

To further reduce the risk of local transmission at large-scale events, all ticketed events with 250 participants or more will be cancelled or deferred. We have also introduced restrictions and advisories for events and gatherings.

These measures are part of our overall approach to fight COVID-19 — which will continue to be guided by data, scientific evidence, and expert advice. But these measures alone are not enough. We must all do our part — continue to practise good personal hygiene and be socially responsible. Together, we can overcome and emerge stronger from this outbreak.

You can read more details in Ministry of Health, Singapore’s press release below.

#SGUnited

Singapore will implement additional precautionary measures to slow the transmission of the COVID-19 virus. These include travel advisories against all non-essential travel and border restrictions for Italy, France, Spain and Germany, as well as additional social distancing measures within Singapore.

• In light of the rapid spread of the virus across Europe, Singaporeans are advised to defer all non-essential travel to Italy, France, Spain and Germany. Our existing advisory to defer all travel to Hubei province in mainland China, and non-essential travel to the rest of mainland China, Iran, Japan and the Republic of Korea, remains.

• From 15 March 2020, 2359 hours, all new visitors with recent travel history to Italy, France, Spain and Germany within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Singapore, or transit through Singapore.

• From 15 March 2020, 2359 hours, residents (Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents) and long-term pass holders (including work passes, Student’s Pass, Dependent’s Pass, and Long-Term Visit Pass) with recent travel history to Italy, France, Spain and Germany within the last 14 days, will be issued with a Stay-Home Notice.

• From 4 March, travellers entering Singapore and exhibiting fever and/or other symptoms of respiratory illness are required to undergo a COVID-19 swab test at the checkpoint, regardless of travel history. With immediate effect, all such travellers will also be issued a 14-day SHN , which they will have to serve in full even if the result of the swab test is negative. Those who meet the clinical suspect case definition will be conveyed to the hospital for follow-up.

• In order to reduce the risk of local transmission, we will introduce requirements and advisories for events and gatherings, workplaces and public venues. This is to limit large crowds gathering in close proximity over a prolonged duration.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/additional-precautionary-measures-to-prevent-further-importation-and-spread-of-covid-19-cases

Lawrence Wong
11 March 2020 at 14:03 ·

<Social Distancing>

Yesterday the Taskforce announced the suspension of all senior-oriented activities by government agencies for 14 days. This is an example of a “social distancing” measure, where we reduce the contact people have with one another to slow down the spread of the virus.

Beyond this specific move, we are looking at a broader range of social distancing measures, including for events, schools, workplaces, as well as religious services.

We are mindful that some of these measures can be disruptive to the daily lives of Singaporeans. If we do them all at once, many activities will grind to a halt, and our city will have to shut down. If we implement the measures too early, people may get fatigued. And remember that various medical experts have already said that the virus can last till end-2020 at least.

So it is critical to put in place the right measures at the right time, to act as effective “circuit breakers” to slow down the transmission chain. In deciding what to do and when to implement them, we will continue to be guided by data, scientific evidence and expert advice.

Additional precautionary measures will be put in place to reduce the risk of further transmission of COVID-19 among seniors.

All senior-centric activities conducted by government agencies will be suspended for 14 days from 11 March to 24 March 2020. These include activities held at CCs, RCs, Senior Activity Centres, Active Ageing Hubs, CREST centres, Health Promotion Board and ActiveSG sport centres.

Social responsibility is a critical factor in slowing the transmission of the virus. Many of the locally transmitted cases were the result of the socially irresponsible actions of a few individuals who attended events and activities despite being unwell.

We urge all Singaporeans to play their part in the fight against the virus. Those who are unwell, even with mild flu-like symptoms, should see a doctor and stay at home to prevent spreading illness to others.

Josephine Teo is in Singapore.
9 March 2020 at 20:48 · Singapore ·

HARNESSING TECHNOLOGY TO MANAGE COVID-19

Since 5 March, travellers to #Singapore who have a fever or display signs of respiratory illness have to undergo a COVID-19 nasal swab test. The samples, collected at all air, land and sea checkpoints, are analysed by the test kit developed by HTX SG. It has an accuracy rate of more than 99 per cent and is able to test for a result in three hours.

The test kit helped to detect the presence of COVID-19 in Case 147 upon arrival in Singapore in 7 March. He was subsequently confirmed to have COVID-19 infection on the morning of 8 March.

Proud that our HTX scientists from the Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear and Explosives (CBRNE) Centre of Expertise developed this test kit quickly to meet our frontline needs, after the COVID-19 genome sequence was made public in mid-January.

I’m glad that this innovation from our scientists at HTX can play a part in limiting the spread of imported cases in our ongoing battle with #COVID19.

Task force formed to raise public hygiene standards beyond COVID-19 outbreak

Lee Hsien Loong
6 March 2020 at 14:04 ·

COVID-19 makes hygiene and cleanliness more important than ever. More and more people are getting infected all over the world. Singapore has restricted travellers from badly hit countries, but we can’t close our borders completely. So we must expect more cases and clusters to pop up in Singapore.

We have been quite successful identifying patients, tracing contacts and stamping out clusters. We will keep on doing this. But we also need to slow the spread of the virus, and that means we must raise our hygiene standards.

Better hygiene must be our first line of defence. We have formed the SG Clean taskforce, to be chaired by Minister Masagos Zulkifli. It will focus on 3 things:

- public cleanliness (keeping public spaces clean);
- personal hygiene (washing your hands); and
- social norms (use serving spoons when you share food).

Let’s make better hygiene our way of life, and defeat COVID-19! – LHL

#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether
#SGClean

Amy Khor
6 March 2020 at 17:43 ·

With the continued global spread of the COVID-19 virus, it is important for us to remain vigilant and take active steps to safeguard public health.

We are entering a new situation, a new normal, where enhanced personal hygiene and social responsibility have to be an integral part of our lives. This is especially so, when we don’t know how long COVID-19 will last.

Today Masagos Zulkifli announced the formation of the SG Clean Taskforce, which is under the purview of the Multi-Ministry Taskforce for COVID-19. The Taskforce will rally Singaporeans to step up cleanliness and hygiene standards through three key areas:

— Ensuring cleanliness of public spaces is a shared responsibility
— Improving personal hygiene
— Adapting social norms

We need everyone to come on board, to stand united as a nation, so that we can keep ourselves and our loved ones safe.

Let’s make SG Clean our new way of life.

#SGClean

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

Masagos Zulkifli
6 March 2020 at 02:52 ·

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce (MTF) has been introducing measures progressively, to meet the challenges of the evolving COVID-19 situation. This has helped us to manage the spread of the virus, and facilitate contact tracing. We will continue to do all we can. I would like to thank all frontline officers and healthcare workers, and everyone who has pitched in to fight against COVID-19.

But community spread remains a possibility as COVID-19 continues to spread globally. We need to step up cleanliness and hygiene standards in all facets of our lives. This requires us to make some adjustments and adopt new norms.

Today, I announced that I will be chairing a new multi-agency SG Clean Taskforce to drive this, under the purview of the MTF. Together with Desmond Lee Amy Khor Janil Puthucheary Low Yen Ling Baey Yam Keng 马炎庆 and representatives from other agencies, we will focus on 3 key areas to safeguard public health.

First, strengthening shared responsibility for the cleanliness of public spaces. We have made a good start with the launch of the SG Clean campaign last month. And as announced this week, we are making amendments to the Environmental Public Health Act (EPHA) to mandate standards for public cleanliness and place greater accountability on premise managers to ensure the cleanliness of their premises.

Second, improving personal hygiene. All of us can do our part to keep ourselves and others around us safe by practising the “Habits of Good Public Hygiene” as highlighted by National Environment Agency (NEA). Good habits such as washing hands frequently with soap, taking our temperature daily, and using a tissue whenever we sneeze or cough, should become our way of life for the longer term.

Third, adapting social norms. We do not know how long COVID-19 will last. We are entering a new situation, a new normal, where enhanced personal hygiene have to be an integral part of our lives. Do remember to use serving spoons when sharing food, and keep the tables in hawker centres and public spaces clean.

Let us work together to make SG Clean our new way of life.

#SGClean
#SGUnited
#SGTogether

5 March 2020 at 23:46 ·

I announced subsidies for vaccinations in Parliament at Ministry of Health, Singapore Budget (Committee of Supply) debates on Thursday (5 Mar).

All childhood vaccinations recommended under National Childhood Immunisation Schedule and developmental screening will be fully subsidised for Singaporean children.

Adult vaccinations recommended under National Adult Immunisation Schedule will also be subsidised.

Eligible lower to middle income Singaporeans will get 75% subsidy at polyclinics. This corresponds to CHAS Blue and Orange cardholders.

Other eligible Singaporeans will get 50% subsidy for the vaccinations.

Pioneer Generation get an extra 50% subsidies and Merdeka Generation get an extra 25%, off the remaining co-payment amount.

This will take effect before the end of 2020 and will be available at polyclinics, and CHAS GP clinics across Singapore.

We want to keep Singaporeans healthy, stay out of hospitals, keep out vaccine-preventable diseases through vaccinations.

I urge parents to take advantage of the free vaccinations to give our children the best possible start. And adults, particularly seniors, please get vaccinated too - stay healthy!

How Singapore Unites Against A Virus Attack | Stronger: The Battle Against COVID-19 | Full Episode

Did you know? The smoking rate in Singapore dropped to 10.6% in 2019, bringing us close to our stretch target of reducing the smoking rate to below 10% by 2020!

To bring the smoking rate down further, we are implementing anti-smoking measures, such as standardised packaging for tobacco products and raising the minimum legal age for smoking. We will also be testing out new models for smoking cessation at public healthcare institutions to support smokers to quit.

To support Singaporeans to achieve better health, Nutri-Grade labelling and advertising measures for pre-packaged beverages will start from end-2021.

We will also extend the labelling and advertising measures to freshly prepared beverages.

Singaporeans can also look forward to more water dispensers being installed in hawker centres, bus interchanges and terminals to encourage the consumption of plain water.

#WarOnDiabetes
#DroptheSugar

To better support healthcare professionals and improve patient outcomes, the Agency for Care Effectiveness (ACE) will launch the ACE Clinical Update Service in 2020.

Healthcare professionals will be updated with best available evidence on a range of clinical topics through individualised, face-to-face discussions. Useful resources such as those that assist in explaining health conditions or treatment options to patients will also be shared. ACE has started by reaching out to the GP community on the latest developments in asthma management.

#ICYMI Youths at-risk can get better access to coordinated mental health and social support services through the new Integrated Youth Service. The one-stop service will start in Woodlands this year, and will offer individualised emotional support, needs identifications and peer support services.

[Just in] SMS Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）spoke in Parliament on our continued efforts to expand primary care capabilities to ensure that Singaporeans have access to affordable and quality healthcare, close to their homes.

Bidadari and Bishan will each have a new polyclinic by 2030! This will bring the total number of polyclinics to 32 by 2030, up from the 20 we have today.

We are also investing in our general practitioners to provide holistic chronic disease care in the community. By end-2020, at least half of CHAS GP clinics will participate in the Primary Care Network, which takes a team-based approach where patients will follow up regularly with the same care team.

#ICYMI, SMS Amy Khor thanked our healthcare workers, who are truly the backbone of our healthcare system.

Over the next three years, MOH will set aside another $150 million to support community care institutions to further improve the competitiveness of salaries for about 4,000 local nurses and support care staff.

Check out other initiatives targeted at empowering and enabling our healthcare workforce, such as the Community Care Scholarship and the Community Care Nursing Leadership Programme.

In May 2020, seniors can look forward to the launch of the new assisted living model in public housing, where housing is twinned with care services.

The flats will be senior-friendly in design, and come with a package of programmes and services that caters to seniors’ needs over time. They also will be designed with residents’ future needs in mind, including larger bathrooms and pre-installed senior-friendly fittings such as grab bars. There will also be communal spaces and facilities to encourage social interaction amongst the seniors.

An eldercare centre will be co-located at the block, to provide active ageing and befriending services to seniors in the neighbourhood. The flats will also be installed with personal alert buttons which will allow seniors to call a 24/7 emergency response service for assistance if needed.

#ICYMI Minister Gan Kim Yong announced that we will work with the National University Health System - NUHS to design new and innovative care models, and test them at Alexandra Hospital (AH).

The master planning exercise for AH was completed in 2019. We have also shifted AH’s site boundary closer to Queensway to enhance accessibility to patients.

Residents in the area can look forward to the completion of the first phase of AH’s redevelopment by 2030.

🏥🏥🏥

[Just in] Minister for Health, Mr Gan Kim Yong shared MOH’s plans to continue investing in the healthcare system to meet the growing and evolving healthcare needs of an ageing population.

We have started the planning of a new integrated general and community hospital in the East which will be ready around 2030.

Upcoming public hospitals – Woodlands Health Campus and the Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) Integrated Care Hub at Novena – are scheduled to open progressively from 2022.

By 2030, we will have a total of 12 public acute hospitals and 8 public community hospitals.

Heng Swee Keat
3 March 2020 at 13:04 ·

We have seen a sharp increase in COVID-19 cases in some countries over the past few days. In response to this, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce announced today that additional precautionary measures will be implemented for incoming and outgoing travellers.

From Wednesday, 4 March 2020, 2359hrs, travellers with recent travel history to Iran, northern Italy, and South Korea will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore. Residents and long-term pass holders with recent travel history of 14 days to these countries will be issued with a Stay-Home Notice.

At the same time, all travellers arriving in Singapore who exhibit symptoms of respiratory illness will have to undergo a compulsory COVID-19 swab test.

These measures are meant to limit the spread of the disease in Singapore, but despite our best efforts, we have to be mentally prepared for undetected cases to cause a new spike in COVID-19 cases here. We have seen this happen elsewhere.

As we continue to monitor the fast-evolving situation not just locally but also globally, we will adjust our measures so as to ensure these are appropriate.

In the meantime, our first and best line of defence involves every single one of us — let’s continue to stay vigilant and be socially responsible, stay at home if you are unwell and always practise good personal hygiene.

Please see the Ministry of Health, Singapore’s statement below for details.

To date, a total of 78 cases have fully recovered from the infection and have been discharged from hospital. Of the 32 confirmed cases who are still in hospital, most are stable or improving. Seven are in critical condition in the intensive care unit.

Read more in the press release: http://moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/two-new-cases-of-covid-19-infection-confirmed

To protect Singaporeans, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce will put in place additional precautions for outgoing and incoming travellers. Singaporeans are advised to defer non-essential travel to Iran, northern Italy, Japan and the Republic of Korea.

From 4 March 2020, 2359 hours:
• All new visitors with recent travel history to Iran, northern Italy or the Republic of Korea within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Singapore, or transit through Singapore. With immediate effect, the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority will suspend the issuance of all forms of new visas to those with Iranian passports. Previously issued short-term and multiple-visit visas for those with Iranian passports will also be suspended. During this period of suspension, they will not be allowed entry into Singapore.
• Residents (Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents) and long-term pass holders (including work passes, Student’s Pass, Dependant’s Pass and Long-term Visit Pass) with recent travel history to Iran, northern Italy, or the Republic of Korea within the last 14 days, will be issued with a Stay-Home Notice.
• Travellers entering Singapore and exhibiting fever and/or other symptoms of respiratory illness but who do not meet the clinical suspect case definition may be required to undergo a COVID-19 swab test at the checkpoint.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/additional-precautionary-measures-in-response-to-escalating-global-situation

Lawrence Wong
3 March 2020 at 10:10 ·

<Additional Precautions; Be Prepared>

Just shared with the media the additional precautions and travel restrictions the Taskforce has decided to put in place.

For outgoing travellers, we advise to defer non-essential travel for Iran, Northern Italy, Japan and Korea.

For incoming travellers, we will not allow new visitors with recent travel history from Iran, northern Italy and Korea (we have not included Japan for now as the infection rate there is not as high compared to the others). Singaporeans, residents and long-term pass holders returning from these countries will be issued a 14-day stay home notice.

We are also putting in place a new screening mechanism at our borders to test for infected cases, as temperature scans alone are not sufficient. In particular our officers at the checkpoints will look out for those with respiratory symptoms, identify them and ask them to go through a swab test.

Despite our best efforts, we have to be prepared for the infected numbers in Singapore to rise, as has happened elsewhere. As the virus spreads, it will become increasingly difficult to stop it at our borders. There are also likely to be many undetected cases in countries that are not doing proactive testing. We cannot isolate Singapore and shut ourselves from the world. So we will be exposed to new waves of infection.

This is why we must redouble our efforts on what we can do within Singapore. Maintaining good hand hygiene; stepping up cleanliness and hygiene standards in public areas; seeing a doctor when we are sick and staying at home when we are on MC. These are vitally important to slow down the spread of the virus within our community. These new habits must become a permanent part of our daily lives.

Amy Khor
1 March 2020 at 12:38 ·

Our Silver Generation (SG) Ambassadors have been out and about to reach out to vulnerable seniors to keep them updated on the COVID-19 situation, address their concerns and share information on the government support available. In cases where assistance is needed urgently, these vulnerable seniors will have a contact point to reach out to at the Silver Generation Office.

Yesterday, I met Mr Tay and Mdm Lim when I joined the SG Ambassadors to visit some seniors in Ang Mo Kio. They were in good spirits and were positive about the situation, going about their daily routines as usual. They have been keeping themselves informed of basic hygiene tips and know what to do should they develop respiratory symptoms.

We also met Mdm Nooraini and Mr Hamid and shared where the nearest Public Health Preparedness Clinics to them are. Acknowledging the reminders to exercise and stay healthy, Mdm Nooraini said that she often goes to the fitness corner near her place, and take walks around her neighbourhood. Mr Hamid jokingly asked if his walks from the living room to the kitchen were counted as exercise!

I thank the SG Ambassadors for stepping up in this critical time to continue reaching out to our seniors. I am confident that we will be able to overcome the COVID-19 situation if everyone makes an effort to take care of themselves and one another. As Mr Tay said, “Life must go on!”

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
26 February 2020 at 03:12 ·

The first Singapore and Malaysia Joint Working Group for COVID-19 was held in Johor Bahru yesterday. The Singapore delegation crossed the Johor-Singapore causeway to meet with colleagues from Malaysia and also took the opportunity to observe the border health screening facilities at the JB Customs, Immigration and Quarantine (CIQ) Complex.

The first JWG meeting was productive and both countries agreed on the next steps for further cooperation. There were discussions on the latest COVID-19 updates and the screening protocols in place at the two land borders we share.

The JWG agreed to continue entry screening at both countries and align health screening protocols at the land borders. Technical experts from both countries will meet to exchange information on clinical management for COVID-19 patients. We will also activate a bilateral Field Epidemiology Training Network (FETN) to share surveillance data and will continue to exchange relevant information with each other to further strengthen public messaging on COVID-19.

It is of importance that both Singapore and Malaysia continue to work closely together to fight the ongoing outbreak. We look forward to hosting Malaysia colleagues in Singapore for the second #JWGforCOVID19.

#TogetherWeCan #FightAgainstCoVid19!

CHANNELNEWSASIA.COM
Chinese New Year gathering identified as missing link between COVID-19 church clusters

Lee Hsien Loong
25 February 2020 at 20:48 ·

We discovered an important link today between two existing COVID-19 clusters — the Grace Assembly of God church (our biggest cluster) and the Life Church and Missions church.

Cases 83 and 91 had only mild symptoms earlier, and had not been diagnosed with COVID-19. But a new serological test — which detects antibodies in the blood, instead of the virus itself — done subsequently confirmed that they had been infected earlier, and linked the two clusters together.

This breakthrough would not have been possible without close cooperation among the Ministry of Health, Singapore, Singapore Police Force and researchers from Duke-NUS Medical School, who developed the serological test, the world's first, here in Singapore. My thanks to all of you for a job well done!

For now, the best thing we can all do is to continue practising good hygiene, and be socially responsible — do not go to gatherings if you are feeling unwell. Together, we can beat the coronavirus. – LHL

MOH.GOV.SG
MOH | News Highlights

We have confirmed that the locally transmitted COVID-19 infection cluster at Grace Assembly of God is linked to the cluster at The Life Church and Missions Singapore, where two travellers from Wuhan had visited and were likely to be the source of infection. This linkage was established with the assistance of the Singapore Police Force.

To understand how the transmission likely occurred across the different cases, MOH and the Police had extensively analysed the activity maps of the confirmed cases, and interviewed them as well as their close contacts. With the discovery of the links between the two church clusters to the travellers from Wuhan, we have now determined the likely source of infection for a large majority of the locally transmitted cases. All this was achieved through close collaboration between the contact tracing and epidemiological teams in MOH, the Police and researchers at Duke-NUS Medical School.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/links-established-between-church-clusters-and-wuhan-travellers

On Saturday, Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong paid a visit to Choa Chu Kang Polyclinic, Keat Hong Family Medicine Clinic and CCK Family Clinic to thank the doctors, nurses and healthcare staff for their efforts in the fight against COVID-19. He also took the opportunity to listen to their feedback on how they are coping with the additional precautionary measures that the Ministry of Health has been rolling out since January. Minister Gan was joined by Mayor of South West District Ms Low Yen Ling and fellow MP for Chua Chu Kang GRC Mr Zaqy Mohamad.

Despite various new protocols and measures they had to adapt to, the teams are upbeat and determined to do their best to keep their patients safe. They have also worked out good processes to triage patients, isolate and escalate suspect cases, while tending to the vast majority of patients whose conditions are not related to COVID-19.

We hope the public will continue to show them your support, and bear with us if you encounter any inconvenience during your visit to the primary care providers. We also want to thank the sponsors who have so kindly donated care packs for our healthcare workers.

Together with more than 800 Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs), 20 polyclinics and 8 family medicine clinics, our primary care forms the bedrock of the healthcare system. During times of outbreak, they are our frontline partners and play a critical role in detecting and managing our patients. MOH is appreciative of them, and will spare no effort to support them and ensure they have the resources to do their work well.

Lawrence Wong
18 February 2020 at 04:52 ·

<New Stay Home Notice>

The number of Covid-19 cases in China continues to rise. There are now more than 12000 cases outside of Hubei. At the same time, there are many Singaporeans, PRs and long-term pass holders still in China. Many may return after the CNY holidays.

Previously all returnees from China have to serve a 14-day Leave of Absence or LOA. To date, we’ve not had any confirmed cases amongst them. But with the latest situation, we have to do more to guard against the risk of a returnee carrying the virus.

So we have introduced a new Stay Home Notice, which will replace the LOA. Under this new regime, all returnees will have to stay at home or their designated accommodation (eg dormitory or hostel) throughout the 14 day period. They will not be allowed to go out. We will enforce this strictly using a range of technological tools and manual spot checks, and there will be penalties for all who breach the rules.

This additional measures will help to minimise the number of new imported cases, and allow us to focus our energies and efforts on reducing the risks of local transmission within our own community.

A huge thank you to our healthcare family for providing our patients with the best care possible during this period. We salute you for your professionalism and steadfast commitment.

We are heartened that many Singaporeans have rallied around our healthcare family to show them your support. Thank you for your acts of kindness and generosity!

Let’s stand together and support one another in this battle against COVID-19. #SGUnited #SGTogether

For more information on the COVID-19, please visit https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19

The number of confirmed cases in mainland China (outside of Hubei) has increased from over 4,000 cases on 31 January 2020 to over 12,000 today.

At the same time, there remains a substantial number of Singapore residents and long-term pass holders in China, including Singapore Citizens. Many of them are expected to return to Singapore in the coming weeks, and to their workplaces or schools, after the Chinese New Year holidays in China. There is a higher chance that returnees could be carrying the virus.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has therefore decided to introduce a new “Stay-Home Notice” (SHN) for Singapore residents and long-term pass holders returning to Singapore from mainland China (outside of Hubei). This SHN will take effect from 18 February 2020, 23:59 hours, and will apply to all returnees with recent travel history to China (outside Hubei) within the last 14 days.

Under the SHN, they will have to remain in their place of residence at all times during the 14-day period. This is stricter than the existing LOA regime, which had allowed returnees to leave their homes briefly, for example for their meals or to buy household supplies.

Those placed on SHN will be reminded to monitor their health closely and minimise contact with others.

Read more in our press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/implementation-of-new-stay-home-notice
