17 February 2020 at 14:40 ·

Joined a video conference this afternoon between Minister for Health Mr Gan Kim Yong and WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, where we shared with World Health Organization (WHO) our measures to contain COVID-19 in Singapore. Our enhanced surveillance includes the conduct of COVID-19 tests on all pneumonia cases admitted at our restructured Hospitals and sentinel surveillance of influenza cases in the community.

Starting tomorrow, 800-900 Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPC) GP clinics in Singapore will be progressively activated to provide subsidised care for all patients with respiratory illnesses.
With enhanced surveillance, we will expect a higher number of confirmed cases but these measures are important to help minimise the chance of spread in our hospitals and within the community.

DG commended our containment and contact tracing efforts in ring-fencing the clusters and noted that there is currently no widespread community transmission in Singapore. He also urged Singapore to share our experiences with other Member States, so that affected countries can learn from one another in the fight against the virus together.

Singapore stands in solidarity with the global community and will continue to work closely with WHO and Member States to protect our people from the COVID-19.

#TogetherWeCan #FightAgainstCoVid19!

Desmond Lee

<<Courage & Care in trying times>>
Our frontline workers in the healthcare and other sectors have been working tirelessly to respond to the public health threat posed by COVID-19. On behalf of all Singaporeans, we thank them for their hard work and selfless dedication.

Our healthcare workers have expressed appreciation for the many offers of help from many good-hearted Singaporeans. Some have suggested that it might be helpful to have a centralised place for Singaporeans to find out how to contribute, in a way that is timely and relevant. We will support this in two ways:

(1) The Courage Fund. This was set up 17 years ago to support SARS patients, healthcare workers and their dependents as well as the wider community affected by serious infectious diseases. Community Chest Singapore and NCSS will facilitate the use of the fund for COVID-19, to support patients, healthcare workers and other affected people. People who wish to donate can also do so. As of today, we have received $250,000 from President’s Challenge and $300,000 from CapitaLand. https://www.comchest.sg/thecouragefund

(2) We are also creating a centralised platform to enable the various ground-up initiatives to more meaningfully address areas of need. Some Singaporeans may want to volunteer or contribute in a bigger way. I will share more details soon.

The way we respond to this global health crisis will shape not just who we are as Singaporeans but also how we will be remembered by future generations. I am confident that Singaporeans will choose courage and resilience, and continue to look out for one another.

#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether

On behalf of my colleagues on the multi-ministry taskforce, I wrote a letter to the ST a Forum to echo public support for our frontline heroes. Let’s stand with them.

********

<<Need to stick together to get through this>>

The letters by Mr Phillip Tan Fong Lip (Kudos to those fighting outbreak, Feb 6) and Mr Adrian Villanueva (Stay strong and united in current difficulties, Feb 10) are very much appreciated.

With the recent developments in the situation, our battle against the novel coronavirus looks like it could be a long one. Those on the front line - including healthcare workers and everyone involved in ensuring the cleanliness and safety of our environment - will especially need our support.

The kind words and understanding of people like Mr Tan and Mr Villanueva will help them to keep up the fight.

On behalf of my colleagues on the multi-ministry task force, I would like to echo the letter writers' appreciation to everyone involved in standing united to manage this situation.

Across both the public and private sectors, many have gone well beyond the call of duty, working through many nights and over the Chinese New Year period. They are giving their best for Singapore. We would also like to thank their families for their understanding and support.

Because of their hard work, the Government can continue to lead a robust response against the virus, and keep the public updated on the situation in a timely and transparent manner.

Let us all do our part in our national effort to keep Singaporeans safe and healthy.
Be socially responsible, practise good personal hygiene habits, and take the necessary steps if unwell.

As Mr Tan said, we can overcome this if we all cooperate and play a positive role. In these difficult times, we can call on our unity and Singapore spirit to overcome the challenge. We are confident that the best of Singapore will allow us to prevail over this virus.

#SGUnited #singaporetogether

Amrin Amin
11 February 2020 at 23:05 ·

7 teams, 2 shifts, drawn from MOH departments, 8.30 am to 10 pm, 7 days a week.

I joined MOH's team of contact tracers on Monday (10 Feb) and helped to make calls.

Our task - identify and check on all whom a suspect novel coronavirus patient has interacted with, determine who have been in close contact and at risk of an infection. We also check on whether the person is well or not. A close contact must be quarantined for 14 days from last contact with patient.

This is an important aspect of managing this infection. With proper identification and quarantine, we can ring fence the case and contain transmission.

I am proud to work alongside them. They are the unsung heroes, our contact tracing warriors on the frontlines!

Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR)
11 February 2020 at 11:06 ·

#SGUnited: A*STAR has worked with the Department of Laboratory Medicine, Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) to successfully develop thousands of 2019-nCoV diagnostic test kits for a number of Singapore public hospitals.

The tests can accurately screen patients for the coronavirus, possibly reducing the wait time for results and allowing those infected to be treated quickly.

Singapore is self-sufficient in this critical area of diagnostics, with the Diagnostics Development (DxD) Hub having the ability to transfer the know-how to local biotechs and SMEs to ramp up production of the tests for the country and the region.

10,000 tests were recently sent to China to assist in the international effort to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus infection.

The team comprises Dr Masafumi Inoue from A*STAR’s Experimental Drug Development Centre (EDDC); Associate Professor Timothy Barkham from the Department of Laboratory Medicine, Tan Tock Seng Hospital; Dr Sebastian Maurer-Stroh from A*STAR’s Bioinformatics Institute (BII), and Dr Sidney Yee from DxD Hub.

#ASTARforSG #SingaporeTogether #EnhancingLives

I joined Ang Hin Kee, Advisor to the National Taxi Association and the NPHVA this afternoon to meet some 50 taxi and private hire car drivers for a dialogue. Drivers shared their concerns about the virus situation, mainly about the drop in ridership and risks of infection in the course of their work.

We hear them and we feel their worries. Totally understandable. The Government will take the lead to coordinate tripartite efforts with taxi and private hire car operators. NTA and NPHVA will provide more support to the taxi and private hire car sector, and one of the first things we are doing will be to make a one-time contribution of 300,000 surgical masks for active drivers. These masks are intended for drivers to offer to passengers who are unwell but do not have a mask and need a ride to seek medical attention. More support measures will be announced in the coming weeks.

Today’s feedback session was useful and we will take them into consideration when developing the additional measures.

The pervasiveness of social media has changed the way we receive and react to information and news. In the current rapidly evolving nCoV situation, deliberate online falsehoods can spread more widely and quickly than the facts.

In an interview with CNBC last week, I emphasised that it is important to ensure that the public has access to accurate and up-to-date information. We also need to take swift action against the spread of falsehoods that can sow fear and cause panic in our society.

Gov.sg’s Whatsapp is one channel where the public can turn to for regular updates and information on the nCoV situation in all four languages. Residents have told me that they appreciate having such timely updates. Together, we can take a firm stand against falsehoods and help one another to overcome this challenge.

But it troubled me when students told me that some members of the public had shunned them in uniform, even going so far as to refuse to serve them!

This is not what we stand for in Singapore, and I’m sure the few don’t reflect the larger population.

As I shared with the school, it’s important to remember that how we treat the affected people could be how the rest of the world treats us Singaporeans. They could avoid us, just because we have confirmed cases of nCoV infections.

I’m cheered that many students also expressed their desire for school life to go on as far as possible, with precautions, and despite some calls for school closures. Coronavirus: Fighting a psychological battle

Lee Hsien Loong
10 February 2020 at 10:19 ·

When I spoke to Singaporeans on Saturday, I described fighting the coronavirus on two fronts — the medical and, more importantly, the psychological.

This The Straits Times article explains how small and close-knit societies like Singapore are prone to herd mentality and mass behaviour. Drawing on lessons from SARS, it outlines three ways we can practise psychological defence — by not ostracising frontline medical personnel, not going into lockdown and shutting down businesses, and finally, not succumbing to racist and xenophobic thoughts and actions.

Do not let fear and paranoia overwhelm our better selves. We can overcome this current challenge by keeping calm, staying united and supporting one another. – LHL

STRAITSTIMES.COM
Those flouting leave of absence rules face action

Josephine Teo
8 February 2020 at 00:11 ·

HELPING EMPLOYERS OF WORK PASS HOLDERS WITH CHINA TRAVEL HISTORY

We have both Singaporeans and work pass holders (WPHs) who may have visited China recently and have yet to return. I thought it would be timely to address a few recurring questions on the WPHs.

Why not get them to return later?

We are already doing so. Employers now have to seek MOM’s approval before bringing back these WPHs [https://go.gov.sg/mom-wphs requirements-for-employers-with-wph-returning-from-china]. It would be very helpful if employers voluntarily defer their return. However, we are mindful that not all employers can do so without severely disrupting their business. If this happens, their local employees will also be affected.

What happens when these WPHs return?

For returning WPHs (and likewise, Singaporeans), there are multiple layers of health and temperature checks before and when they arrive in #Singapore. Once here, they must observe a mandatory 14-day leave of absence (LOA) as an extra precaution, and minimise social contact. Singapore Ministry of Manpower takes the mandatory LOA very seriously – we will require regular reporting, and also conduct spot checks. Penalties for individuals caught flouting the rules includes the cancellation of their work passes and repatriation.

What if they cannot find suitable accommodation to serve their LOA?

If these WPHs and their employers are unable to find suitable accommodation, we will not approve their return in the first place. However, we understand that there are companies who need to bring back their workers to keep their businesses running. If employers have difficulties finding accommodation, MOM will help to link them up with available dorm operators.

We greatly appreciate the support and cooperation of the business community during this period. – Jo Teo

[The link to The Straits Times article is here: https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/those-flouting-leave-of-absence-rules-face-action]

Desmond Lee
7 February 2020 at 14:59 ·

We are now in Dorscon Orange as there are a few local cases of 2019-novel coronavirus without any links to previous cases or travel history to China. As such, we are putting in place further safeguards for our preschools and social service facilities that look after seniors and persons with disability.

From tomorrow, 8 February, all preschools, residential and community-based facilities serving vulnerable groups (such as children, the elderly and persons with disability) will:

(a) Restrict the entry of casual visitors to minimise the risk of community transmission.

(b) Limit the movement of staff across different preschools and facilities.

In addition, our residential and community-based facilities will:

(c) Allow only a maximum of two designated caregivers/visitors per enrolled client/resident.

(d) Increase temperature screening to twice daily, if not already the practice.

We also encourage users of our MSF frontline services (including when submitting Baby Bonus/Lasting Power of Attorney forms at service counters, or walk-in registrations for marriage solemnisations at ROM) to avoid crowds by using our online services, or contact us by email/post instead. You can reach us at go.gov.sg/msfcontactus

I seek the understanding of parents, caregivers and staff who may be inconvenienced by these tighter measures. Let’s continue to work together to stay safe and healthy.

Press Releases

Ong Ye Kung
7 February 2020 at 14:07 ·

Today MOH confirmed 3 new cases of the 2019-nCoV infection. Among them is a JC teacher. She was last in VJC on 31 Jan and only developed symptoms on 2 Feb.

The school has taken a slew of precautionary measures, including asking the class she taught in, and colleagues in close contact with her, to take a Leave of Absence. VJC has disinfected the school thoroughly, having more tutorial classes instead of large lectures, and suspending CCAs for two weeks.

I spoke with the teacher on the phone earlier this evening. She felt bad about what happened, but I assured her it was not her fault. What we are doing are necessary precautions to keep our schools safe. I also wished her speedy recovery.

System wide, we have implemented enhanced measures - suspending inter-school activities and external activities until the end of the March school holidays. This is to reduce the mixing of students across schools and exposure to large crowds at public places. We have also put in place a stringent hygiene regime, ensuring students and staff practise good personal hygiene, and also social hygiene protocols such as wiping down surfaces after use.

Some parents have suggested suspending schools. But this is a drastic move that will disrupt life for many families, and it is also not realistic to expect older children to stay home the whole time school is closed.

Should there be wide community spread - which we hope will not happen - and given all the measures we have taken, schools may actually be one of the safest places for our students. We are calling on our 33,000 educators to make that happen.

We will continue to monitor the situation and do the necessary steps to keep our people safe.

<DORSCON Orange>

Given the emergence of new cases in Singapore with no links to previous cases or with no recent travel history to China, there is now indication of community spread of the virus. Hence the Taskforce has decided to raise our alert levels to DORSCON Orange, with additional precautionary measures:

- Event organisers are advised to cancel/defer large-scale non-essential events. Those that wish to proceed should take all necessary precautions including temperature screening, and denying entry to those with respiratory symptoms and recent travel history to China

- All employers and individuals should do regular temperature taking twice daily. Those with a fever should see a doctor promptly.

- All organisations should step up their Business Continuity Plans. This can include telecommuting or operating in split teams.

We are also taking extra precautions in our hospitals, schools/preschools and eldercare organisations to protect our children, elderly and vulnerable groups.

I know many Singaporeans are anxious and worried about the spread of the virus. The government will continue to do everything we can to contain and ring-fence every case we identify, and prevent broader community spread. You can help too by taking these three measures to protect yourself and your family:
- Wash your hands frequently with soap
- Avoid shaking hands (use other forms of greeting) and avoid touching your face with your hands
- Take your temperature regularly and see a doctor immediately if you have a fever

If we continue to stand together and look out for each other, I am confident we can overcome this challenging situation.

Singapore's Support for China's Efforts to Overcome The 2019 Novel Coronavirus Outbreak

Heng Swee Keat
7 February 2020 at 04:59 ·

The 2019-novel coronavirus is a global public health challenge. I spoke to PRC Vice-Premier Han Zheng earlier today. I conveyed my condolences and sympathies to the families who have lost their loved ones to the outbreak, and to the communities in China which have been severely affected by the 2019-nCoV outbreak.

I reiterated to Vice-Premier Han that Singapore will continue to work closely with China and the international community to fight the virus — this includes preventing its further spread and developing better medical testing.

In times like this, with the longstanding special relationship between Singapore and China, it is also important for us to work together.

Singapore researchers have worked to develop diagnostic nCoV test kits for use in laboratories. We can contribute to China’s containment efforts by providing test kits to conduct 10,000 tests at the first instance, together with 3 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) machines. We will be providing another 10,000 tests in the next couple of weeks. Our scientific experts are also exchanging views with their counterparts in China.

Earlier this week, the Singapore Red Cross, together with various trade associations and chambers, companies and local community organisations, launched a public appeal to raise funds to provide humanitarian assistance to the affected communities in China. The Singapore Government will also contribute $1 million in seed funding to this collective effort by Singaporeans.

Infectious diseases are transboundary in nature. Countries can only overcome this challenge by stepping up measures within each country, and by collaborating with one another.

Singapore will continue to do our part — enhancing our safeguards as the situation evolves, and working with China and the international community to combat this outbreak.

I am confident we can overcome this challenge together.

#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether

Lawrence Wong
6 February 2020 at 14:34 ·

<Stepping up the Leave of Absence Regime>

We had earlier put in place the Leave of Absence (LOA) regime for all returning travellers, including Singaporeans/PRs, from the rest of China (i.e. outside of Hubei province). They were assessed to be of lower risk (compared to Hubei travellers) and were not quarantined, but we required them to serve out a 14-day LOA at their homes.

But given the escalating situation in China, we have decided to step up the entire LOA regime, which is mandatory. Specifically we will further enhance the monitoring and surveillance system with regular video/phone calls and spot checks, and impose penalties for non-compliance. So whether one is on home quarantine or LOA, the requirements will be strictly upheld, and we will ensure all comply with the rules.

For returning PRC workers, we will also require their employers to notify MOM before their workers return, so we can push back and stagger their arrivals over a longer period of time. For those with genuine difficulties finding suitable accommodations, we will work with the employers to identify suitable dorm facilities for the workers to serve out the LOA. I visited a dorm in Tuas with Manpower Minister Josephine Teo and I’m glad that the dorm operators are also helping to prepare spaces for the returning workers.

In the end all of us must do our part. Individuals under quarantine or LOA must comply with the requirements strictly; employers must take responsibility for their returning workers; landlords and dorm operators can also help by making their spaces available for workers to serve the home quarantine or LOA. That’s how we can all fight and contain the virus together

As of 6 February 2020, 2pm, we have confirmed two additional cases of 2019 novel coronavirus infection in Singapore. Of these, one case is a close contact of a previously confirmed case. The other case has no recent travel history to mainland China and does not appear to be linked with previous cases. This case was confirmed late last night and contact tracing is still in progress, with focus on identifying any links it may have with past cases or travellers from China. We will provide further updates tomorrow as the investigations progress.

Thus far all our previously announced confirmed cases have been either PRC travellers from Hubei, or individuals with links to PRC travellers. All such cases have been isolated and ring-fenced. But we must be prepared for the possibility of new infection clusters involving locals within the community, not linked with recent travel to China or contact with recent PRC travellers. This has already happened in several places outside of mainland China. We had earlier stepped up significantly our precautionary measures to reduce the risk of community spread of the virus. We stand ready to ramp up our measures even more once we have some findings from the ongoing investigations.

I went down to Chinatown yesterday together with NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng 黄志明 to find out how the shops and workers are coping with the evolving 2019-nCoV (#NovelCoronovirus) situation.

Employees too can play a part by observing their own personal hygiene, such as washing their hands more frequently, and seek medical attention promptly if they are unwell.

With the world’s population aged over 60 almost doubling from 12% to 22% between now and 2050, the question of how we can continue to create opportunities for seniors to stay healthy and connected to the community, and to delay the onset of frailty is something many nations are concerned about.

The Ministry of Health (MOH) has worked with government agencies and our partners to empower seniors to stay active and healthy. For instance, under the National Seniors Health Programme, over 550,000 seniors in the community have been reached through health talks and exercise programmes. Seniors are also connected to active ageing programmes, befriending and care and support services by Silver Generation Ambassadors who proactively reach out to them.

While MOH works with various public and private stakeholders to continually create such opportunities, we are also aware that seniors in the future will have different needs and aspirations from seniors of today. Therefore, fresh ideas are always needed. It is for this reason that NRF and MOH have partnered with the U.S. National Academy of Medicine’s (NAM) to launch the Catalyst Awards to reward bold, innovative ideas from any discipline that could extend the human health span through disease prevention, mobility, functionality, social connectedness, longevity, and more. I hope Singaporeans will step up to participate in the competition to uncover some breakthroughs in fostering healthy longevity that will benefit the seniors in our community, and perhaps, even the rest of the world.

More details on the Awards can be found here: https://nmrc.gov.sg/grants/competitive-research-grants/healthy-longevity-catalyst-award

What we know about the 6 new cases of novel coronavirus in Singapore

Heng Swee Keat
4 February 2020 at 14:23 ·

6 new cases of the 2019-novel coronavirus were confirmed today, including:
- 2 cases who were evacuated back from Wuhan on 30 January; and
- 4 cases of local transmission.

Local transmission occurs when the source of the infection can be identified. In these 4 cases, two staff at a shop serving tourists from China, and their tour guide were in close contact with the tourists. The fourth person is a domestic helper of one of the staff.

Ministry of Health, Singapore is now doing contact tracing to identify contacts of the cases, to quarantine them and to minimise the risk of spread. In this way, we can reduce the risk of further transmission by closely monitoring the cluster of contacts.

As of now, Minister Gan Kim Yong noted that there is no evidence of a widespread sustained community transmission. A widespread community transmission happens when confirmed cases have no linkages to possible contact source of infection. There is no evidence of this, but we must remain vigilant.

Glad that one of the earlier confirmed cases, a Wuhan resident, has been cleared of the virus and discharged from the National Centre of Infectious Diseases. Our frontline staff at our hospitals are working very hard, so let us support them, and also wish all the affected patients a speedy recovery.

Ministry of Education, Singapore and MSF Singapore are taking additional measures for our students in our pre-schools, primary and secondary schools, special education (SPED) schools, junior colleges, and Millennia Institute. They will suspend camps, assemblies and mass gatherings. You can read about this here: http://bit.ly/MOE-4Feb

As the situation evolves, we will put in additional measures accordingly. Our current travel restrictions will continue to help contain the risk of spread but there is still a risk that the situation may get worse. Should that happen, the Taskforce will consider additional measures to reduce human-to-human interactions, to protect the well-being of our people.

I hope that Singaporeans can remain calm, stay vigilant, and continue to take care of your own personal hygiene. Together, we can get through this.

#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether

Minister for Health Gan Kim Yong delivered a Ministerial Statement in Parliament today, to provide updates on the 2019 novel coronavirus situation and healthcare-related measures that we have put in place.

We have set up multiple lines of defence to reduce the risk of imported cases and local community transmission:

1) To prevent further importation of the virus into our shores, we have introduced measures such as temperature and health screening at all checkpoints, as well as international travel controls.

2) To detect and contain the virus, and prevent it from spreading further, we have good surveillance systems to identify cases. Our healthcare providers are right at the frontline, and are on heightened alert and ready to deal with cases as they emerge.

3) Most importantly, all of us must play our part and exercise social responsibility, to prevent or stem any possible spread of the virus in the community. Do continue to practise good personal hygiene – wash your hands regularly with soap and water, and avoid touching your face with your hands.

These measures, when taken together, will improve our resilience and ability to respond to this disease.

Our heartfelt thanks as well to our healthcare family, who have worked tireless over the last few weeks to keep Singapore safe.

Read more in the Ministerial Statement: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/ministerial-statement-on-whole-of-government-response-to-the-2019-novel-coronavirus-(2019-ncov)

Chan Chun Sing added a new photo to the album Visit to Oasia Downtown Hotel.
2 February 2020 at 11:02 ·

Visited Oasia Downtown Hotel with Minister Josephine Teo this afternoon where we met with senior management and staff from the hotel. We were briefed on the additional measures that the hotel is taking in light of the novel coronavirus situation and how the company is supporting both guests and staff during this period.

It has not been an easy time for those in the tourism sector. Revenue is declining for businesses and workers have had to take on more responsibility and duties to ensure the health and safety of customers. But I was very happy to see during my visit that the staff at Oasia Downtown were still in good spirits and understood why the additional precautions are necessary.

During my visit, I also announced that the Singapore Tourism Board will be implementing targeted measures to support our tourism businesses during this period. We will waive license fees for hotels, travel agents and tourist guides and defray enhanced cleaning costs of hotels that provided accommodation to confirmed and suspected cases of nCoV infections.

The new measures announced today may not be very big but they are a signal to our tourism companies that we have heard their concerns and stand ready to support them.

During these challenging times, cash flow is a key concern for businesses. I encourage businesses who need more support to tap on Enterprise Singapore’s Enterprise Financing Scheme to address their financing needs. We will also look at further enhancing support in the form of temporary bridging loans.

For aviation-related companies who have been impacted due to a decrease in overseas travellers, we will provide assistance to defray business costs and help maintain air connectivity between Singapore and China. Taxi and private hire car drivers whose income may be affected due to the sudden decline in visitor arrivals will also be provided with more assistance.

The state of the global economy today is very different from 2003 when SARS happened. China in particular has much deeper linkages with other economies around the world. While it is still too early to tell the exact impact of the nCoV, I want to assure businesses that we will continue to walk this journey with them and provide them the necessary support. Our workers also remain our key priority and we want to ensure that we preserve as many jobs as we can during this challenging period. CCS

Getting through this together

Yesterday, 1500 SAF personnel were mobilised to pack 5.2 million surgical masks for distribution to households. The first batches are rolling out to the constituencies. They will continue to do this round the clock for the next few days until the task is completed.

Even as they packed, grassroots leaders and volunteers responded to the call to the community for help with the mask distribution at the RC and neighbourhood centres which which starts today and will continue over several days.

In the hospitals our medical healthcare workers are at the frontline, working hard to take care of those who are unwell and having to be extra careful as they are more exposed than others to the risk of infections.

At our airports, ports and land checkpoints, our immigration personnel are working overtime on temperature checks and spotting anyone who may have symptoms of the Wuhan virus.

In pre-schools and schools teachers have to be vigilant and look out for our students children.

Behind the scenes, the civil service has been putting into operation contingency plans, adjusting and responding at short notice as and when new scenarios arise.

Yesterday, the Scoot crew - volunteers all - flew to Wuhan and brought our Singaporeans home. There were some Singaporeans who could not come back as they had symptoms, but they are certainly not forgotten. Our embassy in China is in touch with them to ensure their welfare, and we hope the conditions will be clear for them to come back as soon as possible.

Different sectors, different people. But all working tirelessly to get us through this situation. This is what it means to work together and to pull together.

A big thank you to all these heroes and the many others who are quietly going about their jobs or volunteering their time and effort so that we can beat this virus.

In this situation we all have a part to play and every action counts.
- be vigilant
- follow the advisories on usage of masks
- wash your hands with soap and water regularly
- be patient and understanding too.
- go to trusted sources for information.

We will get through this together.

<New travel restrictions>

The virus outbreak in China is spreading beyond Hubei province. The number of reported infection cases has doubled to over 9,000. Significantly, the virus has spread to every region of mainland China. The likelihood of widespread community transmission in other parts of China is now high. We are likely to see a sharper rise in the local transmission of the virus in other Chinese cities in the coming days.

We have therefore decided to expand our travel restrictions to all new travelers arriving from mainland China. In particular all new visitors (regardless of nationality) with travel history in China in the last 14 days will not be allowed to enter into Singapore or to transit through Singapore.

Returning Singaporeans, PRs and long-term pass holders who have travelled in China will be allowed to enter Singapore, but they will be put on a 14-day leave of absence. They will be issued a health advisory to stay at home and avoid social contact.

We are not letting up on our efforts to fight the virus. Across the Government, public officials are working hard to respond to this challenging situation - be it our healthcare workers at the frontline, our medical teams at the airport, ICA officers at checkpoints, SAF personnel and PA staff at the mask packing/distribution centres; or our officials at the quarantine facilities. Businesses are also doing their part to take precautions, and individuals are practicing good personal hygiene habits.

This is the Singapore spirit which will see us through all challenges. We can and will get through this together!

In view of the growing possibility of transmission from new travellers arriving from other parts of mainland China, we have assessed that it is prudent to take additional pre-emptive measures at this stage.

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce on the Wuhan Coronavirus has decided to take further steps to limit the potential risk that new travellers arriving from mainland China pose to Singapore.

From 1 February 2020, 2359h, all new visitors with recent travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days will not be allowed entry into Singapore, or to transit through Singapore.

With immediate effect, the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) (@Immigration.Checkpoints.Authority) will suspend: (i) the issuance of all forms of new visas to those with PRC passports, (ii) Singapore’s status as a visa-free transit facility for those with PRC passports, and (iii) previously issued short-term and multiple-visit visas for those with PRC passports.

With immediate effect, all residents (Singaporean Citizens/ PRs) with recent travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days; and Long-term pass holders (including Work Passes and Permits, Student Pass, Dependent Pass and Long-term Visit Pass) with recent travel history to mainland China within the last 14 days, will be issued an advisory for them to be placed on a 14-day leave of absence from the day of their return from China.

There remains no evidence of community spread in Singapore, and these latest measures are aimed at minimising the risk of this occurring.

Read more in the press release: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/extension-of-precautionary-measures-to-minimise-risk-of-community-spread-in-singapore

Lee Hsien Loong is at NCID National Centre for Infectional Diseases.
31 January 2020 at 10:03 · Singapore ·

It has been a stressful week not just for the general public, but in particular for healthcare and medical professionals.

We have watched the new coronavirus outbreak in China closely, from the moment the first news came out. Actually we have been preparing for such a situation ever since SARS in 2003. We knew that one day something like that would happen again. So, in a way, this outbreak was a shock, but not a surprise.

9 of the 13 confirmed cases in Singapore are currently being treated at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID), next to Tan Tock Seng Hospital. I urge everyone to show understanding and support to our healthcare and medical teams, public officers, the SAF and The People's Association, who will be distributing masks to Singaporeans over the weekend. We owe them our gratitude for their hard work and dedication.

I have every confidence that if we stay vigilant and united, we can overcome this challenge. – LHL

Lawrence Wong

<Masks for all Households; Use Responsibly>

We have sufficient masks in the national stockpile if everyone uses them responsibly. Responsible usage means following medical advice - only those who are sick need to wear masks; for those who are well, there is no need to wear masks.

Over the last 9 days, we released more than 5 million masks from the national stockpile to retailers. They were snapped up in hours. Yet many Singaporeans are still unable to get a mask. The current situation is clearly not sustainable.

This is why the Taskforce has decided to change our distribution method, as my colleague Chan Chun Sing and I announced this morning. First, we will prioritise the national stockpile of masks for essential services, namely our healthcare workers at the frontline. Second, for the general public we will release masks from the national stockpile directly to Singaporeans. In particular we will provide a packet of 4 masks each for every local household.

We are doing this to assure all Singaporeans that if any member of the family falls sick and needs a mask, they will have one at hand. But remember to use the masks responsibly. Do not wear the masks immediately. Keep this as a precaution and use the masks only if someone in the family falls sick and needs to go out to see the doctor.

I know many Singaporeans are concerned about the virus and want to protect themselves and their families. The best thing to do is to uphold good personal hygiene. Wash your hands regularly with soap; do not use your hands to touch your face; if you are sick, see a doctor and stay at home until you recover.

With individual and collective responsibility, we can maintain a strong defence against the virus, and overcome this together.

Chan Chun Sing
30 January 2020 at 05:45 ·

During a media conference with Minister Lawrence Wong this afternoon, we announced that the Government will issue four surgical masks to each household from this weekend.

The masks are for residents to use when they are unwell and going to seek medical help. Upon medical assistance, healthcare professionals will be able to assess the subsequent need for more surgical masks.

During times of uncertainty, it is natural that some will take to hoarding in-demand supplies such as masks. We understand this. But such behaviour is not helpful to our collective defence and we seek Singaporeans’ understanding that the priority for our mask stockpile will have to go to our frontline healthcare workers and the most vulnerable in our society.

We are actively working on identifying new suppliers for in-demand items and will also ensure that existing lines are kept robust. However, in these uncertain times, we must be mindful that there is keen competition from others to secure their supplies as well. Many global suppliers are prioritising China because it is the epicenter of the outbreak. Places such as Taiwan have also banned the export of surgical masks and we expect more to follow suit.

We are also aware of concerns about profiteering. Today, the Price Controller will issue warning letters to retailers such as Deen Express suspected of profiteering. We have also sent notification letters to e-commerce platforms to cooperate with MTI and provide us with requested information on errant sellers on their platforms.

These are challenging times and people are fearful. We understand and want to do all we can to reassure Singaporeans. By providing each household with their own set of masks, we hope to address concerns about the purchase of masks and allow our supplies to return to normalcy. I thank Singaporeans for their understanding and patience during this period and we will continue to work hard to contain the spread of the Wuhan Coronavirus. CCS

Ong Ye Kung
29 January 2020 at 11:47 ·

Schools reopened today after the Chinese New Year break. I decided to visit a couple of primary schools and was only allowed in after having my temperature taken. Good to know no one is exempted!

It was pretty much business as usual. Many students were happy to go back to school. They went about their lessons, played at recess, went for learning journeys. I popped into a P1 and P5 class at Bendemeer Primary, as well as chatted with students in an after school programme at Zhangde Primary.

I practised my teaching pedagogy and got the students to discuss how viruses transmit via droplets through sneezes and coughs, and let them derive at how best to protect themselves against transmission.

The verdict was the same across the classes: (a)wash our hands regularly with soap, (b) keep our hands away from our faces, and (c) wear a mask if we are sick so that our droplets don’t infect others.

I also spoke to teachers, including the team at Zhangde Primary working to help students from vulnerable backgrounds. They shared with me their challenges, and the specific cases which made progress on. They know the name of every child. They know they are making a difference to each of the kids under their charge.

I also met student volunteers from Singapore Polytechnic who mentor the students. I see the sparkle and enthusiasm in their eyes.

Life has to go on and we must continue to make our difference to society. The students, teachers and staff I met today were calm and resolute. Today I witnessed societal resilience.

[ElderFund to launch on 31 Jan]

Happy to share that applications for ElderFund will start from 31 Jan 2020. This is a new disability assistance scheme we announced last year.

ElderFund is an additional safety net to help lower-income and severely disabled Singaporeans with their basic long-term care needs. It will supplement existing Government, community and family support in providing for the needs of disabled Singaporeans.

Severely disabled Singapore Citizens aged 30 and above who are unable to benefit from ElderShield and Interim Disability Assistance Programme for the Elderly (IDAPE), or the future CareShield Life, and have low income and low MediSave balances, can apply for ElderFund.

Successful applicants can get up to $250 cash payout every month.

We estimate that in the next 10 years, on average, about 9,000 Singaporeans per year can potentially benefit from ElderFund. We hope that ElderFund can go some way to provide peace of mind to Singaporeans who need an extra helping hand.

For more information on how to apply for ElderFund, including how to be assessed for severe disability, please contact the Agency for Integrated Care - AIC Singapore at 1800-650-6060 or visit www.aic.sg/ElderFund.

Lawrence Wong
28 January 2020 at 09:16 ·

<Wuhan coronavirus - additional measures>

I mentioned yesterday that the situation is evolving rapidly, and the key is for us to be able to swiftly adjust and recalibrate our actions.

Over the last 24 hours, we have seen an accelerating trend of infection among the population of Chinese nationals from Hubei. Within Singapore, we’ve had a near doubling of imported cases overnight. All the confirmed cases are Chinese nationals from Hubei. Within China, the numbers are rising sharply too. The vast majority of cases in Chinese cities can also be traced back to Hubei.

Given the heightened risks from Hubei travellers, we have decided to take additional measures on top of those announced yesterday to limit these risks:

First, there are recent travellers from Hubei who are now in Singapore. There are 2000 of them here, including Singaporeans/PRs and tourists. We are getting in touch with all of them, and will quarantine those with higher risks (particularly the ones who arrived more recently and are still within the incubation period).

Second, there is a group of returning residents (Singaporeans/PRs) and long-term pass holders, i.e they are in China now and will likely return over the coming days after the CNY holidays. We will also quarantine those amongst them with recent travel history in Hubei or with PRC passports issued in Hubei.

Third, for new PRC visitors, the numbers are already coming down, but we will take extra precautions. For those with recent travel history to Hubei or PRC passports issued in Hubei, we will not allow them entry into Singapore or transit through Singapore. ICA will suspend issuance of new visas to those with PRC passports issued in Hubei; all previously issued visas will also be suspended.

We have a comprehensive plan with contingencies for different scenarios. These measures are part of our plans. Given the accelerating trends and risk levels, we’ve decided to activate them now.

We have to be mindful that the situation is fluid, with new information coming out from China every day, and with our risk assessments being updated constantly. There are signs now that the virus is more transmissible than SARS although less fatal. But we can’t tell how things will unfold. We have to be prepared that this Wuhan virus may well be different from SARS, including the possibility of infection before any symptoms arise. We cannot rule out the possibility of wider infection and community spread.

So we will monitor closely and adjust our posture day by day. We are now taking stricter measures against Hubei travelers. If there is evidence of community spread in other Chinese cities or provinces, we will update our measures accordingly.

There is so far no evidence of community spread in Singapore. So our actions are aimed at containment - to reduce the risk of such community spread. Meanwhile let’s all stay calm and keep our guard up. The Taskforce will continue with our approach of vigilant monitoring and swift actions to protect Singaporeans.

Lee Hsien Loong
28 January 2020 at 10:25 ·

I have received many messages from you expressing concerns about the Wuhan coronavirus. I fully understand your feelings. We are all worried for ourselves and our loved ones, here and overseas.

The situation is developing rapidly. We have activated our contingency plans, and all our agencies are working together. Our hospitals and healthcare workers are well prepared. We have been preparing for something like this ever since SARS in 2003.

Meanwhile, scientists and medical professionals across the world are working around the clock to understand the virus and develop a vaccine. Experts think the Wuhan virus may be less lethal than SARS, but more infectious. Patients who are infected may possibly be contagious before symptoms show. If true, this will make it harder to screen and detect new cases, and to stop the spread.

So far, all seven confirmed cases in Singapore are Chinese nationals from Hubei. We have not had local transmission or community spread yet, but that can happen, and we must be prepared for it. Meanwhile, we have suspended entry into or transit through Singapore for people who have recently travelled to Hubei, and those with PRC passports issued in Hubei. We will quarantine Singapore residents and those holding long term passes who are returning here, who have recently visited Hubei.

We will continue to monitor the situation closely and do more if necessary. Meanwhile, we should all remain calm. All of us can do our part to limit transmission of germs by practising good hygiene. Wash your hands regularly, and seek medical advice early and wear a mask if you feel unwell. But in general, there is no need to wear a mask if you are not ill.

Also please do not listen to or spread rumours and untrue reports — alas there is a lot of that circulating around, on WhatsApp and social media. Sharing news responsibly is an important way we can protect ourselves.

You may have noticed that some retailers have started to ration the sale of masks (in packages with smaller quantity). This is to ensure that there is adequate supply for Singaporeans and to prevent unnecessary hoarding. We are also working with retailers to manage pricing and we remind them not to profiteer from the increased demand.

As there is currently no local transmission of the 2019-nCoV infection, masks are generally not needed in our normal daily activities. However, do put on a face mask if you have respiratory symptoms like a cough or runny nose to prevent the spread of the flu or the common cold viruses. Above all, practise good personal hygiene by washing your hands frequently. If you are feeling unwell, please seek medical attention promptly.

We urge Singaporeans to stay calm and vigilant to #FightAgainst2019nCoV.

Wuhan virus: Increased border checks, leave of absence among new counter-measures

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
27 January 2020 at 04:53 ·

The Ministerial Task Force on the Novel Coronavirus Infection (MTF-NCI) announced additional measures to protect Singaporeans against the 2019-nCoV. These include the following:

1) Temperature Screening at airports will cover all incoming flights with additional scrutiny of passengers from mainland China, especially those holding passports from Hubei province.

2) Singaporeans are advised to avoid non-essential travel to mainland China. This is on top of the previous travel advisory to avoid all travel to Hubei province.

3) Returning workers and students from mainland China will have to give health and travel declarations to their respective organisations and do self monitoring of symptoms and temperature twice a day for 14 days upon their return.

- for those who may have close contacts with vulnerable populations, such as those in preschools, schools, healthcare sector and ElderCare sectors, will be given compulsory 14 days leave of absence (LOA) so they can stay at home and minimise close contact with others.

Other organisations are recommended to follow these measures as well. Employers may adopt additional precautionary measures if they choose to do so, depending on their operational requirements.

As the situation is evolving very rapidly, the MTF will monitor developments very closely. The government will implement additional measures, if necessary.
All of us have a role to play to keep the virus at bay. Together we can #FightAgainst2019nCoV!

Ministry of Health, Singapore

🍊🍊🍊 Happy Chinese New Year to all Singaporeans 🍊🍊🍊

Yesterday morning, I visited our healthcare colleagues at the Ng Teng Fong General Hospital and JurongHealth Campus to thank them for their hard work and dedication.

Glad to have had our colleagues from the hospitals’ Inpatient Operations, Food Services, as well as Environmental Services teams join us for a lo hei session. We may not see them very often, but they are also very important in ensuring our patients receive the care they need.

Two of them were Chef Richard Woo and Chef Elton Hoo, who prepared the lo hei for us (that had smoked salmon fish shaped in a koi and ingot). A yearly affair, the hospital’s kitchen and dieticians worked together on a special dinner menu on the eve of Chinese New Year, to bring some festive cheer to patients. The festive meal sets included dishes like fresh crabmeat with silken tofu bisque, stewed treasure duck or chicken with sea cucumber, braised long cabbage with crispy dried scallop, and chilled lemongrass jelly with wolfberries.

I also met 83 year-old Mr Chua Kim Hong, who was in good spirits and waiting for his son to pick him up to go home to celebrate Chinese New Year.

With the coronavirus situation escalating globally, we know that this is a challenging time for the healthcare family. We really appreciate your dedication and commitment during this period. Please take care and persevere on – we are fully behind you. 💪🏻

Here’s wishing all our healthcare family and all Singaporeans a happy and healthy Chinese New Year! 🧧

The fourth confirmed case is a 36 year-old male Chinese national from Wuhan who arrived in Singapore with his family on 22 January. He is currently warded in an isolation room at Sengkang General Hospital (SKH) and his condition is stable.

He was classified as a suspect case and immediately isolated. Subsequent test results confirmed Wuhan coronavirus infection at about 9.30pm on 25 January.

We have on 23 January 2020 confirmed one imported case of novel coronavirus infection in Singapore. The case is a 66 year-old male Chinese national from Wuhan who arrived in Singapore with his family on 20 January 2020. He is currently warded in an isolation room at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) and his condition is stable. He was immediately isolated upon presenting to SGH with clinical symptoms.

The multi-ministry taskforce set up to direct a whole-of-government response to the novel coronavirus pneumonia outbreak has decided to step up Singapore’s overall preventive posture, given the expected inflow of visitors during the festive season and in view of the confirmed case. This would include expanding our border controls, to include land and sea checkpoints.

Singapore will also expand our travel advisory to recommend that Singaporeans avoid travel to the whole of Hubei Province, in view of the travel restrictions that China has imposed on Huanggang and Ezhou. We advise Singaporeans to continue to exercise caution and attention to personal hygiene when travelling to the rest of China.

Given the high volume of international travel to Singapore, we expect to see more suspect cases and imported cases. We urge the public to remain calm and vigilant, and to adopt good personal hygiene practices.

Amy Khor
22 January 2020 at 04:41 ·

The Singapore General Hospital campus has come a long way from its early days at Sepoy Lines. Affectionately known to many as “See Pai Poh”, the SGH Campus today is home to specialist centres like Duke-NUS Medical School, Academia and Outram Community Hospital, in addition to the main SGH.

Today, I attended the ground-breaking ceremony of the new SGH Elective Care Centre and National Dental Centre Singapore - NDCS which will form the first component of the new SGH Campus. This new building, sited right next to the exit of the North-East MRT line, will bring us one step closer to achieving increased connectivity.

Over the years, SGH has continued to innovate to bring better care and value to patients. For example, SGH has developed a new care protocol for patients undergoing hip replacement surgery, which enabled 80% of patients enrolled in the 2019 pilot to go home on the same day, or within 23 hours of their surgery, instead of staying in the hospital for an average of four days in 2016. The new NDCS will also leverage new technology to improve care delivery, such as 3D printing, which will allow for more accurate treatment planning and shorter treatment time.

As Singaporeans’ healthcare needs evolve, I hope that our public healthcare institutions will continue to innovate and provide the best health outcome and quality care to their patients.

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
21 January 2020 at 10:22 ·

The Ministry of Health, Singapore is putting in place additional precautionary measures to reduce the risk of importation of the novel coronavirus pneumonia to Singapore. This follows confirmation of human-to-human transmission, as well as increase in the number of cases and widened distribution of the virus in China.

From 22 January 2020, we will widen the definition of suspect cases to include persons with the following:

(i) Pneumonia and travel history to China within 14 days before onset of symptoms; or

(ii) Acute respiratory infection who had been to any hospital in China, within 14 days before onset of symptoms.

These cases will be isolated in hospital as a precautionary measure to prevent transmission.

Temperature screening at Changi Airport will also be expanded to cover all inbound travellers on flights arriving from China from tomorrow. Suspect cases meeting the expanded definition will be referred to hospitals for further assessment.

Do stay vigilant and adopt good personal hygiene practices. We remind travellers to monitor your health closely and seek medical attention promptly if you feel unwell, and inform your doctor of your travel history.

The situation is evolving and investigations are still ongoing in China. If you need to travel to the affected areas, do check MOH’s website (www.moh.gov.sg) regularly for updates.

[MOH steps up precautionary measures]

In response to the increase in cases of novel coronavirus pneumonia in Wuhan and exported cases to other cities and countries, as well as the anticipated increase in travel volume in the lead up to the Chinese New Year holidays, MOH will expand temperature screening at Changi Airport and issue Health Advisory Notices for all inbound travellers on flights arriving from China from 22 January 2020.

Individuals with pneumonia and travel history to Wuhan within 14 days before onset of symptoms will be isolated in hospital as a precautionary measure to prevent transmission, and investigated.

This is in addition to the other precautionary measures that MOH has put in place since the start of January 2020.

MOH urges the public to remain vigilant and to adopt good personal hygiene practices. All travellers to Wuhan should monitor their health closely and seek medical attention promptly if they feel unwell, and also inform their doctor of their travel history.

For more information, please read our press release at https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moh-steps-up-precautionary-measures-in-response-to-increase-in-cases-of-novel-coronavirus-pneumonia-in-wuhan.

[Publication of Lists of Non-Compliant and Unlicensed Healthcare Service Providers and Practitioners on MOH website]

MOH’s priority is to ensure patient safety and welfare. Access to relevant information helps empower the public to make better informed healthcare decisions. From today, MOH will publish two lists on the MOH website to provide information about non-compliant and unlicensed healthcare providers and practitioners offering medical and/or dental services.

The lists name providers and practitioners who have been found to offer unlicensed healthcare services, as well as those who have been suspended or prosecuted for breaching the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act (PHMCA), Medical Registration Act (MRA) and/or Dental Registration Act (DRA). Providers and practitioners who have been suspended or terminated from the Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS), MediSave and/or MediShield schemes will also be listed. Both lists will be updated periodically to keep them current.

Besides the lists, MOH has taken several steps to empower the public to make more informed decisions. The HealthWatch (https://www.moh.gov.sg/healthwatch) platform, launched last year, provides tips and advice for those seeking healthcare services. Moving forward, we will continue to work towards enhancing public education efforts.

The lists can be accessed via the links below:
List of enforcement actions taken by MOH under the PHMCA, MRA and DRA – https://www.moh.gov.sg/enforcement-actions-for-breaches-of-regulatory-requirements
List of suspensions and revocations by MOH under CHAS, MediSave and MediShield Life – https://www.moh.gov.sg/suspensions-revocations-from-healthcare-financing-schemes

[More than Half of Private Ambulances Accredited Under MOH’s Voluntary Accreditation Scheme]

🚑🚑🚑 #didyouknow all private ambulances will be licensed under the new Healthcare Services Act in the second half of 2021? This will enhance patient care and ensure patient safety and welfare.

To help private ambulance operators prepare for these changes and start their transition into the licensing framework, MOH introduced the Voluntary Accreditation Scheme for private ambulance operators in 2018 to help them raise their capabilities and competencies, such as through the training of personnel. Today, 30 operators are already on this scheme, and more than 50 percent of the total number of private ambulances in Singapore are accredited. You can find the full list of accredited private ambulance operators at www.moh.gov.sg/licensing-and-regulation/accredited-private-ambulance-operators.

MOH will also bring about greater price transparency for consumers. We will work with the accredited operators to publish the range of common fees charged, so that consumers are able to make informed decisions on their choice of private ambulance operators.

For more information, check out https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/more-than-half-of-private-ambulances-accredited-under-voluntary-accreditation-scheme.

Amy Khor
12 January 2020 at 05:52 ·

“Eat more, rest more, don’t work so hard” - We often hear such well-meaning advice offered to pregnant women, but is it sound? Evidence suggests that physical activity and exercise in pregnancy may help limit gestational weight gain, as well as reduce the risk of Gestational Diabetes (GDM) in the expectant mother. It is critical that we tackle GDM, as it could lead to risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life for both mother and child.

I’m glad to see that a committee of healthcare professionals and clinicians have come together to develop the Guidelines on Physical Activity and Exercise in Pregnancy. Launched at the Asia Pacific Diabetes in Pregnancy Conference & IPRAMHO International Meeting at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, the guidelines will help healthcare professionals provide guidance to pregnant women on pre- and post-natal physical activity to achieve better pregnancy outcomes. This is indeed a positive step in raising awareness of appropriate exercise and weight management before, during and after pregnancy.

For expectant mothers, try this advice instead: “Eat healthy and engage in moderate-intensity physical activity regularly”. If you are unsure, do consult your doctor on the appropriate exercises that you can do.

[Update on local situation regarding severe pneumonia cluster in Wuhan]

Epidemiological investigations, clinical assessment and laboratory test results from the suspect case reported on 10 January 2020 involving a 26 year-old male Chinese national with pneumonia and travel history to Wuhan have found that the case is not linked to the pneumonia cluster in Wuhan. The case has also tested negative for coronavirus.

The Ministry of Health will continue to monitor the situation closely. As medical practitioners are on the lookout for cases with pneumonia who have recently returned from Wuhan, Singapore is likely to see more suspect cases that will need to be investigated for possible links to the Wuhan cluster.

We urge the public to remain vigilant and to adopt good personal hygiene practices at all times. Travellers to Wuhan should monitor their health closely and seek medical attention promptly if they feel unwell, and also inform their doctor of their travel history.

[New Senior Care Centre in Hougang]

Residents in Hougang can look forward to a new senior care centre in their neighbourhood! The Home Nursing Foundation’s HNF Wellness@Hougang which officially opened this morning is located in Hougang Community Club and well-positioned to collaborate with the community and enrich the suite of active ageing programmes offered to Hougang residents.

Many seniors prefer to remain in their communities and in the company of their family and friends as they age. We are glad that partners like HNF have been supporting seniors to age-in-place, and have expanded their range of services to better serve the different care needs of our seniors in the community.

Our heartiest congratulations to HNF on the launch of their first senior day care centre. We look forward to many more good years of partnership with them!

[Update on local situation regarding severe pneumonia cluster in Wuhan]

As of 10am, 10 January 2020, the Ministry of Health has been notified of a 26 year-old male Chinese national with pneumonia, who had travel history to Wuhan. He has been admitted for further assessment and treatment, and isolated as a precautionary measure. His condition is stable.

The suspect case has not visited the Huanan seafood wholesale market associated with the cluster of pneumonia in Wuhan.

Investigations to establish whether the suspect case is linked to the Wuhan pneumonia cluster are ongoing.

A message on influenza has been circulating on WhatsApp. We would like to clarify that the message is not from MOH. Influenza or the flu is spread mainly by droplets through an infected person coughing and sneezing. Keeping one’s throat moist does not prevent influenza.

If you receive the message over WhatsApp or other platforms, please do not forward it.

We can minimise the spread of flu by:
🚰 Washing our hands with soap before eating and after going to the toilet;
😷 Covering our mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing, and throwing tissue away into a bin immediately!
🏠 Staying at home when you are sick, and wearing a mask if you are going out; and
🙅 Avoid sharing food and drinks, eating utensils, toothbrushes or towels with those who display symptoms of influenza.

We advise those in high-risk groups – such as young children, pregnant women, the elderly, and those with weakened immune systems or chronic illnesses – to get vaccinated against influenza yearly.

Lam Pin Min（蓝彬明）
9 January 2020 at 15:14 ·

I was at Republic Polytechnic open house this afternoon where we launched the RP - ST Logistics Healthcare Supply Chain Laboratory. I also had the pleasure of meeting many young inquisitive minds including those behind the innovative projects featured in the joint lab.

The healthcare supply chain is a vast process with a complex network of products and players. Like all complex networks, it is vulnerable to risks of rising cost and disrupted services. But it also presents opportunities for greater cost effectiveness while ensuring safe care delivery to patients. With emerging technologies, such as RFID tracking and robotic process automation, the possibilities are endless.
I am glad that industry players and institutes of higher learning, such as RP and ST Logistics, are collaborating and creating a learning space for students to gain hands-on learning experience in the application of supply chain technologies. We must continue to develop talents and equip students with the relevant skills so that they are empowered to seize opportunities when they arise.

Ministry of Health, Singapore

[New Healthcare Services Bill for better patient safety and welfare]

The Healthcare Services (HCS) Bill was debated and passed in Parliament today to ensure that patient safety and well-being are safeguarded while our regulatory framework remains relevant to current and emerging models of care.

In recent years, there have been significant changes to the healthcare landscape in Singapore. While almost all healthcare services were previously provided from physical ‘brick-and-mortar’ locations, there are now new healthcare models and services, including home and community-based care and telemedicine services. These have emerged in response to technological advances, changing care needs of our population as well as changes in patient expectations. The new HCS Bill, which is a services-based licensing regime that replaces the old premises-based framework, will ensure the safe delivery of such new services in this evolving healthcare landscape.

The new framework will also provide the flexibility to accommodate new, patient-centric healthcare models and facilitates the development of new and innovative healthcare services that can benefit many more patients.

The HCS Bill will be implemented in phases from early 2021 to end 2022 and MOH will work closely with healthcare providers to ensure a smooth transition.

For more information, please read https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/opening-speech-for-second-reading-of-healthcare-services-bill-by-mr-edwin-tong-senior-minister-of-state-ministry-of-health-6-january-2020.

[Update on local situation regarding severe pneumonia cluster in Wuhan]

As of 3pm, 5 January 2020, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has not been notified of any new suspect cases.

Epidemiological investigations, clinical assessment and laboratory test results from the suspect case reported on 4 January 2020 involving a 3 year-old female Chinese national with pneumonia and travel history to Wuhan have found that the case is not linked to the pneumonia cluster in Wuhan. The case has also tested negative for SARS and MERS-CoV. The cause of her pneumonia is Respiratory Syncytial Virus, a common cause for childhood respiratory infection.

As medical practitioners are on the lookout for cases with pneumonia who have recently returned from Wuhan, Singapore is likely to see more suspect cases that will need to be investigated for possible links to the Wuhan cluster. MOH will continue to monitor the situation closely. We urge the public to remain vigilant and to adopt good personal hygiene practices at all times. Travellers to Wuhan should monitor their health closely and seek medical attention promptly if they feel unwell, and also inform their doctor of their travel history.

[Update on local situation regarding severe pneumonia cluster in Wuhan]

As of 2pm, 4 January 2020, the Ministry of Health has been notified of one suspect case involving a 3 year-old female Chinese national with pneumonia and travel history to Wuhan. The case has not visited the Huanan seafood wholesale market in Wuhan associated with the cluster of pneumonia of unknown cause.

The case has been warded for further assessment and treatment, and isolated as a precautionary measure. The case is currently in stable condition. Preliminary tests showed that the case is positive for Respiratory Syncytial Virus, a common cause for childhood pneumonia. Investigations are ongoing to confirm this as the cause.

COVID-19 vaccination for seniors will commence island-wide from next Monday, 22 February.

Over the next three weeks, seniors aged 70 years and above can expect to receive personalised letters inviting them to sign up for vaccination. We will start by inviting seniors living near polyclinics or vaccination centres, so that they can be conveniently vaccinated at a vaccination site near their home. All seniors will be able to receive their vaccination by mid-March when we have opened a vaccination centre in each town. We expect all the letters to reach our seniors aged 70 years and above by the first week of March.

Thereafter we will move to vaccinate the seniors aged 60 to 69 years. They will receive their invitation letters around the middle of March, and the vaccination will commence from around end-March onwards.

Upon receiving the invitation letter, seniors can register online for their vaccination at vaccine.gov.sg, and then receive an SMS with a unique link to book their vaccination appointments. Those who require assistance booking their vaccination appointments can bring their invitation letter to any community centre/club from today.

We will also be setting up more vaccination centres. By the middle of March, 31 vaccination centres will be in operation, with at least one vaccination centre in each town. In total, there will eventually be around 40 vaccination centres. These centres, together with the polyclinics and selected Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs), will ensure that every Singaporean and long-term resident in Singapore who is medically eligible can receive their vaccinations conveniently.

Vaccination is critical to protect us and our loved ones against COVID-19. This collective protection will become more effective as more people are vaccinated and is a key enabler allowing us to return to normalcy. We strongly encourage everyone to get vaccinated when your turn comes, so that as a society, we can keep each other safe from the disease.

Find out more here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/start-of-covid-19-vaccination-for-seniors

In the next few days, seniors above 70 years old will progressively receive notification to book appointments for their Covid-19 vaccination. Since late January, selected Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs) across the island have been providing COVID-19 vaccination to healthcare workers.

The PHPCs have been playing an integral role in the fight against COVID-19 pandemic, from providing subsidised consultation and treatment for acute respiratory infections to conducting COVID-19 swab tests to help us quickly detect cases.

As we ramp up our vaccination efforts, some of these will now play a new role as vaccination sites. These selected PHPCs, along with our 20 polyclinics and vaccination centres, ensure that everyone has convenient and easy access to COVID-19 vaccination.

Vaccination is crucial in protecting ourselves and our loved ones against COVID-19, as well as others who cannot be vaccinated due to medical reasons. When your turn comes, I strongly encourage you to get vaccinated if you are medically eligible! This collective protection will become more effective as more of us are vaccinated and will enable us to return to normalcy. Remember, no one is safe, unless everyone is safe!

This Chinese New Year, many of our healthcare workers are working hard to keep healthcare services running in Singapore and to continue to fight the pandemic at the frontline. Minister for Health, Mr Gan Kim Yong , has recorded a special video message for our healthcare workers to thank them for their tireless efforts to keep fellow Singaporeans safe.

To all of our healthcare colleagues, thank you for bringing comfort and cheer to our patients over this festive season. Your dedication and tenacity will stand us in good stead as we soldier on in our battle against COVID-19.

We wish everyone a happy and healthy Chinese New Year!

We may be celebrating this Lunar “niu” Year a little differently but it is no less meaningful! Keeping gatherings small means we can focus on connecting with our loved ones. Send your warm wishes to friends and family virtually if you can, and keep them safe. Remember the auspicious number eight as you arrange for meet-ups or home visits, and limit visits to not more than 2 other households a day! And keep your mask on and practise safe distancing when you are out. Let’s continue to keep one another safe while we enjoy the festivities.

Wishing everyone good health this Lunar New Year!

1,033 general practitioner (GP) clinics, of which 758 are Public Health Preparedness Clinics (PHPCs), will be open at various times during the Chinese New Year public holidays from 11 to 14 February 2021.

If you feel unwell during the festivities, we encourage you to visit your GP or a 24-hour clinic for minor, self-limiting conditions. Seek medical treatment at a hospital’s Accident & Emergency (A&E) department only for serious or life-threatening emergencies, such as chest pain, breathlessness, and uncontrollable bleeding.

If you have symptoms of an acute respiratory infection (such as cough, sore throat and runny nose) as well as fever and loss of taste or smell, you are strongly encouraged to visit a PHPC and get swabbed early when advised by your doctor. It is important to test for COVID-19 early for early detection, management and containment to prevent further spread of the disease, to help protect your loved ones and vulnerable members of the community.

Check out the list of clinics open here: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/over-1-000-general-practitioner-clinics-open-during-chinese-new-year-holidays

Wishing you and your family good health and happiness this Chinese New Year!

The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation and will tighten border measures for travellers from Vietnam, given the increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vietnam. At the same time, with the improvement in the COVID-19 situation in New South Wales (NSW), Australia, we will adjust our border measures for travellers from NSW, Australia. In addition, to minimise the risk of potential incubating cases leaking into the community for travellers, we will tighten border measures for the Business Travel Pass (BTP) scheme.

From 12 February 2021, 2359 hours, Singapore Citizens (SCs), Permanent Residents (PRs) and Long-Term Pass holders entering Singapore with travel history to Vietnam within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will be subject to an on-arrival COVID-19 PCR test, 14-day SHN at dedicated SHN facilities, and a PCR test before the end of the SHN period. Short-term travellers holding an Air Travel Pass (ATP) with travel history to Vietnam within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will not be allowed to enter Singapore. All travellers who are not SCs or PRs will need to take a COVID-19 PCR test within 72 hours before departure. These travellers will still be required to undergo an On-Arrival Test (OAT) and serve their SHN upon arrival and be tested at the end of SHN.

From 10 February 2021, 2359 hours, SCs, PRs and Long-Term Pass holders returning from NSW, Australia will undergo a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival at the airport in lieu of a 7-day SHN, and if the result is negative, they will be allowed to go about their activities in Singapore. Short-term visitors travelling from NSW, Australia can also apply for an ATP for entry into Singapore on or after 16 February 2021.

Travellers on the BTP scheme are now required to undergo COVID-19 PCR Tests on Day 3, Day 7 and Day 14 of their return. An additional serology test will also be required on Day 3.

As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community.

Read more: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-for-travellers-from-vietnam-new-south-wales-(australia)-and-business-travel-pass-scheme
